00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:16.030
you'll see my bounding box has reappeared.

48
00:02:16.030 --> 00:02:16.530
>> Nice.

49
00:02:17.820 --> 00:02:21.150
>> So what I'm gonna do first is
show you how to resize this banana.

50
00:02:21.150 --> 00:02:24.020
So we want this banana to be
a little bit bigger than it is.

51
00:02:24.020 --> 00:02:28.110
Now if you were to just drag
a corner of it, you'll notice that

52
00:02:28.110 --> 00:02:32.900

which is not exactly what we want.

53
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:36.730
So, I'm just gonna hit Enter and
I'm gonna undo what I just did.

54
00:02:36.730 --> 00:02:41.639
So, what we're gonna do this time is we're
going to hold down on Shift as we click

55
00:02:41.639 --> 00:02:43.240
and hold out this corner.

56
00:02:43.240 --> 00:02:47.910
Okay?
So, ready and let's just.

57
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:50.770
Okay, there we go.

58
00:02:51.880 --> 00:02:54.830
And it keeps the proportions for us.

59
00:02:54.830 --> 00:02:56.350
>> So it constrains it.

60
00:02:56.350 --> 00:02:59.840
It excises the X and Y proportionally.

61
00:02:59.840 --> 00:03:01.960
>> Yes.
So again, make sure to hold down Shift.

62
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:05.910
Because if you don't,
you might distort your best friend or

63
00:03:05.910 --> 00:03:08.030

whoever you're working with.

64
00:03:08.030 --> 00:03:10.740
So don't do that,
it looks really silly on people.

65
00:03:10.740 --> 00:03:15.640
So I'm gonna go ahead and
hit Enter to commit my change.

66
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:17.290
So now I want to rotate it.

67
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:18.720
So there are several ways you can do this.

68
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:23.450

00:03:23.450 --> 00:03:26.870

70
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:30.500
So we're gonna go ahead and

00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:34.400

00:03:34.400 --> 00:03:37.684
So off to the side,
mine says negative 34.3 right now.

73
00:03:37.684 --> 00:03:40.340
That's showing your degree of rotation.

74
00:03:40.340 --> 00:03:44.440
Now if you come up to the very top, you'll
be able to see that number here as well.

75
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:45.780
And you can input your own number.

76
00:03:45.780 --> 00:03:47.380
So let's say that we wanted to do 90.

77
00:03:47.380 --> 00:03:47.880
There you go.

78
00:03:48.990 --> 00:03:50.920
You can go ahead and set your rotation.

79
00:03:50.920 --> 00:03:53.560
>> So you can be very specific
with that rotation if you need to.

80
00:03:53.560 --> 00:03:57.103
>> Exactly, so I'm gonna go ahead and
commit that, so

81
00:03:57.103 --> 00:04:00.743
now we have this crazy
up-side-down banana [LAUGH].

82
00:04:00.743 --> 00:04:01.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

83
00:04:01.600 --> 00:04:05.850
now we're gonna go into this Transform
menu, so we have a lot of options

84
00:04:05.850 --> 00:04:09.940
under this Transform menu, so
we're gonna go to Edit up at the top.

85
00:04:09.940 --> 00:04:12.480
And we're going to click on Transform.

86
00:04:12.480 --> 00:04:15.641
So you'll see off to the side we have
a lot of different options under our

87
00:04:15.641 --> 00:04:17.070
Transform menu.

88
00:04:17.070 --> 00:04:18.350
So scaling is what we did at first.

89
00:04:18.350 --> 00:04:20.330
Scaling is changing its size.

90
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:23.374
Then we just rotated it, but again,
you can get to them in this menu.

91
00:04:23.374 --> 00:04:27.520
It's very flexible in Photoshop
how you're going to do things.

92
00:04:27.520 --> 00:04:30.120
But, next thing I'm gonna show
you is something called skew.

93
00:04:30.120 --> 00:04:30.988
So let's go ahead and select Skew.

94
00:04:30.988 --> 00:04:31.964
>> Bless you.

95
00:04:31.964 --> 00:04:34.504
>> [LAUGH] Very funny.

96
00:04:34.504 --> 00:04:40.670
[LAUGH] So skewing, what happens is you'll
notice that our arrow has turned to white.

97
00:04:40.670 --> 00:04:43.650
So, it's turned to white and
now if I drag it.

98
00:04:44.960 --> 00:04:51.960
We're distorting its angle now,
it's basically how it looks on the page.

99
00:04:51.960 --> 00:04:54.550
So if we were to have
something like a sign.

100
00:04:54.550 --> 00:04:58.480
Let's say that you took a picture of
your favorite street downtown and

101
00:04:58.480 --> 00:05:01.030
you wanted to put a banana on the sign for
some reason.

102
00:05:01.030 --> 00:05:04.460
You can skew the banana in a way
to better fit on the sign.

103
00:05:04.460 --> 00:05:07.820
Or we're gonna go over a few other
different transformation options,

104
00:05:07.820 --> 00:05:09.610
that will allow you to
do just that as well.

105
00:05:09.610 --> 00:05:11.890
>> Almost like you can give it
a little bit of perspective.

106
00:05:11.890 --> 00:05:14.170
>> Exactly, there actually is
perspective on here, as well.

107
00:05:14.170 --> 00:05:16.930
>> Okay.
>> We're gonna go back to transform, and

108
00:05:16.930 --> 00:05:19.780
this time we're going to select, distort.

109
00:05:19.780 --> 00:05:23.610
So, distort is also our
little white arrow.

110
00:05:23.610 --> 00:05:27.180
And it works very similar
to what we were just doing.

111
00:05:27.180 --> 00:05:28.780
I'm gonna go ahead and hit Enter on that.

112
00:05:30.260 --> 00:05:32.580
And now I'm gonna show you
the perspective like you just mentioned.

113
00:05:32.580 --> 00:05:37.650
So we're gonna go to Transform >
Perspective and we can drag out exactly

114
00:05:37.650 --> 00:05:42.730
how it looks, so if we want our banana
to look 3D you can do that in here.

115
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:45.530
So we've really changed our banana now.

116
00:05:45.530 --> 00:05:47.340
It doesn't even look

117
00:05:47.340 --> 00:05:50.278

118
00:05:50.278 --> 00:05:51.830
>> I think so.

00:05:51.830 --> 00:05:54.610
So lets go back to Edit and
Transform again and

00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:56.510
then beneath that you'll

00:05:56.510 --> 00:05:58.760
So Warp is a really fun one.

00:05:58.760 --> 00:06:03.500
Warp, a grid comes up and
we can select these little dots and

00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:05.705

124
00:06:05.705 --> 00:06:09.350
>> Wow.

125
00:06:09.350 --> 00:06:10.562
>> We twisted our banana.

126
00:06:10.562 --> 00:06:12.170
I'm gonna go ahead and hit Enter on that.

00:06:12.170 --> 00:06:15.115
So now we this abstract

128
00:06:15.115 --> 00:06:16.866
[LAUGH]
>> That is beautiful.

129
00:06:16.866 --> 00:06:17.371
[LAUGH]
>> Thank you.

130
00:06:17.371 --> 00:06:22.940
[LAUGH] Lets go back to Edit and

00:06:22.940 --> 00:06:26.365
So right beneath all of those options

00:06:26.365 --> 00:06:28.130

133
00:06:28.130 --> 00:06:30.409
So you can go ahead and
click that if you'd like.

134
00:06:30.409 --> 00:06:33.390
And there we go,
we've rotated it 180 degrees.

135
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:35.040
Now as you noticed before,

136
00:06:35.040 --> 00:06:38.930
when I did our rotation where I had
our little arrows out to the side.

137
00:06:38.930 --> 00:06:40.830
You can also enter the 180 there as well.

138
00:06:40.830 --> 00:06:41.850
>> Okay.

139
00:06:41.850 --> 00:06:43.480
>> So lots of different options.

140
00:06:43.480 --> 00:06:44.920
Let's go back here to Transform.

141
00:06:44.920 --> 00:06:48.840
You can do clockwise,
you can also do counterclockwise.

142
00:06:48.840 --> 00:06:51.007
Very quick and easy.

143
00:06:51.007 --> 00:06:55.025
Let's go back to Transform again and
you'll see we have Flip Horizontal and

00:06:55.025 --> 00:06:55.920
Flip Vertical.

00:06:55.920 --> 00:06:58.670
Have you ever flipped horizontal or

146
00:06:58.670 --> 00:07:00.110
>> A couple of times, yes.

00:07:00.110 --> 00:07:01.328
But I always get it confused,

00:07:01.328 --> 00:07:04.070
which one is flipping horizontal

149
00:07:04.070 --> 00:07:07.410
I typically have to do one and
go that's the one I want or no,

150
00:07:07.410 --> 00:07:08.380
that's not the one I want.

151
00:07:08.380 --> 00:07:10.150
Undo and do the other one.

152
00:07:10.150 --> 00:07:12.320
>> All right, so let's see what

153
00:07:12.320 --> 00:07:13.190
>> Okay.
>> All right.

154
00:07:14.470 --> 00:07:15.250
And there we go.

155
00:07:15.250 --> 00:07:16.350
>> Nice.

156
00:07:16.350 --> 00:07:20.234
>> So it went from left to
a reflection of itself on the right.

00:07:20.234 --> 00:07:24.060
And let's see what happens if we
were to go ahead and Flip Vertical.

158
00:07:25.350 --> 00:07:27.730
So vertical is your up and down.

159
00:07:27.730 --> 00:07:28.350
>> Okay.

160
00:07:28.350 --> 00:07:29.830
Horizontal is yoor side to side.

161
00:07:29.830 --> 00:07:31.300
>> I will remember that.

162
00:07:31.300 --> 00:07:33.927
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

163
00:07:33.927 --> 00:07:38.740
also under Transform we have
Puppet Warp and Perspective Warp.

00:07:38.740 --> 00:07:43.229
Now these are more advanced tools if you
like to do more advanced transformations.

165
00:07:43.229 --> 00:07:47.080
So Puppet Warp is something that might
be used if you're a photographer and

166
00:07:47.080 --> 00:07:50.710

167
00:07:50.710 --> 00:07:52.980
So maybe their arm is up in

168
00:07:52.980 --> 00:07:54.260
You don't like it.

169
00:07:54.260 --> 00:07:57.100
You can actually set points and

170
00:07:57.100 --> 00:07:59.770
shift the arm to make it look

00:08:00.820 --> 00:08:01.990
That's pretty unbelievable.

00:08:01.990 --> 00:08:03.164
>> That is amazing, yeah.

173
00:08:03.164 --> 00:08:05.810
>> Perspective Warp works

00:08:05.810 --> 00:08:08.570
let's say that you had a picture of

00:08:08.570 --> 00:08:11.570

fake advertisement up there.

176
00:08:11.570 --> 00:08:12.120
You could,

177
00:08:12.120 --> 00:08:16.030

178
00:08:16.030 --> 00:08:19.360
So that way it has more 3D
kind of dimension going on.

179
00:08:20.550 --> 00:08:21.700
>> That is pretty impressive.

180
00:08:21.700 --> 00:08:25.540
Although it does make me think you can't

181
00:08:25.540 --> 00:08:29.510
>> That's exactly right
with Photoshop [LAUGH].

182
00:08:29.510 --> 00:08:31.910
Okay, so
now I'm gonna show you how to zoom.

00:08:31.910 --> 00:08:34.970
So, zooming is something that you're gonna
want to know how to do in Photoshop,

184
00:08:34.970 --> 00:08:38.420
because chances are, you're going to
be working on a very close level.

185
00:08:38.420 --> 00:08:41.970
So you might even be looking
at pixels versus pixels.

186
00:08:41.970 --> 00:08:44.750
So I'm going to show you
different ways to zoom.

187
00:08:44.750 --> 00:08:47.700
The first one is to go
to View up at the top.

188
00:08:47.700 --> 00:08:52.277
So under View you'll see Zoom In,
Zoom Out, Fit on Screen, 100%, 200%,

189
00:08:52.277 --> 00:08:52.991
Print Size.

190
00:08:52.991 --> 00:08:54.220
They're all there for you.

191
00:08:54.220 --> 00:08:56.210
You're welcome to click on that.

192
00:08:56.210 --> 00:08:57.270
So I'm just gonna go ahead and click in.

193
00:08:57.270 --> 00:08:58.890
And there, we zoomed in once.

194
00:09:00.310 --> 00:09:04.490
The other thing that you can do
is go ahead and do Cmd++or Cmd+-.

I highly recommend doing
your shortcuts for

00:09:06.943 --> 00:09:10.680
Ctrl+- Ctrl++ depending on
whether you're on a PC or a Mac.

197
00:09:10.680 --> 00:09:15.490
So we're gonna go ahead and I'm just
going to just click several times and

00:09:15.490 --> 00:09:18.620
you'll see that we are down

199
00:09:19.650 --> 00:09:20.910
So do you know what a pixel is?

200
00:09:20.910 --> 00:09:22.510
Have you ever heard of a pixel?

201
00:09:22.510 --> 00:09:24.320
>> I don't know the formal
definition of one, no.

202
00:09:25.500 --> 00:09:29.720
>> Okay,
well a pixel is just a tiny block of color

203
00:09:29.720 --> 00:09:34.030
that builds upon other blocks of
colors to create a big image, okay?

204
00:09:34.030 --> 00:09:34.710
>> Okay.

205
00:09:34.710 --> 00:09:36.240
>> So now we're really zoomed in.

206
00:09:36.240 --> 00:09:38.630
I don't even know where I am in
this document right now, and

00:09:38.630 --> 00:09:40.640
now I need to figure out how to get back.

208
00:09:40.640 --> 00:09:44.080
Now if I were to just click and drag,
I'd actually be moving the banana,

209
00:09:44.080 --> 00:09:46.250
which is not what I wanna do.

210
00:09:46.250 --> 00:09:49.220
So what we're going to do
is we're going to learn

211
00:09:49.220 --> 00:09:52.000
how to do more of a panning type option.

212
00:09:52.000 --> 00:09:54.600
So over on the left you'll
notice we have a hand.

213
00:09:54.600 --> 00:09:55.440
It's kind of waving.

214
00:09:55.440 --> 00:09:56.380
It's saying hello.

215
00:09:56.380 --> 00:10:00.820
You can click on the hand tool and that
allows you to adjust in your canvas so

216
00:10:00.820 --> 00:10:02.800
I'm going to zoom out so
you can actually see this.

217
00:10:04.070 --> 00:10:10.040
So we're adjusting our canvas without

218
00:10:10.040 --> 00:10:14.720
The other way to do that is to click
on the space bar, so the space bar will

00:10:14.720 --> 00:10:19.093

220
00:10:19.093 --> 00:10:22.465
Now it's very helpful if you have
a very complicated document and

221
00:10:22.465 --> 00:10:25.343
you're trying to get over to
a very specific part of it,

222
00:10:25.343 --> 00:10:28.008
you can use this hand or
your space bar to get there.

223
00:10:28.008 --> 00:10:29.759
>> Very nice.

224
00:10:29.759 --> 00:10:33.580
>> Okay, the other great thing about
panning or using your space bar is

00:10:33.580 --> 00:10:37.810
it will default back to your
original tool that you were using.

00:10:37.810 --> 00:10:40.360
So let's say that you're trying
to cut out a part of an image.

227
00:10:40.360 --> 00:10:45.830
You cut it out, but then you need to
use the hand tool real quick to move.

228
00:10:45.830 --> 00:10:48.972
Once you let go of the space bar,
it'll still be on you other tool.

229
00:10:48.972 --> 00:10:49.980
>> That's convenient.

230
00:10:49.980 --> 00:10:50.990
>> Yes, very helpful.

231
00:10:52.070 --> 00:10:54.730
Okay, so any questions about
the transformations part?

00:10:54.730 --> 00:10:59.340
We're going to talk a little bit more

233
00:10:59.340 --> 00:11:00.540

234
00:11:00.540 --> 00:11:02.730
It is amazing what you can
do with the transform tool.

235
00:11:02.730 --> 00:11:04.070
Very cool stuff.

236
00:11:04.070 --> 00:11:05.260
>> Yeah, very cool.

237
00:11:05.260 --> 00:11:08.590
All right, so now what we're going
to do is I'm gonna show you how to

00:11:08.590 --> 00:11:10.490
resize an image in Photoshops.

00:11:10.490 --> 00:11:14.650
We learned how to open an image before,

00:11:14.650 --> 00:11:17.340
So let's go to File > Open,

00:11:17.340 --> 00:11:20.490
you can open any kind of image on

242
00:11:20.490 --> 00:11:25.620
I'm going to go ahead and

00:11:25.620 --> 00:11:26.372
This is Cinnamon.

244
00:11:26.372 --> 00:11:27.055
>> Aw, hi Cinnamon.

245
00:11:27.055 --> 00:11:28.150

00:11:28.150 --> 00:11:29.765

00:11:29.765 --> 00:11:31.179

00:11:31.179 --> 00:11:32.570

So, I'm gonna show you

So it's right now in pixels and if I

00:11:50.710 --> 00:11:54.820
I could change it to inches, and you'll
see it's little bit bigger than an 8x8.

256
00:11:54.820 --> 00:11:58.980
Let's say that I wanted it, a little

00:11:58.980 --> 00:12:02.020

You'll notice my height changed as well.

The reason why is because of this

What this does is it makes sure that

00:12:15.960 --> 00:12:18.730

we don't want distorted images.

00:12:18.730 --> 00:12:21.180
We don't want Cinnamon to,

00:12:21.180 --> 00:12:21.880
She's so small.

265
00:12:21.880 --> 00:12:23.120
We don't want that to happen.

266
00:12:23.120 --> 00:12:25.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, what we're gonna do is we're going

267
00:12:25.340 --> 00:12:26.060
to go ahead and do that.

268
00:12:26.060 --> 00:12:28.360
And then you'll notice that we
have something called Resample.

269
00:12:28.360 --> 00:12:33.670
So if you have Resample checked, it will
make sure that your pixels react properly.

270
00:12:33.670 --> 00:12:35.785
So let's go ahead and
see what happens when we click OK.

271
00:12:37.410 --> 00:12:39.240
So you'll notice that it
looks like we zoomed out.

272
00:12:39.240 --> 00:12:42.536
We didn't,
It's just that our file got smaller.

273
00:12:42.536 --> 00:12:44.134
Does that make sense?
>> Very good, it does.

274
00:12:44.134 --> 00:12:47.690
Is resampling something you should
do every time you change the size?

275
00:12:47.690 --> 00:12:52.000
>> Yes, that way you don't
damage your proportions or

276
00:12:52.000 --> 00:12:53.320
damage the way the pixels look.

277
00:12:53.320 --> 00:12:53.930
>> Okay.

278
00:12:53.930 --> 00:12:58.420
>> Okay, so the other thing we're
gonna learn how to do is cropping.

279
00:12:58.420 --> 00:13:00.970
Cropping is destructive.

280
00:13:00.970 --> 00:13:02.804
So what that means is
once you crop something,

281
00:13:02.804 --> 00:13:04.610
you are deleting those pixels forever.

282
00:13:04.610 --> 00:13:07.865
Say goodbye to whatever part of
the picture, we're not gonna see it again.

283
00:13:07.865 --> 00:13:08.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

284
00:13:08.870 --> 00:13:10.500
we're going to crop part of this image.

285
00:13:10.500 --> 00:13:12.050
I'm gonna zoom it a little bit.

286
00:13:12.050 --> 00:13:13.870
>> Crop carefully and responsibly.

287
00:13:13.870 --> 00:13:15.570
>> Crop carefully and very responsibly.

288
00:13:15.570 --> 00:13:20.510
[LAUGH] So I just zoomed in so that way we
could see Cinnamon a little bit better,

289
00:13:20.510 --> 00:13:23.450
so I did my Cmd++ or your Ctrl++.

290
00:13:23.450 --> 00:13:25.721
And there,
now we have her exactly where we want her.

291
00:13:25.721 --> 00:13:28.570
Now I don't want that
TV in the background.

292
00:13:28.570 --> 00:13:30.490
That's kinda ruining my
picture of Cinnamon.

293
00:13:30.490 --> 00:13:32.230
So let's fix it a little bit.

294
00:13:32.230 --> 00:13:35.190
We're gonna go over to the Crop tool,
which is over on the left.

295
00:13:35.190 --> 00:13:37.410
It looks like two intersecting boxes.

296
00:13:38.680 --> 00:13:42.310
It's also a shortcut C, so
if you need it that way, there you go.

297
00:13:42.310 --> 00:13:45.950
Now up in the top left, you'll see all
the different options for cropping.

298
00:13:45.950 --> 00:13:48.490
So you can do square,
you can do original ratio.

299
00:13:48.490 --> 00:13:51.204
You can do all sorts of different things
that you're going to need to find what

300
00:13:51.204 --> 00:13:52.928
works best for your image.

301
00:13:52.928 --> 00:13:56.830
I'm just gonna go ahead and
leave it on my one to one square.

302
00:13:56.830 --> 00:14:01.197
So you'll notice that we have little
dark lines around the edge of our photo.

303
00:14:01.197 --> 00:14:03.695
What we're gonna do is,
I'm gonna select one of those,

304
00:14:03.695 --> 00:14:07.320
I'm gonna select this top one and
drag it down ever so slightly.

305
00:14:07.320 --> 00:14:13.250
Since I have square selected,
it's keeping my image as square, okay?

306
00:14:13.250 --> 00:14:15.010
So I have her exactly where I want her.

307
00:14:15.010 --> 00:14:18.176
Now I have to confirm this crop.

308
00:14:18.176 --> 00:14:20.220
So I'm gonna go ahead and hit Enter, or

309
00:14:20.220 --> 00:14:22.530
you can hit the check
to commit your change.

310
00:14:22.530 --> 00:14:24.810
So I'm going to hit Enter,
and there we go.

311
00:14:24.810 --> 00:14:26.370
Now we don't have the TV anymore.

312
00:14:26.370 --> 00:14:27.360
>> Beautiful
>> Yeah.

313
00:14:27.360 --> 00:14:28.700
>> Now we can focus in on Cinnamon.

314
00:14:28.700 --> 00:14:31.456
>> We can focus in on Cinnamon's
little face and her little bows.

315
00:14:31.456 --> 00:14:32.110
>> Very good.

316
00:14:32.110 --> 00:14:33.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

317
00:14:33.570 --> 00:14:35.490
>> Wow, that's a lot of great information.

318
00:14:35.490 --> 00:14:38.950
A lot of things I can do with that
image when it comes to transforming.

319
00:14:38.950 --> 00:14:40.630
I can do pretty much whatever I want.

320
00:14:40.630 --> 00:14:44.790
Resize it, flip it, rotate it,
crop it, fantastic.

321
00:14:44.790 --> 00:14:47.020
Anything else we need to go over
in this particular episode?

322
00:14:47.020 --> 00:14:48.790
>> No, I think that's pretty much it.

323
00:14:48.790 --> 00:14:52.820
So now that you've learned how to open,
how to place, how to crop, go ahead and

324
00:14:52.820 --> 00:14:54.250
try some of your own photos.

325
00:14:54.250 --> 00:14:57.310
Maybe you wanna try resizing
your favorite picture.

326
00:14:57.310 --> 00:14:59.010
Go ahead and try it.

327
00:14:59.010 --> 00:15:00.010
>> Very good, all right.

328
00:15:00.010 --> 00:15:01.430
Well, thank you, Kara, for that one.

329
00:15:01.430 --> 00:15:02.570
A lot of great information there.

330
00:15:02.570 --> 00:15:03.660
Enjoyed doing this with you.

331
00:15:03.660 --> 00:15:05.960
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

332
00:15:05.960 --> 00:15:08.320
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

333
00:15:08.320 --> 00:15:09.435
>> And I'm Kara Page.

334
00:15:09.435 --> 00:15:11.279
>> And we'll see you next time.

335
00:15:11.279 --> 00:15:18.854
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Overview of Layers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:10.005
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.423 --> 00:00:15.779
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.779 --> 00:00:18.036
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and

4
00:00:18.036 --> 00:00:22.037
today we're gonna be going
over Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

5
00:00:22.037 --> 00:00:25.474
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be taking a look at layers, and

6
00:00:25.474 --> 00:00:27.130
here to help us with that is Ms. Kara.

7
00:00:27.130 --> 00:00:28.500
How are you doing, Kara?

8
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:29.150
>> I'm great.

9
00:00:29.150 --> 00:00:31.600
Are we ready to go ahead and
get started with layers?

10
00:00:31.600 --> 00:00:32.870
>> Absolutely.

11
00:00:32.870 --> 00:00:34.900
>> Okay, so let's go ahead and
get started.

12
00:00:34.900 --> 00:00:36.450
I'm gonna show you
actually with paper first,

13
00:00:36.450 --> 00:00:39.710
because that makes a lot more sense
than jumping right into Photoshop.

14
00:00:39.710 --> 00:00:41.074
So we're gonna go very low tech for
this little exercise.

15
00:00:41.074 --> 00:00:41.991
>> All right.

16
00:00:41.991 --> 00:00:43.203
[LAUGH]
>> So

17
00:00:43.203 --> 00:00:45.760
I'm going to start with three
little sheets of paper.

18
00:00:45.760 --> 00:00:49.330
So let's go ahead and
turn on the overhead cam for this.

19
00:00:49.330 --> 00:00:51.290
Okay so now you can see my workspace.

20
00:00:51.290 --> 00:00:53.330
Let's line it up just so.

21
00:00:53.330 --> 00:00:56.780
Okay we have this lovely little rectangle.

22
00:00:56.780 --> 00:00:58.770
Okay, so that's a layer, okay.?

23
00:00:58.770 --> 00:01:00.370
Play along with me this is a layer.

24
00:01:00.370 --> 00:01:02.308
Now I'm going to stack
something on top of it.

25
00:01:02.308 --> 00:01:08.540
So it's going to be this little
green Post-It Note, okay?

26
00:01:08.540 --> 00:01:11.275
So these two are completely
separate things, but

27
00:01:11.275 --> 00:01:13.840
they're sitting on top of each other,
so now we have two layers.

28
00:01:13.840 --> 00:01:16.900
>> So they look like they're interacting,
but they're actually on separate layers so

29
00:01:16.900 --> 00:01:17.720
they're really not.

30
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:19.950
>> Exactly.
And then we have a third.

31
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:23.190
So here we have our third
little swirly layer.

32
00:01:23.190 --> 00:01:25.890
So this layer is mostly
covering up the second,

33
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:28.820
which isn't ideal for what we want.

34
00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:31.250
But we could do several things
in Photoshop to adjust this.

35
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:34.420
The first thing we could do
is rearrange our layer order.

36
00:01:34.420 --> 00:01:39.780
So let's move this red guy and
let's put him all the way to the bottom.

37
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:42.010
Ok, so now he's the bottom layer.

38
00:01:42.010 --> 00:01:46.450
Now we can decide, okay, I want the green
to be over here slightly overlapping.

39
00:01:46.450 --> 00:01:48.488
I want this rectangle to be over here.

40
00:01:48.488 --> 00:01:50.648
They're all separate from each other, so

41
00:01:50.648 --> 00:01:53.834
you can do whatever you want to
them without editing the other.

42
00:01:53.834 --> 00:01:55.877
So let's pretend that we had scissors,
okay?

43
00:01:55.877 --> 00:01:59.440
And you wanted to cut out a little
shape on one of these shapes.

44
00:01:59.440 --> 00:02:01.610
So we're gonna make one into a snowflake.

45
00:02:01.610 --> 00:02:02.727
You could do that to, say,

46
00:02:02.727 --> 00:02:06.880
the green one without affecting any other
layer because it's completely separate.

47
00:02:06.880 --> 00:02:07.850
>> Nice.

48
00:02:07.850 --> 00:02:08.920
Okay.
>> Okay?

49
00:02:08.920 --> 00:02:09.700
>> I like that visual aid.

50
00:02:09.700 --> 00:02:10.306
Very good.
>> [LAUGH]

51
00:02:10.306 --> 00:02:10.818
>> [LAUGH]

52
00:02:10.818 --> 00:02:11.328
>> All right,

53
00:02:11.328 --> 00:02:14.820
so we're gonna be talking about something
called merging layers, as well.

54
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:17.630
So if you just think back to this whole

55
00:02:17.630 --> 00:02:22.660
paper idea it will help you with things
like merging, flattening, grouping.

56
00:02:22.660 --> 00:02:24.850
So are we ready to go ahead and
get started in Photoshop?

57
00:02:24.850 --> 00:02:25.870
>> Absolutely.

58
00:02:25.870 --> 00:02:27.249
>> Okay.
So let's go ahead and

59
00:02:27.249 --> 00:02:28.639
get our screens ready here.

60
00:02:32.307 --> 00:02:35.366
Okay, so what we're gonna do first
is we're going to go ahead and

61
00:02:35.366 --> 00:02:36.640
select a new document.

62
00:02:36.640 --> 00:02:38.867
So hit New.

63
00:02:38.867 --> 00:02:42.810
And I'm just gonna use a standard U.S.
paper, eight and a half by eleven.

64
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:44.490
Because it really doesn't matter for
what we're doing so

65
00:02:44.490 --> 00:02:46.730
we're just gonna go ahead
with the default size.

66
00:02:46.730 --> 00:02:47.470
So hit OK.

67
00:02:48.750 --> 00:02:51.510
Now the first thing that you'll
notice is we have a Layers panel.

68
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:56.710
The Layers panel is down in your bottom
right corner of the screen, right here.

69
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:58.290
Okay, you'll see the word Layers, and

70
00:02:58.290 --> 00:03:01.110
then it kind of looks like
collapsible folders right there.

71
00:03:01.110 --> 00:03:04.660
So you'll notice we actually have a layer
here, and it's called Background.

72
00:03:04.660 --> 00:03:07.840
So it'll say Background, and
it'll have this little lock icon there.

73
00:03:08.960 --> 00:03:11.870
Now it's locked, which means you
wouldn't be able to edit it at all.

74
00:03:11.870 --> 00:03:15.800
So if I wanted to do something like erase
part of this background I wouldn't be able

75
00:03:15.800 --> 00:03:17.450
to because it's locked.

76
00:03:17.450 --> 00:03:20.430
So let's go ahead and
unlock our background layer first.

77
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:25.400
So the easiest way to do that is to
either click on the lock icon, or

78
00:03:25.400 --> 00:03:27.360
what you can do is
double-click on your layer.

79
00:03:27.360 --> 00:03:28.320
Either one works, okay?

80
00:03:29.580 --> 00:03:31.610
So you'll notice now
that it's called Layer 0.

81
00:03:31.610 --> 00:03:34.870
I don't like to call my layers
just Layer 1, Layer 2, Layer 3..

82
00:03:34.870 --> 00:03:35.585
That's not descriptive.

83
00:03:35.585 --> 00:03:36.607
You're gonna lose things.

84
00:03:36.607 --> 00:03:37.547
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

85
00:03:37.547 --> 00:03:39.790
[LAUGH]
>> So let's rename this layer.

86
00:03:39.790 --> 00:03:43.600
What we're gonna do is we're gonna
double-click where it says Layer 0.

87
00:03:43.600 --> 00:03:47.202
Make sure to select the word, though,
and not the icon to the left.

88
00:03:47.202 --> 00:03:51.580
So double-click and I'm going to name
this Background, so I know what it is.

89
00:03:52.700 --> 00:03:55.720
And I just hit Enter
once I was done typing.

90
00:03:55.720 --> 00:03:58.340
Okay, so now we have a layer.

91
00:03:58.340 --> 00:04:00.120
Now we want to add another layer.

92
00:04:00.120 --> 00:04:03.610
So what you're going to do is you're going
to find the little icon in the bottom

93
00:04:03.610 --> 00:04:07.340
corner that looks like a sticky note
with a little corner turned up.

94
00:04:07.340 --> 00:04:08.870
So I'm going to click on that.

95
00:04:08.870 --> 00:04:11.100
If you hover over it,
it also says Create New Layer.

96
00:04:12.400 --> 00:04:14.669
So now we have an empty Layer 1.

97
00:04:14.669 --> 00:04:19.064
You can tell it's empty because it has
a checkerboard pattern right here on

98
00:04:19.064 --> 00:04:20.140
its icon.

99
00:04:20.140 --> 00:04:22.427
That means that there's nothing there,
okay?

100
00:04:22.427 --> 00:04:23.461
So I'm gonna name this one.

101
00:04:23.461 --> 00:04:25.342
I'm going to name this one Line.

102
00:04:25.342 --> 00:04:27.804
So I'm gonna double-click
on the word again.

103
00:04:27.804 --> 00:04:30.930
And I'm just going to write Line,
and hit Enter.

104
00:04:30.930 --> 00:04:33.212
So now we have our own
layer to mess around with.

105
00:04:33.212 --> 00:04:36.620
Now I'm going to use the Brush
tool to create a line.

106
00:04:36.620 --> 00:04:39.240
Now we haven't gone over
the Brush tool in depth.

107
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:40.280
That's completely fine.

108
00:04:40.280 --> 00:04:43.170
Just go along with me because
we're not doing anything in depth.

109
00:04:43.170 --> 00:04:46.830
This is just to show you what
layers are like in Photoshop.

110
00:04:46.830 --> 00:04:49.230
So your Brush icon is all
the way over on the left and

111
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:51.630
it looks exactly like a paintbrush.

112
00:04:51.630 --> 00:04:52.740
So you're going to select that.

113
00:04:54.010 --> 00:04:58.270
And I'm just going to select a pretty
standard brush up at the top.

114
00:04:58.270 --> 00:04:59.465
You can select any of these.

115
00:04:59.465 --> 00:05:01.140
You don't have to worry about
what they mean right now.

116
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:02.860
It really doesn't matter.

117
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:06.040
So I'm gonna click off of that,
and I'm going to select a color.

118
00:05:06.040 --> 00:05:07.610
So right now I'm defaulted to white.

119
00:05:07.610 --> 00:05:09.931
If I paint white on white [LAUGH]
you're not gonna see anything.

120
00:05:09.931 --> 00:05:13.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm going to just pick a red color.

121
00:05:13.870 --> 00:05:15.980
It'll be really bright and vibrant.

122
00:05:15.980 --> 00:05:17.610
It'll be easy for you to see.

123
00:05:17.610 --> 00:05:19.263
So I'm just going to do a little doodle.

124
00:05:20.912 --> 00:05:21.730
Okay?

125
00:05:21.730 --> 00:05:23.490
>> Nice.
>> And there we have a line.

126
00:05:24.730 --> 00:05:27.540
Now if I wanted to erase
part of this line,

127
00:05:27.540 --> 00:05:29.470
I could without affecting
the background layer.

128
00:05:29.470 --> 00:05:31.650
So let me demonstrate that for you.

129
00:05:31.650 --> 00:05:34.760
So I'm gonna come over
here to the Eraser tool.

130
00:05:34.760 --> 00:05:36.800
And I'm just going to
erase part of the line.

131
00:05:36.800 --> 00:05:40.850
And you'll notice that the white
background didn't disappear at all.

132
00:05:40.850 --> 00:05:42.710
Okay, this is the layers-based system.

133
00:05:44.020 --> 00:05:46.960
All right, let's say that I don't
want to look at my line anymore.

134
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:48.880
So for some reason,
I just don't want to look at it.

135
00:05:48.880 --> 00:05:52.360
I want to move on to something
else in my document.

136
00:05:52.360 --> 00:05:54.450
What I can do is hide visibility.

137
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:58.170
So you'll notice to each one of
your layers you have an eyeball.

138
00:05:58.170 --> 00:06:01.380
That indicates whether you have
visibility turned on or off.

139
00:06:01.380 --> 00:06:03.882
So I'm going to go ahead and
click Off, and

140
00:06:03.882 --> 00:06:06.990
now it looks like we have
a blank document again.

141
00:06:06.990 --> 00:06:10.377
>> A mutual friend of ours says you gotta
poke the eye to turn off the layer, right?

142
00:06:10.377 --> 00:06:12.630
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, exactly.

143
00:06:12.630 --> 00:06:14.160
So I'm gonna put this line back on.

144
00:06:14.160 --> 00:06:17.670
And I'm actually going to show you
how to duplicate this layer now.

145
00:06:17.670 --> 00:06:19.560
So I really like what
this line looks like.

146
00:06:19.560 --> 00:06:20.960
It's kinda like a hair curl.

147
00:06:20.960 --> 00:06:22.200
We're gonna go with it.

148
00:06:22.200 --> 00:06:23.340
I'm going to duplicate it.

149
00:06:23.340 --> 00:06:27.120
Now, there are several different
ways to duplicate in Photoshop.

150
00:06:27.120 --> 00:06:29.798
The first way I'm gonna show you is
by right-clicking on the layer,.

151
00:06:29.798 --> 00:06:32.135
So let's go ahead and right-click,

152
00:06:32.135 --> 00:06:35.880
and you'll notice that there
is a little flyout menu.

153
00:06:35.880 --> 00:06:39.270
I'm going to select Duplicate Layer, okay?

154
00:06:39.270 --> 00:06:40.170
Here you can name it.

155
00:06:40.170 --> 00:06:41.259
So I'm going to name mine.

156
00:06:41.259 --> 00:06:45.720
Instead of Line Copy,
I'm gonna name it Line 2.

157
00:06:45.720 --> 00:06:47.280
Okay, so now we have a separate line.

158
00:06:47.280 --> 00:06:50.250
You can't really tell it looks any
different because it layers right on top

159
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:53.640
of the other, so I'm going to show
you how to make sure it's there.

160
00:06:53.640 --> 00:06:57.750
One, you can check the visibility,
or you could use your Move tool.

161
00:06:57.750 --> 00:07:00.910
So your Move tool, again, is that top
tool all the way over to the left.

162
00:07:00.910 --> 00:07:02.650
We just learned about it.

163
00:07:02.650 --> 00:07:04.980
So select your Move tool, click, hold and

164
00:07:04.980 --> 00:07:06.807
drag, and now, magically,
>> Voila.

165
00:07:06.807 --> 00:07:08.618
>> We have more than one line.

166
00:07:08.618 --> 00:07:11.190
[LAUGH] So that's one way of duplicating.

167
00:07:11.190 --> 00:07:14.640
Again that's by right-clicking and
selecting Duplicate Layer.

168
00:07:14.640 --> 00:07:17.220
Let's say you wanna do it a faster way.

169
00:07:17.220 --> 00:07:21.750
Another way that you can do is by
selecting your layer in your Layers panel

170
00:07:21.750 --> 00:07:24.480
and then dragging it down
to the New Layer button.

171
00:07:25.660 --> 00:07:28.565
Again, you'll see we have Line 2 Copy.

172
00:07:28.565 --> 00:07:30.621
It automatically names
it with Copy at the end.

173
00:07:30.621 --> 00:07:32.339
I'm going to change mine to be Line 3.

174
00:07:34.777 --> 00:07:37.590
Okay, and
I'm gonna use the Move tool again.

175
00:07:38.960 --> 00:07:39.600
Move it over here.

176
00:07:39.600 --> 00:07:40.590
>> Nice.

177
00:07:40.590 --> 00:07:47.380
>> Okay, my last and favorite way to
duplicate is by using the ALT key.

178
00:07:47.380 --> 00:07:50.535
So what we're going to do is make sure
that you are on the correct layer and

179
00:07:50.535 --> 00:07:52.053
you have your Move tool selected.

180
00:07:52.053 --> 00:07:55.234
And select ALT or Option on your keyboard.

181
00:07:55.234 --> 00:07:58.879
And you'll notice that
a little double arrow pops up.

182
00:07:58.879 --> 00:08:01.098
That's to show you that you
can duplicate something.

183
00:08:01.098 --> 00:08:03.072
So I'm gonna click,
hold, and drag it over.

184
00:08:03.072 --> 00:08:06.115
And there we have another line.

185
00:08:06.115 --> 00:08:10.625
So I'm going to rename this line
since again I dont like it being

186
00:08:10.625 --> 00:08:14.155
called line3 copy, so
I'm gonna name it line4.

187
00:08:15.160 --> 00:08:19.230
So now we have a lot of lines and
they feel unorganized.

188
00:08:19.230 --> 00:08:22.270
So we're going to make
them feel organized.

189
00:08:22.270 --> 00:08:25.535
So one way that you can do that is
by adding a color coding system to

190
00:08:25.535 --> 00:08:26.760
your layers.

191
00:08:26.760 --> 00:08:30.590
If you right-click on your layer, again,
you'll have the pop-up menu that comes up.

192
00:08:30.590 --> 00:08:34.880
If you come all the way to the bottom,
you'll see you have color options.

193
00:08:34.880 --> 00:08:39.300
So I'm going to make all my lines
red since my lines are red.

194
00:08:39.300 --> 00:08:40.926
So I can come through and

195
00:08:40.926 --> 00:08:45.816
I can actually select more than one
by holding down Shift and clicking.

196
00:08:48.533 --> 00:08:51.570
And let's make them all red.

197
00:08:51.570 --> 00:08:55.780
So, in your layers panel,
now you should have four lines and

198
00:08:55.780 --> 00:08:57.720
they should all have that red indicator.

199
00:08:57.720 --> 00:09:01.760
>> And now that doesn't affect the color
of the object or what you've drawn.

200
00:09:01.760 --> 00:09:03.400
It's just in the layers panel.

201
00:09:03.400 --> 00:09:05.472
>> Correct,
it's almost like using a highlighter.

202
00:09:05.472 --> 00:09:08.180
>> Very good.
>> It's just to remind you of something.

203
00:09:08.180 --> 00:09:11.610
Now let's say that I wanted all of
these lines to be grouped together.

204
00:09:11.610 --> 00:09:15.530
So what that means is I want
them all to be closely related.

205
00:09:15.530 --> 00:09:20.440
So, maybe you are designing a logo, or you
were designing some kind of larger shape,

206
00:09:20.440 --> 00:09:22.230
and you wanted everything
to be interconnected.

207
00:09:22.230 --> 00:09:24.940
So when you went to the move tool,
you moved everything at once.

208
00:09:24.940 --> 00:09:27.420
You do that with what's
called a layer group.

209
00:09:27.420 --> 00:09:28.880
So to find your layer groups,

210
00:09:28.880 --> 00:09:32.870
you're going to come down to the bottom of
your layer panel, and instead of clicking

211
00:09:32.870 --> 00:09:37.260
on that little sticky note icon, you're
going to click on the little folder icon.

212
00:09:37.260 --> 00:09:39.510
If you hover over it'll
say create new group, so

213
00:09:39.510 --> 00:09:40.890
I'm gonna do that, create new group.

214
00:09:41.890 --> 00:09:45.500
And I'm going to double
click where it says Group 1,

215
00:09:45.500 --> 00:09:47.520
and I'm going to name this lines.

216
00:09:48.650 --> 00:09:51.190
So right now, if you collapse your folder,
there's nothing in it,

217
00:09:51.190 --> 00:09:52.440
it's just an empty folder.

218
00:09:52.440 --> 00:09:56.220
We need to move these
lines into our group.

219
00:09:56.220 --> 00:09:59.980
So how I can do that is I can
click hold and drag and drop.

220
00:10:01.510 --> 00:10:05.435
Or you can select more than
one by Shift clicking or

221
00:10:05.435 --> 00:10:10.930
Ctrl clicking and
dragging them up into this folder as well.

222
00:10:10.930 --> 00:10:14.346
So now if I collapse, you won't
see any of our individual layers,

223
00:10:14.346 --> 00:10:15.634
you just see the folder.

224
00:10:15.634 --> 00:10:18.634
And you'll notice if we
go to our move tool now,

225
00:10:18.634 --> 00:10:20.893
we move all of our lines at one time.

226
00:10:20.893 --> 00:10:22.559
>> Very nice.

227
00:10:22.559 --> 00:10:26.143
It quite makes it very easy when you're
starting to work with complex shapes or

228
00:10:26.143 --> 00:10:29.291
photos that have a lot of pieces and
you're gonna move them as a unit or

229
00:10:29.291 --> 00:10:30.780
kinda treat them as a unit.

230
00:10:30.780 --> 00:10:32.540
>> Correct, great.

231
00:10:32.540 --> 00:10:35.090
All right, so
I'm gonna add a new kind of layer now.

232
00:10:35.090 --> 00:10:39.530
So again I'm gonna go down to our

233
00:10:39.530 --> 00:10:42.160
Click on that, and
now we have a blank layer.

234
00:10:42.160 --> 00:10:45.080
So, I'm going to make

235
00:10:45.080 --> 00:10:48.040
Again, we haven't gone over the type
tool in depth, that's completely fine.

00:10:48.040 --> 00:10:50.880
Just do it along with me,

00:10:50.880 --> 00:10:56.820
I'm just going to go over to my T,
and I need to change the color

00:10:56.820 --> 00:10:59.140
from red, because it's going to
be hard to see the difference.

239
00:10:59.140 --> 00:11:02.050
So this little icon up at the top,
that's your color picker.

240
00:11:02.050 --> 00:11:04.520
I'm just gonna make it black, so
you can clearly see the difference.

241
00:11:05.690 --> 00:11:10.087
I'm going to single click on our
document to activate our type tool, and

242
00:11:10.087 --> 00:11:13.131
I'm just going to call
this playing with layers.

243
00:11:16.714 --> 00:11:19.922
This font is a little
bit difficult to read so

244
00:11:19.922 --> 00:11:24.510
I'm just gonna change it to
an Arial Bold and make it larger.

245
00:11:24.510 --> 00:11:28.890
So that way you can clearly see it,
it's right there.

246
00:11:28.890 --> 00:11:31.900
So this layer is on top right
now in our layers panel.

247
00:11:31.900 --> 00:11:35.810
You can see that because your layer
order is in your layers panel.

248
00:11:35.810 --> 00:11:41.140
Now if I were to move our type layer down,
you can see what happens.

249
00:11:41.140 --> 00:11:45.050
All of a sudden,
the lines are overlapping the text, okay?

250
00:11:45.050 --> 00:11:47.951
Or if I move it all the way down
here under my background layer

251
00:11:50.352 --> 00:11:52.540
You won't be able to see it at all.

252
00:11:52.540 --> 00:11:56.960
So that's why it's really important to be

253
00:11:56.960 --> 00:12:00.179
If anything disappears, chances are it's
hidden beneath one of the other layers.

254
00:12:01.490 --> 00:12:02.245
>> Very good.

255
00:12:02.245 --> 00:12:05.991
>> Okay, so I'm going to add a color
code to this one as well just so

256
00:12:05.991 --> 00:12:11.173
it's easier for us to tell the difference,
so I'm going to make this one grey, okay?

257
00:12:11.173 --> 00:12:14.606
All right, so
now we have different kinds of layers,

258
00:12:14.606 --> 00:12:19.660
I'm going to add a shape last, so let's
go ahead and create a new layer again.

259
00:12:20.870 --> 00:12:23.420
And this time I'm going to create a shape.

260
00:12:23.420 --> 00:12:25.480
So our shapes are over here on the left.

261
00:12:25.480 --> 00:12:27.230
Yours is probably
defaulted to a rectangle.

262
00:12:27.230 --> 00:12:29.370
You can use whatever shape you want.

263
00:12:29.370 --> 00:12:34.930
You just click, hold, and
drag out a shape, okay.

264
00:12:34.930 --> 00:12:36.040
There we go.
There's my shape.

265
00:12:37.120 --> 00:12:38.450
So I have a shapes layer now.

00:12:38.450 --> 00:12:42.602
And I'm going to move it

267
00:12:44.485 --> 00:12:46.990
So there, now we have this cool,

268
00:12:46.990 --> 00:12:50.616
I'll make the box a little bit bigger so

269
00:12:50.616 --> 00:12:52.138
>> Very cool.

270
00:12:52.138 --> 00:12:55.859
>> Yeah, I'll go ahead and give
a color code to this as well, just for

00:12:55.859 --> 00:12:57.650
organizational purposes.

00:12:57.650 --> 00:12:59.170
Again, you don't have to use color codes,
but

00:12:59.170 --> 00:13:02.250
it's very helpful if you
have a big layer document.

274
00:13:02.250 --> 00:13:05.060
I mean, you might have a hundred
layers in your document.

275
00:13:05.060 --> 00:13:07.560
>> Wow.
>> It helps to have them organized.

276
00:13:07.560 --> 00:13:11.260
Now, what might have happened to you
if you did drag the rectangle to make

277
00:13:11.260 --> 00:13:15.350
the lines, you may have accidentally
dropped it into your lines folder.

278
00:13:15.350 --> 00:13:19.000
If you did,
now it's part of your lines folder group.

279
00:13:19.000 --> 00:13:20.300
So that's an issue.

280
00:13:20.300 --> 00:13:23.410
What you need to do is pull it
out from there, and just drag and

00:13:23.410 --> 00:13:27.760
drop it outside of the folder, okay?

282
00:13:27.760 --> 00:13:30.760
All right, so
let's say that you like this box here, but

283
00:13:30.760 --> 00:13:34.610
you're not crazy about it, you're thinking
maybe I should have gone with the square,

284
00:13:34.610 --> 00:13:36.130
maybe I should have gone with the circle.

285
00:13:36.130 --> 00:13:38.570
What you can do is delete your layer.

286
00:13:38.570 --> 00:13:40.630
So just like everything else in Photoshop,

287
00:13:40.630 --> 00:13:43.470
there are tons of different
ways to delete a layer.

288
00:13:43.470 --> 00:13:48.690
The easiest way is to select your layer
in the layers panel and hit delete.

289
00:13:48.690 --> 00:13:50.120
>> Easy enough.
>> Easy enough.

290
00:13:50.120 --> 00:13:53.820
I'm gonna undo what I just did so
you can see other ways to delete.

291
00:13:53.820 --> 00:13:57.530
Another way to delete is by clicking and
holding it and dragging it down

292
00:13:57.530 --> 00:14:00.370
to the trash can that's in the bottom
portion of your layers panel.

293
00:14:01.800 --> 00:14:03.710
That's another way to delete.

294
00:14:03.710 --> 00:14:09.228
Then again, yet another way to delete
is by right clicking on your layer,

295
00:14:09.228 --> 00:14:11.721
and deleting from there, okay?

296
00:14:11.721 --> 00:14:14.067
Now, if you choose your
right click method,

297
00:14:14.067 --> 00:14:16.800
it will say are you sure you
want to delete the layer?

298
00:14:17.800 --> 00:14:21.990
Click Yes, you're good to go, okay.

299
00:14:21.990 --> 00:14:26.000
So there's also a concept called
flattening layers in Photoshop.

300
00:14:26.000 --> 00:14:30.570
So flattening layers,
let's think back to our paper, okay.

301
00:14:30.570 --> 00:14:33.160
So these little papers
that we had together,

302
00:14:33.160 --> 00:14:36.530
flattening would be as if we'd glued
them together with super glue.

303
00:14:36.530 --> 00:14:38.000
So now they're all attached and

304
00:14:38.000 --> 00:14:41.900
you can't pull one apart from the other,
that's what flattening layers is.

305
00:14:41.900 --> 00:14:42.840
>> Irreversible.

306
00:14:42.840 --> 00:14:43.510
>> It's irreversible.

307
00:14:43.510 --> 00:14:44.040
>> Gotch you.

308
00:14:44.040 --> 00:14:46.490
>> So if you need to flatten your layers,

309
00:14:46.490 --> 00:14:49.130
you gonna want another copy
of your Photoshop documents.

310
00:14:49.130 --> 00:14:50.010
>> Just in case.

311
00:14:50.010 --> 00:14:54.580
>> Just in case, because once you flatten
your layers it becomes one layer.

312
00:14:54.580 --> 00:14:58.210
Which means you can't edit each individual
layer, you can't add special effects,

313
00:14:58.210 --> 00:15:02.090
you can't change the colors to
just one thing very easily.

314
00:15:02.090 --> 00:15:02.600
>> Okay.

315
00:15:02.600 --> 00:15:04.290
>> Okay, all right, so

316
00:15:04.290 --> 00:15:07.720
let's talk about these thumbnails that
are to the left of the layer names.

317
00:15:07.720 --> 00:15:11.980
You'll notice that the type has a T,
background's just blank,

318
00:15:11.980 --> 00:15:16.400
our lines if we open up our folder you'll
notice that they're transparent with,

319
00:15:16.400 --> 00:15:19.660
you can barely see it, but
there's a little red line there.

320
00:15:19.660 --> 00:15:24.140
Now, these thumbnails help tell
you what kind of layer this is.

321
00:15:24.140 --> 00:15:26.350
So, any kind of text layer will have a T.

322
00:15:26.350 --> 00:15:31.070
If it's something called a smart object,
so something that you placed into

323
00:15:31.070 --> 00:15:35.780
Photoshop, like a picture, it'll have
a little icon in the corner, okay?

324
00:15:35.780 --> 00:15:38.790
Or if you had a shape, it would
have a shape in the corner as well.

325
00:15:38.790 --> 00:15:42.385
This also helps you figure
out which layers are what.

326
00:15:42.385 --> 00:15:46.380
[LAUGH] Now a great thing in Photoshop,
is you can actually search

327
00:15:46.380 --> 00:15:51.610
through your layers if you use a color
coding system, or if you add a filter.

328
00:15:51.610 --> 00:15:54.929
So right to the right of
where it says the word kind,

329
00:15:54.929 --> 00:15:57.104
you'll see you can sort by type.

330
00:15:57.104 --> 00:15:59.525
So I'm going to look just for type layers.

331
00:15:59.525 --> 00:16:04.296
So if I click on the T, you'll notice
my layer panel only has the type.

332
00:16:04.296 --> 00:16:06.155
Little layer there.

333
00:16:06.155 --> 00:16:11.920
Okay, same thing if I were to
do an image which our lines are.

334
00:16:11.920 --> 00:16:14.285
Or if I'd had a shape,
you can sort that way as well.

335
00:16:14.285 --> 00:16:17.620
>> I'd say, that'd be very handy if you're
to add a document, like you were saying,

336
00:16:17.620 --> 00:16:21.300
with 100 different layers on it, being
able to get to the type of layer at least,

337
00:16:21.300 --> 00:16:23.000
now you got a much shorter
list to go through.

338
00:16:23.000 --> 00:16:23.630
>> Exactly.
>> Yeah.

339
00:16:23.630 --> 00:16:25.180
>> Exactly, it's a big time saver.

340
00:16:26.310 --> 00:16:29.640
Okay, so,
a few other things about the layers panel.

341
00:16:29.640 --> 00:16:32.500
So, we've been talking about
this whole idea of a group.

342
00:16:32.500 --> 00:16:34.648
Let's say that you didn't want
something grouped anymore.

343
00:16:34.648 --> 00:16:38.609
Okay, so one of these lines you wanted to
take out, because you want to do something

344
00:16:38.609 --> 00:16:42.270
else with, you can, again,
drag it outside of the folder.

345
00:16:42.270 --> 00:16:45.270
And now it's all of sudden ungrouped,

346
00:16:45.270 --> 00:16:48.370
which means you can move it
separate from everything else.

347
00:16:48.370 --> 00:16:51.860
So grouping is kind of like,
as if you were to take those

348
00:16:51.860 --> 00:16:55.460
paper layers that I showed you,
and put a strip of tape over them.

349
00:16:55.460 --> 00:16:58.420
So maybe it's some duct tape,
something that's not super abrasive.

350
00:16:58.420 --> 00:17:01.196
So, when you pull it off you still can
separate the layers from each other.

351
00:17:01.196 --> 00:17:03.215
>> A little less permanent
than flattening layers.

352
00:17:03.215 --> 00:17:06.170
>> Yes, precisely, precisely.

353
00:17:06.170 --> 00:17:10.430
Okay, so there are a few other things in
this layers panel that are helpful to you.

354
00:17:10.430 --> 00:17:13.930
Just to note, we are gonna be going over
them in the future when we talk about

355
00:17:13.930 --> 00:17:15.620
things like blending modes and
adjustments.

356
00:17:15.620 --> 00:17:19.380
But just so you know where they are now,
we're gonna talk about them briefly.

357
00:17:19.380 --> 00:17:23.790
So you'll see, you probably have a word
that says normal here, if you don't,

358
00:17:23.790 --> 00:17:26.270
it just defaults into
another blending mode.

359
00:17:26.270 --> 00:17:30.190
These are blending modes and
they're used very often in photography.

360
00:17:30.190 --> 00:17:35.840
So let's say that you wanted to layer an
image over itself a few times, you can add

361
00:17:35.840 --> 00:17:40.300
one of these different options and it will
completely change the look of your photo.

362
00:17:41.530 --> 00:17:44.110
So again, we're gonna be going over
those more in depth when we talk about

363
00:17:44.110 --> 00:17:44.940
photography, but

364
00:17:44.940 --> 00:17:47.740
that's where that is in case you're
wondering what a blending mode is.

365
00:17:49.160 --> 00:17:52.560
Okay, so the filter is off to the right,
you can turn it on or off.

366
00:17:53.820 --> 00:17:57.350
Then to the right of Normal
you have Opacity and Fill.

367
00:17:57.350 --> 00:18:01.190
So Opacity and
Fill Are measures of transparency.

368
00:18:01.190 --> 00:18:05.740
So let's go ahead and test this out
with this line that I have selected.

369
00:18:05.740 --> 00:18:08.740
So our line two, you can do it on
anything you want, but I'm going to

370
00:18:08.740 --> 00:18:13.130
lower the opacity, which means you're
going to be able to see through it.

371
00:18:13.130 --> 00:18:15.930
So you'll notice that it's
getting more faded and

372
00:18:15.930 --> 00:18:18.700
faded because I'm adjusting the opacity.

373
00:18:20.130 --> 00:18:22.130
Now we're gonna do
the same thing with fill.

374
00:18:22.130 --> 00:18:23.760
So fill, I'm gonna drop it down from 100.

375
00:18:23.760 --> 00:18:27.190
And you'll notice it looks
pretty much identical.

376
00:18:27.190 --> 00:18:31.370
The reason why, is because opacity and
fill essentially do the same thing, but

377
00:18:31.370 --> 00:18:35.240
they react differently if you
have layer styles on them.

378
00:18:35.240 --> 00:18:37.010
So, if you had a drop shadow, or

379
00:18:37.010 --> 00:18:40.040
if you had some kind of stroke
They would react differently.

380
00:18:40.040 --> 00:18:41.460
>> Okay.

381
00:18:41.460 --> 00:18:41.960
>> Okay.

382
00:18:43.100 --> 00:18:44.460
All right.
Right beneath that,

383
00:18:44.460 --> 00:18:46.120
you'll see you have lock.

384
00:18:46.120 --> 00:18:48.680
So these are all your
different locking options.

385
00:18:48.680 --> 00:18:51.680
Okay.
So if you wanted to lock your transparent

386
00:18:51.680 --> 00:18:52.730
pixels, you can do that.

387
00:18:52.730 --> 00:18:56.060
You can lock your image pixels.

388
00:18:56.060 --> 00:18:59.089
You can lock the position
of whatever the item is.

389
00:19:00.260 --> 00:19:04.730
You can prevent moving in and out of art
boards of you're using art boards, and

390
00:19:04.730 --> 00:19:09.010
you can use just the standard lock button,
which might be the option that you have.

391
00:19:09.010 --> 00:19:15.060
So you can do lock all, or you can select
a certain layer and hit our lock icon So

392
00:19:15.060 --> 00:19:18.010
now that it's locked, I'm not going
to be able to do anything to it.

393
00:19:18.010 --> 00:19:20.200
So I'm gonna come over
here to my move tool.

394
00:19:20.200 --> 00:19:23.020
It's not letting me do a thing now,
nothing.

395
00:19:23.020 --> 00:19:27.230
See, and it says, could not use the move
tool because the layer is locked.

396
00:19:27.230 --> 00:19:28.942
>> That's nice of it to tell you.

397
00:19:28.942 --> 00:19:29.455
>> Yes.
>> [LAUGH]

398
00:19:29.455 --> 00:19:31.415
>> So there is several reasons why you

399
00:19:31.415 --> 00:19:33.080
might want to lock a layer.

400
00:19:33.080 --> 00:19:36.830
Let's say that you are doing
this amazing project and

401
00:19:36.830 --> 00:19:38.930
you really like what one
of your layers looks like.

402
00:19:38.930 --> 00:19:41.370
And you're afraid that you're accidentally
going to make an edit to it and

403
00:19:41.370 --> 00:19:45.380
you don't want to make an edit,
you would lock your layer than.

404
00:19:45.380 --> 00:19:49.360
>> Yeah, I've seen certain way, if you've
got a line on top of some complex thing,

405
00:19:49.360 --> 00:19:51.630
sometimes it can be hard to click
right on that line and move it.

406
00:19:51.630 --> 00:19:54.850
You end up clicking underneath it and
Yup, like it.

407
00:19:54.850 --> 00:19:57.410
>> Precisely.
[LAUGH] Okay,

408
00:19:57.410 --> 00:20:00.780
and then if you come down to
the bottom of our layers panel.

409
00:20:00.780 --> 00:20:06.150
You have an active layer selected,
you'll notice that we have an FX button.

410
00:20:06.150 --> 00:20:07.950
This FX, these are your special effects.

411
00:20:07.950 --> 00:20:09.830
Their your layer styles.

412
00:20:09.830 --> 00:20:12.280
So if you wanted to add
something like a dropped shadow,

413
00:20:12.280 --> 00:20:13.910
this is where you would do it.

414
00:20:13.910 --> 00:20:14.700
So I'll go ahead and

415
00:20:14.700 --> 00:20:18.330
show you an example, let's just do
a drop shot since that I had mentioned.

416
00:20:18.330 --> 00:20:22.060
I'm just going to click OK,
now you'll notice that we have a very

417
00:20:22.060 --> 00:20:25.430
crazy looking-drop shot, probably not
the kind of drop shot you're going to want

418
00:20:25.430 --> 00:20:30.660
to see on your document but at least
now you see this has an effect now.

419
00:20:30.660 --> 00:20:33.980
So you'll notice this does have
an effect and in the Layer panel you'll

420
00:20:33.980 --> 00:20:38.220
see it looks different You'll see there's
an FX and a little arrow next to it.

421
00:20:38.220 --> 00:20:42.000
So this arrow allows you to
collapse the effect, okay?

422
00:20:42.000 --> 00:20:43.880
So if I didn't want to see the effect.

423
00:20:43.880 --> 00:20:45.830
You might have five different
effects on one layer.

424
00:20:45.830 --> 00:20:47.520
It makes your layers panel really long.

425
00:20:47.520 --> 00:20:48.030
>> Hm.

426
00:20:48.030 --> 00:20:48.910
>> It's probably not what you want.

427
00:20:48.910 --> 00:20:51.170
So you'll probably want to collapse them.

428
00:20:51.170 --> 00:20:54.080
The other thing that you can do with your
layer styles now that they're in your

429
00:20:54.080 --> 00:20:58.020
layers panel is you can hit
the visibility icon on that as well.

430
00:20:58.020 --> 00:21:00.080
>> Neat.
>> So you can hit it for all effects or

431
00:21:00.080 --> 00:21:02.380
you can select one specific effect.

432
00:21:02.380 --> 00:21:05.040
So maybe you've added several effects and
your trying to figure out

433
00:21:05.040 --> 00:21:08.850
which one kinda threw off the image, you
can do that by adjusting your visibility.

434
00:21:11.603 --> 00:21:12.103
Okay.

435
00:21:13.106 --> 00:21:17.980
All right and then you can also
do something called a layer mask.

436
00:21:17.980 --> 00:21:20.620
A layer mask is something that we're
going to be going over in depth in

437
00:21:20.620 --> 00:21:21.450
a future lesson.

438
00:21:21.450 --> 00:21:23.700
But this is where you would find it.

439
00:21:23.700 --> 00:21:26.710
Layer masks are great because
they allow you to edit

440
00:21:26.710 --> 00:21:29.810
the layer without destroying
all of the pixels.

441
00:21:29.810 --> 00:21:32.510
So it's a less damaging way
to erase than an eraser.

442
00:21:33.790 --> 00:21:34.760
Okay?

443
00:21:34.760 --> 00:21:38.230
You also have Fill and
Adjustment Layers as well, so

444
00:21:38.230 --> 00:21:40.800
if you wanted to add a color fill,
you could do that.

445
00:21:40.800 --> 00:21:44.070
Or if you wanted to add an adjustment
fill, which would be something like

446
00:21:44.070 --> 00:21:48.120
brightness and contrast, you can do
that at the bottom of your layers panel.

447
00:21:48.120 --> 00:21:49.230
Very cool.

448
00:21:49.230 --> 00:21:52.470
>> Then again, you have your group icon,
you have your new layer icon, and

449
00:21:52.470 --> 00:21:55.440
you have your delete layer icon,
or your trashcan..

450
00:21:56.920 --> 00:22:00.700
So any questions about anything
that we've gone over with layers?

451
00:22:00.700 --> 00:22:03.940
>> Nope, good with questions, I think
you did a great job explaining layers.

452
00:22:03.940 --> 00:22:06.090
We have a good understanding
of what we can do with those.

453
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:07.170
So thank you for that.

454
00:22:07.170 --> 00:22:09.290
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

455
00:22:09.290 --> 00:22:10.740
Remember, we got more coming your way.

456
00:22:10.740 --> 00:22:13.010
But signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

457
00:22:13.010 --> 00:22:13.830
>> And I'm Kara Page.

458
00:22:13.830 --> 00:22:15.785
>> And we'll see you next time.

459
00:22:15.785 --> 00:22:22.085
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Selections
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.359 --> 00:00:15.231
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.231 --> 00:00:16.860
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.860 --> 00:00:21.790
And today we're gonna be doing
Adobe Photoshop CC 2015, and specifically,

5
00:00:21.790 --> 00:00:25.920
we're gonna be looking at ways to
select objects in our project.

6
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:29.180
And here to help us with that is Ms.
Kara Page, how's it going Kara?

7
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:32.780
>> I'm great and let's go ahead and
just dive right into selections,

8
00:00:32.780 --> 00:00:35.440
cuz it's something that's a little
bit more complicated in Photoshop.

9
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:38.580
So this is the first time we're
taking a big step towards something

10
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:39.320
great with Photoshop.

11
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:40.370
>> All right.

12
00:00:40.370 --> 00:00:43.810
So what we're gonna do is we
are going to open the cookies image.

13
00:00:43.810 --> 00:00:47.930
So you can find the cookie image along
with your book, so let's go ahead and

14
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:51.830
go to open, and it's called cookies.jpeg.

15
00:00:51.830 --> 00:00:54.210
So, again I hope you've had a snack-
>> [LAUGH]

16
00:00:54.210 --> 00:00:56.050
>> Because you might get a little hungry.

17
00:00:56.050 --> 00:00:57.040
>> Too late.

18
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:00.310
>> Right, let's go ahead and open that up.

19
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:01.880
So there we have our layer.

20
00:01:01.880 --> 00:01:03.510
And you'll notice that it's locked.

21
00:01:03.510 --> 00:01:05.940
In order to make a selection,
we're going to have to unlock it.

22
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:10.300
So, let's go ahead and hit our little lock
key, which you've just learned about.

23
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:13.830
We're gonna rename it and
I'm gonna name it "cookies".

24
00:01:13.830 --> 00:01:15.680
Okay.
So now we have a cookies background layer,

25
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:20.050
it's unlocked, now we can go ahead and
do something called selection.

26
00:01:20.050 --> 00:01:23.980
Selections allow you to
select part of an image.

27
00:01:23.980 --> 00:01:26.790
There are several different
selection tools in Photoshop.

28
00:01:26.790 --> 00:01:30.240
So we're going to walk through each
one and you can see what they do.

29
00:01:30.240 --> 00:01:35.520
Your selection tools are over on
the left hand side in your Tool panel.

30
00:01:35.520 --> 00:01:40.900
The default top tool for your selection
tools is the rectangular marquee tool.

31
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:45.000
So if you click on that, you'll be
able to see it's a dotted rectangle.

32
00:01:45.000 --> 00:01:50.900
So I'm going to just kind of select my
name out of this little cookies section.

33
00:01:50.900 --> 00:01:54.260
So now that we have it selected you'll see
these running ants, these dotted lines.

34
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:57.060
Let's go ahead and zoom in so
we can further see what we're doing.

35
00:01:57.060 --> 00:02:02.070
So I'm going to hit the Cmd++ or Ctrl++
Again, we've learned about that before.

36
00:02:02.070 --> 00:02:04.365
So that way you can see my
name up front and center.

37
00:02:04.365 --> 00:02:05.450
>> Mm-hm.

38
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:07.140
>> So let's say I don't like
the way that I selected that,

39
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:10.790
maybe I cut off one of the letters,
what I can do is deselect.

40
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:12.493
So I can do CMD+D or

41
00:02:12.493 --> 00:02:16.860
CTRL+D to deselect, that will get
rid of your running ants, okay?

42
00:02:16.860 --> 00:02:22.090
I'm gonna try for that selection again,
so I'm gonna draw my rectangle And

43
00:02:22.090 --> 00:02:26.320
I like this one but
I feel like I need to add to it.

44
00:02:26.320 --> 00:02:30.670
So you can add to a selection
up in the very top left corner.

45
00:02:30.670 --> 00:02:35.360
If you hover over these overlapping
squares it'll say something like add to

46
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:40.760
selection, subtract from selection,
or intersect with selection.

47
00:02:40.760 --> 00:02:42.980
So I'm going to add to this selection.

48
00:02:42.980 --> 00:02:45.200
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
going to draw a box above it.

49
00:02:46.810 --> 00:02:48.800
And now all of a sudden
my box is a lot bigger.

50
00:02:48.800 --> 00:02:50.820
So now I have my entire name there.

51
00:02:50.820 --> 00:02:52.190
>> Very good.

52
00:02:52.190 --> 00:02:52.850
>> Okay?

53
00:02:52.850 --> 00:02:55.560
So same thing is true,
let's say I got too much now.

54
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:58.130
I'm going to go ahead and
subtract from selection.

55
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:00.990
So I'm going to just get
rid of this top part.

56
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:04.880
This is just a little too much in
their refines our selection even more.

57
00:03:07.120 --> 00:03:09.890
So now I have it selected but
what does that even mean.

58
00:03:09.890 --> 00:03:13.170
So it's selected, what am I doing with it.

59
00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:17.120
So if you just keep it as is,
it's not really doing anything.

60
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:20.360
It's just showing you what
you have on your document.

61
00:03:20.360 --> 00:03:21.810
What your trying to select.

62
00:03:21.810 --> 00:03:23.500
Let's say that I wanted to move it.

63
00:03:23.500 --> 00:03:29.260
You could move it if you go to your move
tool, which is up at the very top corner.

64
00:03:29.260 --> 00:03:31.220
And then you'll notice
when you hover over,

65
00:03:31.220 --> 00:03:33.700
there's a little arrow with scissors.

66
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:36.210
That means that you're gonna cut it, which
is probably not what you wanna do, but

67
00:03:36.210 --> 00:03:37.280
we're gonna try it out.

68
00:03:38.470 --> 00:03:42.250
So there we go, I moved my name, which
might be a good thing especially if you

69
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:45.160
have a white background, you're just
trying to move something slightly.

70
00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:49.190
But it looks kind of silly with mine,
because I had a textured background.

71
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:51.340
So I'm going to undo that.

72
00:03:52.660 --> 00:03:54.180
Another thing that you can do is,

73
00:03:54.180 --> 00:03:58.450
now that you have your selection, is you
can actually create a new selection.

74
00:03:58.450 --> 00:04:01.340
So I'm going to do Command C or Control C.

75
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:04.630
And Command V or Control V.

76
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:07.820
Now you'll notice in my layers
panel I have two layers now.

77
00:04:07.820 --> 00:04:12.840
This top layer is a duplicate copy
of what I just selected, okay.

78
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:14.750
>> So not the entire layer, but
just what you had selected.

79
00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:15.290
>> Exactly.

80
00:04:15.290 --> 00:04:18.435
So I'm going to now move my name and
I'm just gonna cut Nick out.

81
00:04:18.435 --> 00:04:20.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's just gonna be Kara and

82
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:24.990
Kara because that's what
these cookies are all about.

83
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:25.630
>> Nick is not happy.
[LAUGH]

84
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:26.700
>> No, not at all.

85
00:04:26.700 --> 00:04:29.310
So, I'm going to rename this so
we know it's a care a copy.

86
00:04:30.330 --> 00:04:32.870
Okay.
So, I just need a quick little selection.

87
00:04:33.950 --> 00:04:35.780
Easy enough,
it was a rectangular marquee tool.

88
00:04:35.780 --> 00:04:38.300
Let's move on to our next marquee tool.

89
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:41.750
So, if you click and
hold down on our rectangular marquee tool,

90
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:44.750
you can select
the elliptical marquee tool.

91
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:49.600
This is a circle, so I can draw a circle
around something I want to select, so

92
00:04:49.600 --> 00:04:55.160
I'm going to create a circle around
this little flower shaped cookie.

93
00:04:55.160 --> 00:04:58.710
Now, I kind of missed it a little bit,
you can nudge your selection.

94
00:04:58.710 --> 00:05:03.480
The way that you nudge a selection in
Photoshop is by using your arrow tools.

95
00:05:03.480 --> 00:05:06.190
So I'm going to just kind
of nudge it a little bit.

96
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:08.920
And there, that's better,
that's what I want.

97
00:05:08.920 --> 00:05:14.010
Now if I wanted to make a copy
again I could, so I'm gonna Ctrl+Z.

98
00:05:14.010 --> 00:05:16.080
See here I'm gonna do that again for you.

99
00:05:16.080 --> 00:05:19.190
There's an error message that says could
not complete the Copy command because

100
00:05:19.190 --> 00:05:21.580
the selected area is empty.

101
00:05:21.580 --> 00:05:23.240
What does that even mean,
what does that mean?

102
00:05:23.240 --> 00:05:28.220
So let's look back at our Layers panel and
make sure we're on the correct layer.

103
00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:31.740
Which I;m not, I need to be on my
cookie's layer because that's where this

104
00:05:31.740 --> 00:05:33.230
little flower cookie exist.

105
00:05:33.230 --> 00:05:35.595
It doesn't exist on the Kara copy layer.

106
00:05:35.595 --> 00:05:39.370
>> So there was really nothing at that
spot where you had selected on that Kara

107
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:39.990
copy layer.

108
00:05:39.990 --> 00:05:43.141
Even though it looks like it,
but there just stacked up there.

109
00:05:43.141 --> 00:05:44.050
>> Yeah, exactly.

110
00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:47.270
So, I'm going to create a copy,
paste a copy, and

111
00:05:47.270 --> 00:05:49.406
now I have a copy of this flower cookie.

112
00:05:49.406 --> 00:05:55.530
I'm going to rename it, and
I'm going to move it over here.

113
00:05:55.530 --> 00:05:56.960
I'm going to make it smaller, so

114
00:05:56.960 --> 00:06:00.055
that way it just looks like I
made more cookies than I did.

115
00:06:00.055 --> 00:06:01.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> Go ahead and hit Enter.

116
00:06:01.490 --> 00:06:02.730
All right, so

117
00:06:02.730 --> 00:06:06.610
now we've gone over the Rectangular
Marquee tool, the Elliptical Marquee tool.

118
00:06:06.610 --> 00:06:10.460
Time to see what other types
of Marquee tools we have.

119
00:06:10.460 --> 00:06:12.960
The next one is a single row marquee tool.

120
00:06:12.960 --> 00:06:16.860
So that's if you wanted to select
a single row of your document,

121
00:06:16.860 --> 00:06:19.430
it's probably not something
that you're going to use very

122
00:06:19.430 --> 00:06:22.880
often unless you're
working on a pixel level.

123
00:06:22.880 --> 00:06:24.320
So again you might not use it,

124
00:06:24.320 --> 00:06:27.610
your rectangular and
ellipse are much more common.

125
00:06:29.000 --> 00:06:31.566
So when you say single row,
you mean single row of pixels?

126
00:06:31.566 --> 00:06:33.153
>> Mm-hm.

127
00:06:33.153 --> 00:06:35.009
>> Wow, okay.

128
00:06:35.009 --> 00:06:40.020
>> Okay, so now let's go ahead onto
our next type of selection tool.

129
00:06:40.020 --> 00:06:41.660
They're called Lasso tools.

130
00:06:41.660 --> 00:06:45.080
So Lassos are really fun
Looks like cowboy's lasso,

131
00:06:45.080 --> 00:06:46.300
that's what your gonna be doing.

132
00:06:46.300 --> 00:06:46.920
>> Woo hoo.

133
00:06:46.920 --> 00:06:49.710
>> So I'm gonna warn you now that
lassoes take a little bit of

134
00:06:49.710 --> 00:06:51.120
practice to get good at.

135
00:06:51.120 --> 00:06:55.300
So don't fret, just keep practicing, it's
something that you'll refine over time.

136
00:06:56.660 --> 00:06:58.460
So we're going to select the lasso tool.

137
00:06:58.460 --> 00:07:02.040
It's over here on the left and
it looks like a little cowboy lasso.

138
00:07:02.040 --> 00:07:04.210
The short cut is an L.

139
00:07:04.210 --> 00:07:05.100
Okay?
So if you want

140
00:07:05.100 --> 00:07:07.160
to get good at shortcuts
just remember this is the l.

141
00:07:08.180 --> 00:07:12.610
So what this allows you to do is to
be more precise with your selections.

142
00:07:12.610 --> 00:07:15.750
So instead of just getting
a big box full of content or

143
00:07:15.750 --> 00:07:19.600
a circle full of content,
now we can be more specific.

144
00:07:19.600 --> 00:07:22.840
So let's say that I wanted
to just get this k.

145
00:07:22.840 --> 00:07:27.181
What I would do is I would click,
hold and drag around it,

146
00:07:27.181 --> 00:07:29.447
almost like I'm tracing it.

147
00:07:31.835 --> 00:07:33.450
And you just keep going.

148
00:07:33.450 --> 00:07:34.970
Don't worry, it does take some time,

149
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:37.520
especially if you're doing
really minute details.

150
00:07:37.520 --> 00:07:41.318
So don't get frustrated, the Lasso
tools can sometimes be frustrating.

151
00:07:41.318 --> 00:07:44.920
[LAUGH] But I went all the way
around the K and you see when I

152
00:07:44.920 --> 00:07:48.620
connected back to my original point it
turned into our dotted little lines.

153
00:07:48.620 --> 00:07:50.585
These are selection lines.

154
00:07:50.585 --> 00:07:53.888
So I'm going to make sure
I'm on my cookies layer and

155
00:07:53.888 --> 00:07:57.805
I'll just show you what it would
look like if I were to move it.

156
00:07:57.805 --> 00:08:01.625
So now I just have my K selected.

157
00:08:01.625 --> 00:08:02.888
>> But a lot more specific,

158
00:08:02.888 --> 00:08:07.270
like when we drew the box, we kinda got
some pieces of the other cookies in there.

159
00:08:07.270 --> 00:08:10.600
This allows you to really get in and
focus that selection.

160
