00:19:05.510 --> 00:19:09.270
And then this one is probably gonna
be a little bit more challenging.

393
00:19:09.270 --> 00:19:11.630
So we're gonna have to take
this a few clicks at a time.

394
00:19:11.630 --> 00:19:15.210
So you can either single-click or
you can click, hold, and drag as well.

395
00:19:17.140 --> 00:19:21.100
So whatever you prefer,
it's completely up to you.

396
00:19:21.100 --> 00:19:22.530
Okay, so it didn't get all of my mushroom.

397
00:19:22.530 --> 00:19:25.770
I'm gonna zoom in so you can really
see where it didn't get the mushroom.

398
00:19:25.770 --> 00:19:30.870
And it's right here so I need to add
to the selection, but I added too much.

399
00:19:30.870 --> 00:19:35.040
Reason why is cuz my little
radius is too large,

400
00:19:35.040 --> 00:19:36.990
so the brush type part is too large.

401
00:19:36.990 --> 00:19:38.910
So let's make it smaller.

402
00:19:38.910 --> 00:19:43.253
And let's click our Alt or Option and
really kinda smooth it out around here.

403
00:19:50.614 --> 00:19:52.230
Okay, so I'm gonna do the same thing.

404
00:19:52.230 --> 00:19:54.060
Let's copy, paste these.

405
00:19:54.060 --> 00:19:54.977
Now we have mushrooms.

406
00:19:56.869 --> 00:20:00.020
And we don't actually need layer zero
anymore, so I'm just gonna hide it.

407
00:20:00.020 --> 00:20:04.300
Now we have ingredients that are cut out,
they're on a transparent background.

408
00:20:04.300 --> 00:20:08.550
So if we were to save this as a .PNG
it would have a transparent background.

409
00:20:08.550 --> 00:20:11.520
Which means you wouldn't have to cut out
the white, you've already done that step.

410
00:20:11.520 --> 00:20:12.020
>> Very nice.

411
00:20:13.350 --> 00:20:13.960
>> Yeah.

412
00:20:13.960 --> 00:20:18.240
So another form of selections
is using the Pen tool.

413
00:20:18.240 --> 00:20:20.990
So you might be familiar with
the Pen tool if you've ever used

414
00:20:20.990 --> 00:20:24.310
Illustrator before cuz
it's a pen based program.

415
00:20:24.310 --> 00:20:27.130
So what we're gonna do we're gonna
select the Pen tool over on the left.

416
00:20:28.460 --> 00:20:32.520
And I'm just going to kind
of single click around here

417
00:20:33.550 --> 00:20:37.310
single click, and single click.

418
00:20:37.310 --> 00:20:39.720
Now with the Pen tool, if you click and

419
00:20:39.720 --> 00:20:44.260
hold down on one of your points, you'll
have these little barbells that come up.

420
00:20:44.260 --> 00:20:46.680
These barbells allow you
to create curvature.

421
00:20:47.850 --> 00:20:50.750
So I'm gonna zoom in a little bit so
you can see that.

422
00:20:50.750 --> 00:20:53.330
So there,
now you have a curvature of your line.

423
00:20:53.330 --> 00:20:55.810
I'm going to keep selecting here.

424
00:20:55.810 --> 00:20:58.830
This part is pretty straight so
it's not too, too bad.

425
00:21:00.070 --> 00:21:02.190
You can just keep going around.

426
00:21:02.190 --> 00:21:05.220
Now again,
the Pen tool's what you'd wanna do for

427
00:21:05.220 --> 00:21:09.980
more specific,
really close type selections.

428
00:21:09.980 --> 00:21:11.590
>> It's just a little tedious.

429
00:21:11.590 --> 00:21:14.250
>> It is a little tedious,
not the preferred method but

430
00:21:14.250 --> 00:21:16.190
it is another way to select.

431
00:21:16.190 --> 00:21:19.110
It's something that you might use
if you are doing really close,

432
00:21:19.110 --> 00:21:20.800
refined selections.

433
00:21:20.800 --> 00:21:24.972
So I'm just going to quickly hurry
this guy up, and kinda show you.

434
00:21:24.972 --> 00:21:26.900
I'm not gonna make it too exact,
so that way.

435
00:21:26.900 --> 00:21:29.430
So we're not using this
part of the pepper.

436
00:21:30.680 --> 00:21:33.503
>> So you see where a little bit of
practice to kinda guide you, and

437
00:21:33.503 --> 00:21:36.480
like you now exactly where you wanna
click, and which one you want to curve, so

438
00:21:36.480 --> 00:21:37.850
that's just gonna take a little practice.

439
00:21:37.850 --> 00:21:39.030
>> It does take some practice, and

440
00:21:39.030 --> 00:21:41.730
you'll be better at it if you
have used Illustrator before.

441
00:21:41.730 --> 00:21:47.039
There are benefits to learning
other Adobe programs.

442
00:21:48.590 --> 00:21:50.040
Now you'll notice we
have this anchor point,

443
00:21:50.040 --> 00:21:53.500
this little circle again, that's telling
us that we can close our selection.

444
00:21:53.500 --> 00:21:56.970
So if you single-click,
it doesn't have those dotted lines.

445
00:21:56.970 --> 00:21:59.020
We need to give it those dotted lines.

446
00:21:59.020 --> 00:22:02.930
So you'll notice up at the top
you'll have a word that says Make.

447
00:22:02.930 --> 00:22:05.370
Right next to Make you'll have
that option to make a selection.

448
00:22:06.570 --> 00:22:08.370
So if you click on Selection.

449
00:22:08.370 --> 00:22:12.370
You can either create a new selection,
add to an existing selection, subtract.

450
00:22:12.370 --> 00:22:16.140
It's those same kind of options that
you had with your Marquee tools.

451
00:22:16.140 --> 00:22:18.290
I'm going to create a new selection.

452
00:22:18.290 --> 00:22:19.870
And I'm going to go ahead and click OK.

453
00:22:19.870 --> 00:22:22.970
And now we have our dotted lines,
just like we did with everything else.

454
00:22:22.970 --> 00:22:24.620
>> Very good.

455
00:22:25.878 --> 00:22:29.440
All right Kara,
again a great look at Photoshop and

456
00:22:29.440 --> 00:22:33.130
all the different selection tools that
we have available within Photoshop.

457
00:22:33.130 --> 00:22:34.750
Important that we understand them.

458
00:22:34.750 --> 00:22:37.640
Obviously selecting is going to be
an important part of working with

459
00:22:37.640 --> 00:22:38.670
our document.

460
00:22:38.670 --> 00:22:42.240
Thanks for that great look, I think we
have a good idea now about how can go

461
00:22:42.240 --> 00:22:45.890
about using the different tools to make
our selections, so thank you for that.

462
00:22:45.890 --> 00:22:47.630
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

463
00:22:47.630 --> 00:22:50.010
Signing of for ITProTV, I'm Mike Roderick.

464
00:22:50.010 --> 00:22:50.600
>> And I'm Kara Page.

465
00:22:50.600 --> 00:22:52.917
>> And we'll see you next time.

466
00:22:52.917 --> 00:23:00.096
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Try It Out! Layers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.321 --> 00:00:10.321
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.661 --> 00:00:15.580
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPROTV.

3
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:22.020
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're going over Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:23.260
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:23.260 --> 00:00:26.580
we're going to be doing one
of our try it out exercises.

6
00:00:26.580 --> 00:00:29.130
So here to walk us through is Ms.
Kara Page.

7
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:30.020
How's it going, Kara?

8
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:30.850
>> I'm great, how are you?

9
00:00:30.850 --> 00:00:31.540
>> Good, thanks.

10
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:33.240
So what have you got lined up for
us today?

11
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:35.240
>> Today we're going to be
making a burger, actually.

12
00:00:35.240 --> 00:00:36.959
So I hope that you've eaten dinner.

13
00:00:36.959 --> 00:00:40.260
[LAUGH] Or lunch, depending on
what time of day it is for you.

14
00:00:40.260 --> 00:00:42.070
So let's go ahead and get started.

15
00:00:42.070 --> 00:00:44.710
The first thing that you
are going to do on your end,

16
00:00:44.710 --> 00:00:48.050
is locate these try it out
layers exercise files.

17
00:00:48.050 --> 00:00:52.170
Okay, they're all image files for
you they're the same as what I'm gonna

18
00:00:52.170 --> 00:00:55.430
be doing so we're going to be walking
step by step through them together.

19
00:00:55.430 --> 00:00:57.230
>> Fantastic.
>> Okay so let's go ahead and

20
00:00:57.230 --> 00:00:58.010
open Photoshop.

21
00:00:59.130 --> 00:01:01.500
So I went ahead and
opened this burger picture,

22
00:01:01.500 --> 00:01:04.420
but just in case you forget how
to open I'm gonna show you.

23
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:07.884
So we're gonna go to this open button.

24
00:01:07.884 --> 00:01:10.282
And here we have burger.jpg, okay?

25
00:01:10.282 --> 00:01:15.630
You can go ahead and click, Open, and
there we are in the same place together.

26
00:01:15.630 --> 00:01:17.920
You'll notice that my layers
panel looks different now.

27
00:01:17.920 --> 00:01:19.600
It's not on the bottom right corner.

28
00:01:19.600 --> 00:01:23.750
The reason why I did that is because
I added it from my Windows menu.

29
00:01:23.750 --> 00:01:27.330
I added the panel and
I dragged it up to the very top so

30
00:01:27.330 --> 00:01:30.790
that why I have a fly out menu
when I click on it instead.

31
00:01:30.790 --> 00:01:32.840
It's completely up to you if you
like looking at it this way.

32
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:35.560
It's sometimes easier if
you have a lot of layers so

33
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:37.890
that way you don't have to
keep scrolling up and down.

34
00:01:37.890 --> 00:01:39.240
>> Very good.

35
00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:40.620
>> Okay, so we have our burger.

36
00:01:40.620 --> 00:01:43.310
That's the first thing
we're starting out with.

37
00:01:43.310 --> 00:01:47.800
And hopefully you remember how to unlock
our burger, so we can actually edit it.

38
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:49.820
If you don't, we're gonna do it right now.

39
00:01:49.820 --> 00:01:52.470
So let's go ahead and
click that unlock button.

40
00:01:53.470 --> 00:01:56.060
And I'm going to rename my layer,
by double clicking.

41
00:01:56.060 --> 00:01:58.830
And I'm going to name this burger.

42
00:01:58.830 --> 00:02:01.000
So we have one layer, we're good to go.

43
00:02:01.000 --> 00:02:03.540
We're ready to start adding ingredients.

44
00:02:03.540 --> 00:02:04.120
>> I like it.

45
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:06.750
That's a good looking burger, but
I think we can do better, right?

46
00:02:06.750 --> 00:02:07.460
>> I think we can.
Yes.

47
00:02:07.460 --> 00:02:08.600
>> All right.

48
00:02:08.600 --> 00:02:11.280
All right, so what we're gonna do
is we're gonna click on our new

49
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:15.460
layer icon button on the bottom,
again it's that sticky not looking thing.

50
00:02:15.460 --> 00:02:16.900
And now we have layer one.

51
00:02:16.900 --> 00:02:19.760
We are going to rename this layer one,
ketchup.

52
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:24.520
Okay, so there we are,
ketchup, good to go.

53
00:02:24.520 --> 00:02:28.640
It's empty again, it's the little
checkerboard, it means it's transparent.

54
00:02:28.640 --> 00:02:30.330
So now we're going to select our brush.

55
00:02:30.330 --> 00:02:32.990
So you can select your brush
over here on the left.

56
00:02:32.990 --> 00:02:36.080
And I'm, I've got mine at 14,

57
00:02:36.080 --> 00:02:39.270
you can have it at whatever size you want,
again it doesn't matter.

58
00:02:39.270 --> 00:02:41.502
It also depends on if you
like a lot of ketchup or not.

59
00:02:41.502 --> 00:02:42.370
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I was gonna say,

60
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:43.862
how much ketchup do you really want?

61
00:02:43.862 --> 00:02:44.680
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

62
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:49.180
So I'm going to change my color down
here on this bottom set foreground.

63
00:02:49.180 --> 00:02:52.460
I'm going to change it
to a nice ketchup red.

64
00:02:52.460 --> 00:02:53.319
>> I like it.

65
00:02:53.319 --> 00:02:54.450
>> Okay.

66
00:02:54.450 --> 00:02:57.600
So now that we are in our layer,
make sure that it does say ketchup.

67
00:02:57.600 --> 00:02:58.770
That's one highlighted.

68
00:02:58.770 --> 00:03:04.350
I'm gonna go ahead and just kind of
draw some ketchup on this burger.

69
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:08.260
So I have one of those little single

70
00:03:08.260 --> 00:03:11.015
serve packets that's really
hard to get the ketchup out of.

71
00:03:11.015 --> 00:03:11.550
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

72
00:03:11.550 --> 00:03:14.620
if you want your ketchup to
be a larger stream you just

73
00:03:14.620 --> 00:03:17.290
change the size of your brush, okay?

74
00:03:17.290 --> 00:03:20.250
So now we have ketchup,
if we wanted to remove the ketchup,

75
00:03:20.250 --> 00:03:24.300
maybe we have a picky eater,
we can click on this Visibility icon.

76
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:26.910
And then we're back to our burger.

77
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:27.410
>> Very good.

78
00:03:28.430 --> 00:03:30.980
>> Okay, let's go ahead and
add another condiment.

79
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:32.810
So I'm going to click on
the Create New Layer.

80
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:36.010
And I'm going to name this one mustard.

81
00:03:37.810 --> 00:03:39.990
>> Can't have a good
burger without mustard.

82
00:03:39.990 --> 00:03:42.840
Right now, mustard isn't my personal
favorite, it's kinda funny that I

83
00:03:42.840 --> 00:03:46.790
choose a burger, because I only
like burger and cheese, that's it.

84
00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:47.460
>> Wow, okay.

85
00:03:47.460 --> 00:03:50.710
>> So I'm going out of my comfort zone
by making you a gourmet burger today.

86
00:03:50.710 --> 00:03:52.460
>> We appreciate that.

87
00:03:52.460 --> 00:03:53.130
>> all right,

88
00:03:53.130 --> 00:03:57.240
let's go to our brush again and I'm gonna
pretend that we really like mustard.

89
00:03:57.240 --> 00:04:01.230
So I'm going to make my brush
a little bit larger than it was.

90
00:04:01.230 --> 00:04:04.390
And I need to pick a nice
mustard yellow from over here.

91
00:04:04.390 --> 00:04:06.920
If picking a color makes you
a little bit nervous, don't worry,

92
00:04:06.920 --> 00:04:08.900
we are going to be going
over that in the future.

93
00:04:08.900 --> 00:04:11.470
Okay, so

94
00:04:11.470 --> 00:04:14.710
I'm gonna make sure I'm on my mustard
layer, cuz if I'm not, watch what happens.

95
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:18.820
I'm gonna pretend that we're on ketchup,
I'm going to draw on ketchup.

96
00:04:18.820 --> 00:04:20.810
And now it's the same layer.

97
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:24.820
So if I hit my Visibility icon,
I lose my mustard as well.

98
00:04:24.820 --> 00:04:25.710
So we don't want that.

99
00:04:25.710 --> 00:04:29.800
I'm going to undo what I just
did by hitting Ctrl+Z or Cmd+Z.

100
00:04:29.800 --> 00:04:32.560
>> So very important to make sure
you know what layer you're on,

101
00:04:32.560 --> 00:04:34.220
before you start making changes.

102
00:04:34.220 --> 00:04:34.720
>> Exactly.
>> Okay.

103
00:04:36.010 --> 00:04:37.880
Let's go ahead and click on mustard so
we know where we are.

104
00:04:38.970 --> 00:04:42.880
And I'm just gonna do a nice little
zig zag of mustard on there.

105
00:04:42.880 --> 00:04:43.630
>> Beautiful.

106
00:04:43.630 --> 00:04:44.440
>> Okay?

107
00:04:44.440 --> 00:04:48.840
Let's say I accidentally went beyond, so
I missed the burger, now it doesn't look

108
00:04:48.840 --> 00:04:53.090
like a real burger anymore, we have
an issue, I need to erase that mustard.

109
00:04:53.090 --> 00:04:55.000
So you're gonna select the Eraser tool.

110
00:04:55.000 --> 00:04:56.750
Over here on the left.

111
00:04:56.750 --> 00:04:58.120
And I'm just going to erase this.

112
00:04:58.120 --> 00:05:00.920
Now you'll notice it's
not erasing the burger.

113
00:05:00.920 --> 00:05:03.500
The reason why is because
the burger is on a different layer.

114
00:05:04.740 --> 00:05:07.570
So again, this is where layers become
really important in Photoshop.

115
00:05:07.570 --> 00:05:08.290
>> Very good.

116
00:05:08.290 --> 00:05:10.550
>> So now we have some ketchup,
we have some mustard.

117
00:05:10.550 --> 00:05:13.020
It's time to add some other ingredients.

118
00:05:13.020 --> 00:05:16.300
So find your layers, or your pictures for

119
00:05:16.300 --> 00:05:20.050
these layers, and I'm going to go
ahead and add our first ingredients.

120
00:05:20.050 --> 00:05:23.090
So I'm gonna go to File and
Place Embedded, remember,

121
00:05:23.090 --> 00:05:25.730
that's something you've learned before.

122
00:05:25.730 --> 00:05:29.420
And I am going to do our onion next,
so it's onion.png.

123
00:05:29.420 --> 00:05:33.890
The reason why these are PNG files,
is because they are transparent.

124
00:05:33.890 --> 00:05:37.580
So you don't have to cut anything out,
that's going to be our next lesson.

125
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:38.760
Let's go ahead and hit Place.

126
00:05:40.870 --> 00:05:42.620
And we have our onion.

127
00:05:42.620 --> 00:05:46.230
Now you'll see, this onion is huge, it's
bigger than our little mini slider, so

128
00:05:46.230 --> 00:05:48.710
we need to adjust the size of our onion.

129
00:05:48.710 --> 00:05:52.570
You have learned how to adjust
the size before, but as a refresher,

130
00:05:52.570 --> 00:05:57.240
you're going to click on the corner,
hold down shift and drag.

131
00:05:57.240 --> 00:05:59.770
That will maintain
the proportions properly.

132
00:06:00.790 --> 00:06:03.170
And I'm gonna move this onion over.

133
00:06:03.170 --> 00:06:05.380
And I'm gonna hit enter
to commit my change.

134
00:06:05.380 --> 00:06:06.980
>> Much better.

135
00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:08.100
>> So now I have one onion,

136
00:06:08.100 --> 00:06:10.830
which kind of looks silly to only
have one onion on your burger.

137
00:06:10.830 --> 00:06:12.480
So we need to duplicate this layer.

138
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:16.010
So we can do it a number of
different ways, like I said.

139
00:06:16.010 --> 00:06:19.310
But let's go ahead and
do it the first way that I showed you,

140
00:06:19.310 --> 00:06:22.210
which is by right clicking and
duplicating layer.

141
00:06:22.210 --> 00:06:26.000
And I'm going to name this one onion 2.

142
00:06:26.000 --> 00:06:29.230
So now we have two onion layers.

143
00:06:29.230 --> 00:06:32.140
But again, you can't tell that the second
onion's there because it layers on top

144
00:06:32.140 --> 00:06:33.250
of the first one.

145
00:06:33.250 --> 00:06:38.760
So let's get our move tool and
let's move this onion over.

146
00:06:38.760 --> 00:06:41.640
And I don't want my onion to look

147
00:06:41.640 --> 00:06:44.540
exactly the same way because we
just threw the onions on there.

148
00:06:44.540 --> 00:06:46.580
This isn't very accurate
if you have it like this.

149
00:06:46.580 --> 00:06:50.550
So I'm going to just rotate,
which we have learned before.

150
00:06:50.550 --> 00:06:53.160
So I'm just gonna rotate you around.

151
00:06:53.160 --> 00:06:54.030
And go ahead and hit Enter.

152
00:06:55.300 --> 00:06:56.160
>> Nice.

153
00:06:56.160 --> 00:07:00.890
>> So let's say that I wanted
to copy both of these layers.

154
00:07:00.890 --> 00:07:05.850
What you could do, is you could select
both layers by clicking on Shift and

155
00:07:05.850 --> 00:07:06.430
selecting both.

156
00:07:07.480 --> 00:07:10.390
And you can right click and
duplicate layers.

157
00:07:10.390 --> 00:07:12.360
So now you have two to duplicate.

158
00:07:13.430 --> 00:07:14.870
Okay.

159
00:07:14.870 --> 00:07:17.425
And now you'll see I have
all these copies of onions.

160
00:07:17.425 --> 00:07:18.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I have.

161
00:07:19.760 --> 00:07:21.120
Here we go.
And again,

162
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:23.160
I can't see my other two onions.

163
00:07:23.160 --> 00:07:26.020
So let's go ahead and
click on onion two copy.

164
00:07:26.020 --> 00:07:29.020
I'm going to move him off, and

165
00:07:29.020 --> 00:07:31.500
I'm going to click on my other
onion copy and move him.

166
00:07:32.780 --> 00:07:34.810
So let's say that I wanted
to move my first onion.

167
00:07:34.810 --> 00:07:37.740
I don't like the placement of it and
I go to move it.

168
00:07:37.740 --> 00:07:38.970
So I go to click on it.

169
00:07:38.970 --> 00:07:40.970
I click on it and
it's only moving my other onion.

170
00:07:40.970 --> 00:07:45.740
The reason why, is because you have to be
on the specific layer in order to move it.

171
00:07:45.740 --> 00:07:50.390
Okay so I'm going to select on my
original onion layer and there you go.

172
00:07:50.390 --> 00:07:51.790
Now we can move it.

173
00:07:51.790 --> 00:07:54.460
Now if you feel more
comfortable with Photoshop, and

174
00:07:54.460 --> 00:07:57.880
you wanna turn on an option called
Autoselect, you certainly can.

175
00:07:57.880 --> 00:08:02.072
It's in the top-left corner of your
Photoshop window when you have the move

176
00:08:02.072 --> 00:08:02.630
tool on.

177
00:08:02.630 --> 00:08:08.580
So I can select Autoselect, and it will
let me just click willy-nilly in here.

178
00:08:08.580 --> 00:08:11.570
And I can see your layers changing in
your panel over there as you click.

179
00:08:11.570 --> 00:08:12.720
>> Exactly, exactly.

180
00:08:12.720 --> 00:08:17.010
Now the problem with this auto select, is
if you forget to lock some of your layers,

181
00:08:17.010 --> 00:08:18.620
you may accidentally
grab the burger instead.

182
00:08:18.620 --> 00:08:22.240
And if we're dragging the burger
that's not exactly what we wanna do.

183
00:08:24.120 --> 00:08:25.120
Okay?

184
00:08:25.120 --> 00:08:28.200
So now I have all these onions,
I wanna put them in a group.

185
00:08:28.200 --> 00:08:33.460
So what we're going to do, is we're going
to create a folder at the bottom, and

186
00:08:33.460 --> 00:08:37.130
I'm going to name this guy onions,
you guessed it, right?

187
00:08:37.130 --> 00:08:42.410
Gonna drag it up to the top here, and I'm
gonna put all my onions into this folder.

188
00:08:42.410 --> 00:08:44.570
Again, you can drag them one at a time.

189
00:08:44.570 --> 00:08:50.500
Or, you can hold down shift,
select all of them and drag them up.

190
00:08:50.500 --> 00:08:53.680
Now what might happen, let's say
that you have an overlapping onion.

191
00:08:54.900 --> 00:09:01.780
So let's have, one guy.

192
00:09:03.170 --> 00:09:05.730
overlap, and
you really want this onion to overlap.

193
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:07.310
If he, for some reason,

194
00:09:07.310 --> 00:09:12.320
gets in the wrong order, he isn't
necessarily going to overlap anymore.

195
00:09:12.320 --> 00:09:14.330
So, let's see which onion that is.

196
00:09:15.950 --> 00:09:17.040
So the way that you can fix that,

197
00:09:17.040 --> 00:09:20.200
is just by reordering your
layers in your layer folder.

198
00:09:20.200 --> 00:09:21.840
So if that ever happens to you,
don't panic.

199
00:09:21.840 --> 00:09:23.280
It's just layer order
that you need to adjust.

200
00:09:23.280 --> 00:09:26.030
>> That's back to the stacking order we
talked about in the previous episode.

201
00:09:26.030 --> 00:09:27.330
>> Exactly.
>> Good.

202
00:09:27.330 --> 00:09:29.610
Okay, so let's go ahead and
add another ingredient.

203
00:09:29.610 --> 00:09:32.790
So we're gonna go to File
> Place embedded again.

204
00:09:34.340 --> 00:09:36.660
And now we're going to add some spinach.

205
00:09:36.660 --> 00:09:39.230
So again, this is a fancy gourmet burger.

206
00:09:39.230 --> 00:09:44.050
We're not using just iceberg, we're using
spinach so let's go ahead and place that.

207
00:09:44.050 --> 00:09:45.850
And again our spinach is huge so

208
00:09:45.850 --> 00:09:49.040
we need to adjust the size by
holding down shift and dragging.

209
00:09:50.650 --> 00:09:54.190
And you'll notice,
my spinach is beneath everything now.

210
00:09:54.190 --> 00:09:58.440
The reason why that happened,
is because it placed in a different order.

211
00:09:58.440 --> 00:10:00.150
So I want it to be on top of everything,

212
00:10:00.150 --> 00:10:02.800
I'm going to drag it to
the top of my layers panel.

213
00:10:03.880 --> 00:10:04.480
Okay?

214
00:10:04.480 --> 00:10:07.280
But I accidentally dragged it into
my onions, which might happen.

215
00:10:07.280 --> 00:10:11.310
So if that happens to you,
just open up your folder.

216
00:10:11.310 --> 00:10:15.640
And drag it out,
because if we kept the spinach there, and

217
00:10:15.640 --> 00:10:17.820
you went to move the onions,
you would be moving the spinach, too.

218
00:10:19.770 --> 00:10:21.120
Okay?
So, here we have our spinach.

219
00:10:21.120 --> 00:10:24.280
And I'm going to add more spinach,
because we just really like spinach.

220
00:10:24.280 --> 00:10:26.970
So, we're going to try
a different way of duplicating.

221
00:10:26.970 --> 00:10:34.280
We're going to click hold and
drag our layer The New Layer option.

222
00:10:34.280 --> 00:10:36.290
And now we have a finished copy.

223
00:10:36.290 --> 00:10:39.000
Now if you're not careful with the way
that you move your layers, you might

224
00:10:39.000 --> 00:10:42.990
notice that mine are now at the bottom,
so just be careful with when you let go.

225
00:10:44.110 --> 00:10:46.930
And we're going to drag these guys
all the way up to the top again.

226
00:10:46.930 --> 00:10:51.850
So I'm gonna click on my spinach copy,
I'm gonna turn off auto select,

227
00:10:51.850 --> 00:10:54.410
so that way we can practice without it.

228
00:10:54.410 --> 00:11:00.150
And I'm going to go ahead and
resize these a bit and turn them.

229
00:11:01.870 --> 00:11:05.070
Okay, so now we have two spinach copies.

230
00:11:05.070 --> 00:11:07.190
Now you'll notice if you
look at the thumbnail for

231
00:11:07.190 --> 00:11:11.250
these layers, there's this little
Smart Object icon in the corner.

232
00:11:11.250 --> 00:11:13.940
It kind of looks like overlapping boxes.

233
00:11:13.940 --> 00:11:16.720
The reason why that happened is because

234
00:11:16.720 --> 00:11:19.700
these were image files
that we placed in here.

235
00:11:19.700 --> 00:11:22.610
So in order to be edited
fully in Photoshop,

236
00:11:22.610 --> 00:11:25.440
you have to do something
called rastarizing them.

237
00:11:25.440 --> 00:11:29.430
Rastarizing a file is basically
turning it into editable pixels.

238
00:11:29.430 --> 00:11:31.250
So let me demonstrate that for you.

239
00:11:31.250 --> 00:11:36.720
Let's say that I wanted to I don't know,
let's say we are going to erase this.

240
00:11:37.990 --> 00:11:40.190
You will notice that when I
hover over with the eraser,

241
00:11:40.190 --> 00:11:41.970
we have this little no symbol.

242
00:11:41.970 --> 00:11:44.650
Saying sorry you can't do that.

243
00:11:44.650 --> 00:11:48.520
If you click, it will say smart object
must be rasterized before proceeding.

244
00:11:49.620 --> 00:11:52.140
Okay, so
if you don't nothing is going to happen.

245
00:11:52.140 --> 00:11:56.190
The way that you rasterized something
is you right click on the layer name.

246
00:11:57.660 --> 00:12:00.430
And then you'll notice about
halfway down your layers panel,

247
00:12:00.430 --> 00:12:02.130
it's something called Rasterize Layer.

248
00:12:03.400 --> 00:12:06.530
You'll notice that our little
smart object icon disappeared, so

249
00:12:06.530 --> 00:12:11.710
now I can actually erase this
one piece of lettuce, if I want.

250
00:12:14.440 --> 00:12:18.367
Now the reason why I didn't
erase that top piece of spinach,

251
00:12:18.367 --> 00:12:21.530
is because it's above
the other spinach layer.

252
00:12:21.530 --> 00:12:23.900
Even though it is a same type of object,

253
00:12:23.900 --> 00:12:26.970
they are on different layers so
you only edit the object

254
00:12:26.970 --> 00:12:29.840
when it is drawn as a [INAUDIBLE]
>> You have to rasterize both of those

255
00:12:29.840 --> 00:12:30.980
layers individually.

256
00:12:30.980 --> 00:12:34.940
>> Correct and
be on the proper layer as well, okay?

257
00:12:34.940 --> 00:12:37.220
So that's the concept of rasterization.

258
00:12:37.220 --> 00:12:39.490
It's something you might
come into contact with,

259
00:12:39.490 --> 00:12:41.810
especially the more you go to edit things.

260
00:12:41.810 --> 00:12:44.480
So if you're trying to cut
things out of backgrounds, or

261
00:12:44.480 --> 00:12:49.790
add layer style effects to them,
you might need to rasterize things first.

262
00:12:49.790 --> 00:12:50.830
So now we have our spinach.

263
00:12:50.830 --> 00:12:54.210
Let's go ahead and add our last
ingredient, which is tomatoes.

264
00:12:54.210 --> 00:12:57.375
We're gonna do an open face sandwich,
so, really gourmet here.

265
00:12:57.375 --> 00:12:58.153
>> Mm-hm.
>> [LAUGH].

266
00:12:58.153 --> 00:12:59.040
>> [LAUGH].
>> All right.

267
00:12:59.040 --> 00:13:01.340
Let's go ahead and place embedded.

268
00:13:01.340 --> 00:13:03.500
And let's find our tomatoes and place.

269
00:13:03.500 --> 00:13:08.140
So again, let's resize these tomatoes,
because they're big for

270
00:13:08.140 --> 00:13:08.920
our little mini burger.

271
00:13:08.920 --> 00:13:12.660
And I'm gonna place
them right on top here.

272
00:13:12.660 --> 00:13:13.160
>> Hm.

273
00:13:14.520 --> 00:13:15.560
>> Okay.

274
00:13:15.560 --> 00:13:21.270
So let's say that we wanted
to merge all these layers.

275
00:13:21.270 --> 00:13:24.350
Again, you only merge if you
want to collapse everything,

276
00:13:24.350 --> 00:13:26.450
so that means that you
can't edit them anymore.

277
00:13:26.450 --> 00:13:28.820
>> So
once we're done we've gotta finalize, and

278
00:13:28.820 --> 00:13:32.100
we're getting ready to ship it off or
use it wherever.

279
00:13:32.100 --> 00:13:33.250
This might be our last step.

280
00:13:33.250 --> 00:13:37.260
Yes, so before we do that,
let's do one more type of duplication,

281
00:13:37.260 --> 00:13:39.640
just to practice, and
it's my favorite version.

282
00:13:39.640 --> 00:13:41.660
We're going to Alt-drag.

283
00:13:41.660 --> 00:13:45.800
So let's select our layer, and
I'm going to Alt and drag above.

284
00:13:46.810 --> 00:13:50.120
Now, the way that I Alt-dragged here is,
I actually selected the layer name.

285
00:13:50.120 --> 00:13:53.260
You can either select the layer name and
Alt and drag up, or

286
00:13:53.260 --> 00:13:56.540
you can select the actual
image part over in your.

287
00:13:56.540 --> 00:13:57.530
>> Hm.
>> In your image.

288
00:13:57.530 --> 00:13:59.880
So there we have two copies of the tomato.

289
00:13:59.880 --> 00:14:00.850
All right.

290
00:14:00.850 --> 00:14:02.650
So now let's say we
really like our burger.

291
00:14:02.650 --> 00:14:03.790
It's great.

292
00:14:03.790 --> 00:14:05.690
And we've all ready saved a version of it.

293
00:14:05.690 --> 00:14:07.660
So let's go ahead and save it now.

294
00:14:07.660 --> 00:14:09.858
I'm going to call this burger.psd.

295
00:14:09.858 --> 00:14:13.910
Again, the reason why we're calling it
a dot-psd is because we want to be able to

296
00:14:13.910 --> 00:14:16.160
edit the contents in the future.

297
00:14:16.160 --> 00:14:19.100
And it's the Photoshop document
which means it saved your layers.

298
00:14:19.100 --> 00:14:20.520
Let's go ahead and save that.

299
00:14:22.000 --> 00:14:24.880
Again you can maximize compatibility,
that's fine.

300
00:14:24.880 --> 00:14:29.710
Click okay, and
now we need to flatten our layers.

301
00:14:29.710 --> 00:14:34.370
So let's right click, and

302
00:14:34.370 --> 00:14:37.299
you'll see that you can either
merge visible which we'll do first.

303
00:14:38.500 --> 00:14:43.450
So that merges all visible layers, so
if you have anything, it will merge.

304
00:14:43.450 --> 00:14:47.470
And then I undid that, so
I can show you what it looks like.

305
00:14:47.470 --> 00:14:49.832
Now we'll go ahead and right-click again.

306
00:14:49.832 --> 00:14:51.560
And were going to flatten the image.

307
00:14:51.560 --> 00:14:54.920
So you'll notice that it's
a locked background icon.

308
00:14:54.920 --> 00:14:59.550
So it's just like when you first
put an image into Photoshop,

309
00:14:59.550 --> 00:15:02.210
so there you go, it's locked, and

310
00:15:02.210 --> 00:15:06.230
now if you want to save this, I'm gonna
go ahead and save this as a JPEG.

311
00:15:06.230 --> 00:15:10.896
So I'm gonna Save As,
change it from Photoshop in our drop

312
00:15:10.896 --> 00:15:15.483
down menu to a JPEG, and
then I'll go ahead and hit Save.

313
00:15:18.165 --> 00:15:20.010
And there we go.

314
00:15:20.010 --> 00:15:20.640
There we have it.

315
00:15:20.640 --> 00:15:24.750
That is how to make a burger in Photoshop.

316
00:15:24.750 --> 00:15:26.020
>> All right, well thanks for that, Kara.

317
00:15:26.020 --> 00:15:27.030
That was a lot of fun.

318
00:15:27.030 --> 00:15:28.250
And I'm on my way to your house.

319
00:15:28.250 --> 00:15:29.970
That looks like a really good burger.

320
00:15:29.970 --> 00:15:31.260
So we're all hungry now.

321
00:15:31.260 --> 00:15:35.470
Hopefully everybody out there was as
successful as us at creating that burger.

322
00:15:35.470 --> 00:15:39.310
Got to see all the really great techniques
that you taught us, tied together.

323
00:15:39.310 --> 00:15:41.190
So I hope you guy enjoyed that.

324
00:15:41.190 --> 00:15:44.200
Stay tuned for the next one,
signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

325
00:15:44.200 --> 00:15:44.904
>> And I'm Kara Page.

326
00:15:44.904 --> 00:15:46.146
>> And we'll see you next time.

327
00:15:46.146 --> 00:15:54.669
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Try It Out! Selections
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.620 --> 00:00:15.475
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.475 --> 00:00:21.562
I'm your host Mike Roderick, and today
we're doing our Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:21.562 --> 00:00:25.446
And it's time for another one of
those exciting try it out exercises.

5
00:00:25.446 --> 00:00:27.505
In this one we're going
to be doing selections.

6
00:00:27.505 --> 00:00:29.835
And here to help us as always is Ms.
Kara Page.

7
00:00:29.835 --> 00:00:30.885
How's it going Kara?

8
00:00:30.885 --> 00:00:34.465
>> I'm great, let's go ahead and
dive in, start making that pizza.

9
00:00:34.465 --> 00:00:35.495
>> All right.
>> So go ahead and

10
00:00:35.495 --> 00:00:37.670
locate your pizza files.

11
00:00:37.670 --> 00:00:41.110
Okay, so once you have those
selected you'll be ready to start.

12
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:43.940
I'm going to go ahead and
open the pizza files.

13
00:00:43.940 --> 00:00:44.840
Let's go to open.

14
00:00:46.650 --> 00:00:51.435
And it's actually the crust.jpg,
this is the bottom layer of our pizza.

15
00:00:51.435 --> 00:00:52.810
>> Gotta start a pizza with a good crust.

16
00:00:52.810 --> 00:00:56.640
>> Yes, so you'll notice we have a crust,
we've got cheese, we have tomato sauce,

17
00:00:56.640 --> 00:00:58.320
we don't have any toppings though.

18
00:00:58.320 --> 00:00:59.840
And we really need some toppings.

19
00:00:59.840 --> 00:01:00.350
>> Absolutely.

20
00:01:00.350 --> 00:01:01.655
>> It's kind of boring without it.

21
00:01:01.655 --> 00:01:04.245
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let's go ahead and

22
00:01:04.245 --> 00:01:08.200
we're going to go to File and I'm going
to Open first, so let's go to Open.

23
00:01:09.760 --> 00:01:12.140
And let's start with the spinach.

24
00:01:12.140 --> 00:01:14.230
So I'm going to click on spinach,
click Open.

25
00:01:14.230 --> 00:01:17.680
And we have spinach in its own file now.

26
00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:19.820
So spinach has a white background, and

27
00:01:19.820 --> 00:01:23.120
I showed you how to use the magic
wand before, so lets try that.

28
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:26.558
And this time were going to experiment
with different levels of tolerance.

29
00:01:26.558 --> 00:01:28.510
So it's single-click.

30
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:31.240
Now, the default is 32,
that's probably what yours is set at, and

31
00:01:31.240 --> 00:01:36.070
you'll notice that it does a really
nice job of selecting just the spinach,

32
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:37.040
which is great.

33
00:01:37.040 --> 00:01:41.130
But let's see what were to happen if you
had something like our mushrooms file.

34
00:01:41.130 --> 00:01:46.980
So let's change the tolerance up to
about 200, and let's see what happens.

35
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:51.000
So you'll notice it's starting
to not be quite as refined.

36
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:55.650
The reason why is because it's being
more or less specific with colors.

37
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:57.540
And let's-
>> So the bigger number,

38
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:01.890
the more forgiving it is, or the less
exact it is on picking the colors?

39
00:02:01.890 --> 00:02:03.590
>> Correct, that's how it works.

40
00:02:03.590 --> 00:02:05.900
So let's take it down to ten,
and let's see what happens.

41
00:02:05.900 --> 00:02:08.334
So I'm going to deselect your Cmd or
Ctrl+D.

42
00:02:09.740 --> 00:02:14.840
This one does a very good job
because it picks up those greens,

43
00:02:14.840 --> 00:02:15.560
it knows what's going on.

44
00:02:16.690 --> 00:02:18.240
>> So sometimes, depending on your image,

45
00:02:18.240 --> 00:02:22.810
if you've gotta select between objects
that are similar in colors, Photoshop's

46
00:02:22.810 --> 00:02:26.090
having a little bit of difficulty
differentiating between the two.

47
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:28.010
We can use that tolerance to help it out.

48
00:02:29.120 --> 00:02:31.430
>> Precisely, so I'm going to undo that.

49
00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:33.650
I'm gonna set it back to 32,
just so I don't forget,

50
00:02:33.650 --> 00:02:37.010
because we are going to be using
it again in a later point.

51
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:39.410
So now you'll notice we have
different options at the top.

52
00:02:39.410 --> 00:02:42.690
So if we take off Contiguous,
let's see what happens.

53
00:02:42.690 --> 00:02:46.510
And let's just select part of our spinach.

54
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:49.717
So you'll notice that it's selecting
similar colors throughout our different

55
00:02:49.717 --> 00:02:50.526
layers of spinach.

56
00:02:50.526 --> 00:02:51.300
>> But not just that one leaf, yeah.

57
00:02:51.300 --> 00:02:53.420
>> But just not that one leaf.

58
00:02:53.420 --> 00:02:56.000
So let's turn on Contiguous.

59
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:00.060
And now it's just selecting your one leaf.

60
00:03:00.060 --> 00:03:03.080
>> So it's looking at the color, but
now it say's it's gotta be touching.

61
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:03.580
Very good.

62
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:07.610
>> Okay, so
now that you kinda have a better feel for

63

293
00:14:54.777 --> 00:14:56.985
>> Why do you think that happened,
do you have any idea?

294
00:14:56.985 --> 00:14:58.516
>> Were we on the wrong
layer again [LAUGH].

295
00:14:58.516 --> 00:14:59.874
>> We're on the wrong layer again.

296
00:14:59.874 --> 00:15:01.645
So, again, make sure that
you're on the correct layer.

297
00:15:01.645 --> 00:15:03.724
So Background, Copy.

298
00:15:03.724 --> 00:15:05.590
We're gonna paste it, and there we go.

299
00:15:05.590 --> 00:15:07.640
Now we have our pepperoni.

300
00:15:07.640 --> 00:15:13.860
So we can drag him over now
to the crust and let him go.

301
00:15:13.860 --> 00:15:16.510
Now, you'll notice we have
some white around him.

302
00:15:16.510 --> 00:15:20.680
So we can use several different tools
to really refine that selection.

303
00:15:20.680 --> 00:15:24.520
We can use our magic eraser tool,
we can use our quick selection tool.

304
00:15:24.520 --> 00:15:27.450
So let's just go ahead and
try the Quick Selection.

305
00:15:27.450 --> 00:15:29.210
Again, it's hidden
underneath your magic wand.

306
00:15:30.440 --> 00:15:32.510
Quick Selection,
make sure you're on your pepperoni layer.

307
00:15:32.510 --> 00:15:38.180
And that did a pretty good job
of just selecting the pepperoni.

308
00:15:38.180 --> 00:15:40.894
Now, watch what happens if I hit Delete,
though.

309
00:15:40.894 --> 00:15:42.190
>> Oops.

310
00:15:42.190 --> 00:15:44.000
>> I just got rid of my pepperoni.

311
00:15:44.000 --> 00:15:45.290
>> And left the white you didn't want.

312
00:15:45.290 --> 00:15:47.615
>> Exactly, that's not what I want, so

313
00:15:47.615 --> 00:15:50.895
what we need to do is we need
to inverse our selection.

314
00:15:50.895 --> 00:15:53.350
So I've mentioned that before,
but let me show you in practice.

315
00:15:53.350 --> 00:15:57.863
So let's undo what we just did,
so I just CTRL+Z, or CMD+ Z.

316
00:15:57.863 --> 00:16:02.390
We're gonna go up to Select,
and we're going to do Inverse.

317
00:16:02.390 --> 00:16:05.020
Now, you'll notice our
running ant selections

318
00:16:05.020 --> 00:16:07.330
are around the entire document now.

319
00:16:07.330 --> 00:16:10.750
So we have them from edge to edge and
it's on the edge of the pepperoni.

320
00:16:10.750 --> 00:16:14.350
If I were to click Delete now,
now our white's gone.

321
00:16:15.778 --> 00:16:20.860
And let's deselect, and you can make as
many of these pepperonis as you want.

322
00:16:20.860 --> 00:16:22.260
Again, it's completely up to you.

323
00:16:22.260 --> 00:16:22.910
>> Extra pepperoni, please.

324
00:16:22.910 --> 00:16:24.212
>> You can put them in folders.

325
00:16:24.212 --> 00:16:26.681
>> [LAUGH]
>> You can do whatever you like with them.

326
00:16:26.681 --> 00:16:31.460
But this is essentially how to place your
toppings, duplicate them, group them,

327
00:16:31.460 --> 00:16:35.110
pretty much do all of the tools that
we've learned about so far in Photoshop.

328
00:16:35.110 --> 00:16:37.270
>> Fantastic,
I didn't know I was going to get so

329
00:16:37.270 --> 00:16:39.470
hungry when I was learning Photoshop.

330
00:16:39.470 --> 00:16:42.998
But we thank you for that Kara,
great demonstration on all those different

331
00:16:42.998 --> 00:16:46.500
selection techniques that we can
use when working in Photoshop.

332
00:16:46.500 --> 00:16:47.040
Thank you for that.

333
00:16:47.040 --> 00:16:49.030
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

334
00:16:49.030 --> 00:16:51.410
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

335
00:16:51.410 --> 00:16:52.212
>> And I'm Kara Page.

336
00:16:52.212 --> 00:16:53.373
>> And we'll see you next time.

337
00:16:53.373 --> 00:17:01.789
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Overview of Brushes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.988 --> 00:00:14.920
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at Itpro.tv.

3
00:00:14.920 --> 00:00:18.970
I'm your host Mike Roderick, and
today we're doing Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:18.970 --> 00:00:25.040
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be taking a look at brushes.

5
00:00:25.040 --> 00:00:28.750
That's not what you think, right, it's
not hair brushes, it's not paint brushes.

6
00:00:28.750 --> 00:00:32.400
Here to clear that all up for
us is Miss Kara Page, how you doing Kara?

7
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:33.060
>> I'm great.

8
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:33.930
You ready to get started?

9
00:00:33.930 --> 00:00:34.940
>> I am ready.

10
00:00:34.940 --> 00:00:39.225
>> Okay, so today you're going
to turn into a digital artist.

11
00:00:39.225 --> 00:00:40.889
So they are kind of paint brushes, but

12
00:00:40.889 --> 00:00:44.207
they are not the messy kind of paint
brushes that you are thinking of.

13
00:00:44.207 --> 00:00:45.853
>> Okay.
[LAUGH]

14
00:00:45.853 --> 00:00:47.216
>> All right so let's go ahead and

15
00:00:47.216 --> 00:00:49.375
get started by opening up
just a blank document.

16
00:00:49.375 --> 00:00:55.015
So I'm going to goto new,
hopefully your Photoshop is up and

17
00:00:55.015 --> 00:00:58.620
going, I'm just gonna
goto new six by four.

18
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:01.710
Yeah, you can change that to six by four,
you can really use whatever document size

19
00:01:01.710 --> 00:01:05.540
you want, cuz we're just demonstrating
what a brush does in Photoshop.

20
00:01:05.540 --> 00:01:06.840
Gonna go ahead and hit OK.

21
00:01:08.340 --> 00:01:11.460
Okay, now we have our blank canvas.

22
00:01:11.460 --> 00:01:17.671
Let me go ahead and
kind of get rid of this timeline.

23
00:01:19.377 --> 00:01:20.170
Give us a little more
real estate [INAUDIBLE]

24
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:21.870
>> Yes, there we go.

25
00:01:21.870 --> 00:01:24.060
So the timeline is a bit
of a sneak peek and

26
00:01:24.060 --> 00:01:26.290
just something you're going to be
learning in future animations.

27
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:29.190
So I mentioned that before that you're
gonna learn animation in Photoshop,

28
00:01:29.190 --> 00:01:31.910
so that's what that panel looks like.

29
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:32.930
We don't need it up all the time.

30
00:01:32.930 --> 00:01:36.290
All right, so
now we have our big blank canvas space.

31
00:01:36.290 --> 00:01:38.080
Let's go ahead and get started.

32
00:01:38.080 --> 00:01:39.610
So we're going to learn about brushes.

33
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:41.290
So we need to find the brush first.

34
00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:45.340
Well, let's go ahead over to our
tool panel over on the left.

35
00:01:45.340 --> 00:01:48.790
The brush looks identical
to a physical paint brush.

36
00:01:48.790 --> 00:01:50.860
If you hover over it will say brush.

37
00:01:50.860 --> 00:01:52.000
The shortcut is the letter B.

38
00:01:53.400 --> 00:01:55.450
So I'm gonna click on brush.

39
00:01:55.450 --> 00:01:59.150
Now if I were to just quickly draw across.

40
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:01.880
You'll see there I have a brush stroke.

41
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:05.170
Now, there's nothing too exciting
about this particular brush stroke.

42
00:02:05.170 --> 00:02:06.440
It's just defaulted right now.

43
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:11.760
So I'm going to undo what I just did
by doing either command z or control z.

44
00:02:11.760 --> 00:02:14.250
So there,
now we have a blank canvas again.

45
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:17.430
If you want to see brush options
what you you can do is click

46
00:02:17.430 --> 00:02:20.630
over where you see the number
with the dot above it.

47
00:02:20.630 --> 00:02:25.220
Okay, that shows you your brush tip and
it show you the size of your brush.

48
00:02:25.220 --> 00:02:27.930
So I'm going to click on that drop
down arrow right to the right.

49
00:02:29.370 --> 00:02:34.080
Okay now that this is loaded you'll
see my brush size is 14 pixels,

50
00:02:34.080 --> 00:02:35.500
my hardness is at 100.

51
00:02:35.500 --> 00:02:39.720
And then you'll see I have this little
diagram to the left right here.

52
00:02:39.720 --> 00:02:45.040
This diagram allows you to change
the roundness and diameter of your brush.

53
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:49.020
So if you are more of a professional
artist using Photoshop for

54
00:02:49.020 --> 00:02:50.160
actual paintings,

55
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:54.650
digital paintings, you're probably going
to want to ingest those sizes yourself.

56
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:57.630
If you're just you know, using
brushes here and there you're more of

57
00:02:57.630 --> 00:03:02.980
a casual user you probably won't be
adjusting the diameter too often.

58
00:03:02.980 --> 00:03:03.610
Okay.

59
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:08.690
So let's talk about size or hardness,
what these numbers even mean.

60
00:03:08.690 --> 00:03:11.510
So size, pretty easy to understand.

61
00:03:11.510 --> 00:03:13.960
Let's show you what this
14 pixel brush looks like.

62
00:03:13.960 --> 00:03:18.970
I'm just gonna draw straight across You'll
notice my line wasn't exactly straight.

63
00:03:18.970 --> 00:03:23.610
So it's very hard to draw a straight
line with a trackpad or a mouse.

64
00:03:23.610 --> 00:03:26.840
So what you can do in
Photoshop is if you click and

65
00:03:26.840 --> 00:03:31.490
hold down Shift at the same time,
it'll create a straight line, okay.

66
00:03:31.490 --> 00:03:34.410
So here I'm creating a zig-zag
pattern because it's picking up from

67
00:03:34.410 --> 00:03:37.070
where I left off on the last line.

68
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:39.290
Okay, so this is our fourteen size brush.

69
00:03:39.290 --> 00:03:43.130
I'm going to go up here and
change it to something much larger.

70
00:03:43.130 --> 00:03:46.430
Let's change it to a hundred.

71
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:49.580
So you'll notice that right now
mine says one hundred and five.

72
00:03:49.580 --> 00:03:53.660
Now if you use the slider it's harder to
get exactly the number you're looking for.

73
00:03:53.660 --> 00:03:58.620
You can always type in
that number in photo shop.

74
00:03:58.620 --> 00:03:59.880
So, I'm gonna go ahead and draw.

75
00:04:00.900 --> 00:04:04.070
Now you can directly compare
a hundred size versus 14.

76
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:06.710
There's a pretty big difference.

77
00:04:06.710 --> 00:04:09.820
Photo shop goes up to
an extremely large number amount.

78
00:04:09.820 --> 00:04:12.740
You can do thousands and
thousands of pixel size.

79
00:04:12.740 --> 00:04:14.680
So, let's show you what happens then.

80
00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:17.190
So, let's say that we do 5000 pixels.

81
00:04:17.190 --> 00:04:18.808
And we just single click.

82
00:04:18.808 --> 00:04:19.795
>> [LAUGH].

83
00:04:19.795 --> 00:04:22.860
>> It's gonna fill our entire canvas.

84
00:04:22.860 --> 00:04:24.990
Which is great if you don't
know what the paint bucket is,

85
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:26.695
but that's what the paint bucket is for.

86
00:04:26.695 --> 00:04:27.360
>> [LAUGH].
>> So

87
00:04:27.360 --> 00:04:30.770
realistically you're not gonna be
using 5,000 pixel brushes very often

88
00:04:30.770 --> 00:04:33.390
unless you're doing huge canvases or
murals,

89
00:04:33.390 --> 00:04:37.290
so I'm gonna bring this back
down to a reasonable size.

90
00:04:37.290 --> 00:04:39.130
Okay?
I'm gonna undo what we just did.

91
00:04:39.130 --> 00:04:41.450
I'm gonna undo all the way
back to a blank canvas so

92
00:04:41.450 --> 00:04:43.370
we have a starting point here again.

93
00:04:44.960 --> 00:04:46.850
Okay.
So that is size.

94
00:04:46.850 --> 00:04:48.950
Now let's talk about hardness.

95
00:04:48.950 --> 00:04:51.711
Right now it's set at a hundred hardness,

96
00:04:51.711 --> 00:04:56.097
so let's compare the two so
I'm just going to draw a straight line.

97
00:04:56.097 --> 00:04:56.913
Okay?

98
00:04:56.913 --> 00:05:01.054
This is at 100 hardness, so
the edges are very firm.

99
00:05:01.054 --> 00:05:03.294
There's no kind of
wishy-washiness about them.

100
00:05:03.294 --> 00:05:10.168
Let me show you what would happen
if we change the hardness to 50%.

101
00:05:10.168 --> 00:05:12.139
Let me zoom in so
you can actually see that.

102
00:05:13.330 --> 00:05:16.660
If you compare the two, you'll see
the 50% hardness is kinda fuzzy.

103
00:05:16.660 --> 00:05:18.430
>> Yeah, that's what I was gonna say.

104
00:05:18.430 --> 00:05:19.580
It is a little fuzzy there.

105
00:05:19.580 --> 00:05:21.060
>> It's a little fuzzy.

106
00:05:21.060 --> 00:05:23.210
So let's take this down even further.

107
00:05:23.210 --> 00:05:25.400
So let's go down to 25%,
and let's compare again.

108
00:05:25.400 --> 00:05:28.675
So I'm gonna do that right under the 50.

109
00:05:28.675 --> 00:05:32.130
>> Mm-hm.

110
00:05:32.130 --> 00:05:32.910
Okay?

111
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:36.540
So that is your hardness, now you might
want to adjust the hardness of your brush,

112
00:05:36.540 --> 00:05:39.770
if let's say that you're creating
something like spray painting.

113
00:05:39.770 --> 00:05:42.140
Spray painting your not gonna want a hard,

114
00:05:42.140 --> 00:05:45.380
edged brush because it's
not gonna look realistic.

115
00:05:45.380 --> 00:05:47.296
So you can adjust the hardness like that.

116
00:05:47.296 --> 00:05:49.251
>> Very cool.

117
00:05:49.251 --> 00:05:51.390
>> So I'm gonna zoom out for you.

118
00:05:51.390 --> 00:05:55.580
So the difference between the 50 and
25 isn't as noticeable as the 100% and 25.

119
00:05:56.720 --> 00:05:59.180
You'll see as you
experiment with Photoshop.

120
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:02.570
Playing around with the brushes, you'll
find the perfect sweet spot for you.

121
00:06:03.620 --> 00:06:08.730
So everything we've done so
far is using this same brush,

122
00:06:08.730 --> 00:06:11.470
so what were to happen if we
picked one of these other brushes?

123
00:06:11.470 --> 00:06:12.300
So let's see.

124
00:06:12.300 --> 00:06:16.110
I'm going to pick this soft,
round, pressure size brush.

125
00:06:16.110 --> 00:06:19.990
If I do that, you'll notice that the
hardness automatically changed to zero.

126
00:06:19.990 --> 00:06:24.120
That's because this brush is already
in here as what's called a preset.

127
00:06:24.120 --> 00:06:27.840
Photoshop already has preloaded
brushes in here for you.

128
00:06:27.840 --> 00:06:29.730
That way you don't have to
create them from scratch.

129
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:32.429
So let's just,
I'm gonna draw a little smiley face.

130
00:06:33.500 --> 00:06:35.520
There we go.
So it has that low hardness so

131
00:06:35.520 --> 00:06:39.400
the edges aren't very firm and
exact and precise.

132
00:06:39.400 --> 00:06:40.690
Okay.
Let's try another brush,

133
00:06:40.690 --> 00:06:43.450
something that's a little bit more fun and
artistic.

134
00:06:43.450 --> 00:06:46.940
Let's try this brush right here.

135
00:06:46.940 --> 00:06:49.550
So if you hover over the brush,
it'll tell you exactly what it is.

136
00:06:49.550 --> 00:06:51.810
So this is fan high bristle count.

137
00:06:54.352 --> 00:06:59.900
So if we paint like this, it looks
a little bit more like a real paintbrush.

138
00:06:59.900 --> 00:07:04.460
>> Yeah, it almost gives you
a calligraphy effect there when you-

139
00:07:04.460 --> 00:07:06.010
>> It really does, it really does.

140
00:07:06.010 --> 00:07:08.670
Photoshop actually works
really well with calligraphy.

141
00:07:08.670 --> 00:07:10.720
There's actually a set of
calligraphy brushes in

142
00:07:10.720 --> 00:07:11.450
Photoshop-
>> Wow.

143
00:07:11.450 --> 00:07:12.380
>> Preloaded.

144
00:07:12.380 --> 00:07:16.100
So let's go ahead and find those cuz
that's something I was gonna go over next.

145
00:07:16.100 --> 00:07:20.240
So in most of your expandable panels
you'll see this little gear type icon.

146
00:07:20.240 --> 00:07:22.970
It's either a gear or a little menu box.

147
00:07:22.970 --> 00:07:26.280
If you click on this,
it'll provide you with more options.

148
00:07:26.280 --> 00:07:30.330
So the first thing I wanna show you
in this options menu is how to change

149
00:07:30.330 --> 00:07:32.420
what the brushes look like in here.

150
00:07:32.420 --> 00:07:36.410
So let's say that you prefer to look
at large thumbnails of the brushes.

151
00:07:36.410 --> 00:07:37.100
You can.

152
00:07:37.100 --> 00:07:39.270
You'll notice that it changed my brush.

153
00:07:39.270 --> 00:07:43.740
So now, we can clearly see the difference
between the brush bristles,

154
00:07:43.740 --> 00:07:45.740
their hardness, all of that.

155
00:07:45.740 --> 00:07:50.193
Let's say that you prefer to see the list,
you can change it to list format.

156
00:07:50.193 --> 00:07:52.855
Again, this is completely up to you and
your personal preference.

157
00:07:52.855 --> 00:07:54.021
That's where to find that.

158
00:07:54.021 --> 00:07:58.024
Now, let's go onto
the calligraphy brushes.

159
00:07:58.024 --> 00:08:00.714
So you'll notice at the bottom
of this fly out menu,

160
00:08:00.714 --> 00:08:02.930
we have all these different brushes here.

161
00:08:02.930 --> 00:08:07.390
And you'll notice one
says calligraphy brushes.

162
00:08:07.390 --> 00:08:08.230
So I'm going to click on that.

163
00:08:09.590 --> 00:08:13.360
And it says that I'm either
going to replace, or

164
00:08:13.360 --> 00:08:14.630
I could do something called appending.

165
00:08:14.630 --> 00:08:17.980
So let's look and
see what happens with both options.

166
00:08:17.980 --> 00:08:20.730
So right now it says replace current
brushes with the brushes from

167
00:08:20.730 --> 00:08:21.830
calligraphic brushes.

168
00:08:21.830 --> 00:08:22.990
You can go ahead and click OK.

169
00:08:24.050 --> 00:08:25.710
But if you notice your brush panel,

170
00:08:25.710 --> 00:08:29.980
now you don't have any of your original
brushes, which isn't really what

171
00:08:29.980 --> 00:08:34.130
I want because I like to go back and see
those brushes that were there originally.

172
00:08:34.130 --> 00:08:38.014
So what you can do is go back to
that handy little gear icon, and

173
00:08:38.014 --> 00:08:41.094
I'm going to click on
the Reset Brushes option.

174
00:08:43.530 --> 00:08:46.096
Okay, and
I'm going to click OK to replace.

175
00:08:46.096 --> 00:08:48.380
And there I have my original brushes back.

176
00:08:49.910 --> 00:08:52.540
Now, let's say I want to append.

177
00:08:52.540 --> 00:08:53.490
What does append mean?

178
00:08:53.490 --> 00:08:54.250
Let's try it out.

179
00:08:54.250 --> 00:08:55.940
Let's add our calligraphy brushes.

180
00:08:55.940 --> 00:08:59.045
And this time I'm going to
click append instead of OK.

181
00:09:00.410 --> 00:09:03.720
You probably notice it didn't do anything
different, at least on first glance,

182
00:09:03.720 --> 00:09:08.090
unless you noticed that your
scroll menu got longer.

183
00:09:08.090 --> 00:09:12.987
So if you scroll down, now we'll have
our calligraphy brushes down here.

184
00:09:12.987 --> 00:09:19.988
Then we can test one out so
I'm just going to write hi, okay?

185
00:09:19.988 --> 00:09:20.847
There you go.

186
00:09:20.847 --> 00:09:23.700
Now you have some calligraphy
brushes there for you.

187
00:09:25.080 --> 00:09:28.840
Okay, I'm gonna undo all that and again,
so what I did to undo more than once,

188
00:09:28.840 --> 00:09:32.750
just in case you forget,
it's control alt z, command alt z.

189
00:09:32.750 --> 00:09:33.550
That's what it is.

190
00:09:33.550 --> 00:09:38.915
So you notice if I just do once,
I'll just be keep going back and forth.

191
00:09:38.915 --> 00:09:40.111
Not what I want.

192
00:09:40.111 --> 00:09:41.597
>> Mm-hm.

193
00:09:41.597 --> 00:09:42.212
>> There you go.

194
00:09:42.212 --> 00:09:47.553
[LAUGH] Okay,
back to our little brush panel.

195
00:09:47.553 --> 00:09:52.240
You'll notice under Reset,
we also have a Load Brushes option.

196
00:09:52.240 --> 00:09:54.590
So you might want to load brushes if,

197
00:09:54.590 --> 00:09:57.340
let's say that you found some
online that are really cool.

198
00:09:57.340 --> 00:09:59.040
Okay, so there's some great sites on line,

199
00:09:59.040 --> 00:10:02.540
great resources where you
can get free brushes.

200
00:10:02.540 --> 00:10:07.090
So, for example you can get brushes for
things like coffee stains or spraypaint,

201
00:10:07.090 --> 00:10:08.210
like I mentioned before.

202
00:10:08.210 --> 00:10:11.660
So if you find one of those,
you can download that file path and

203
00:10:11.660 --> 00:10:15.380
then load it through here, okay?

204
00:10:15.380 --> 00:10:19.090
If you have certain brushes that you've
created yourself, you can also save them.

205
00:10:19.090 --> 00:10:21.580
We're going to be creating
some of our own brushed today.

206
00:10:23.730 --> 00:10:25.110
Any questions thus far?

207
00:10:25.110 --> 00:10:26.330
>> No.
Very impressive, though.

208
00:10:26.330 --> 00:10:29.150
Just the number of different brushes, and
now that fact that you can go out and

209
00:10:29.150 --> 00:10:31.710
get other brushed that other people
have created and create your own.

210
00:10:31.710 --> 00:10:32.310
Very impressive.

211
00:10:33.350 --> 00:10:36.630
>> All right so now we're going to dig
a bit little further into brushes.

212
00:10:36.630 --> 00:10:40.630
So I'm going to pick one of
our standard hard brushes.

213
00:10:40.630 --> 00:10:44.650
So this is a hard round, you can
really pick whatever brush you want.

214
00:10:44.650 --> 00:10:46.050
So I'm just gonna click off of this so

215
00:10:46.050 --> 00:10:49.140
that way I don't have my
panel distracting us anymore.

216
00:10:49.140 --> 00:10:53.570
So I'm going to just draw
a little squiggly line.

217
00:10:53.570 --> 00:10:55.630
So I haven't done any kind
of adjustments to it,

218
00:10:55.630 --> 00:10:57.806
this is just the hard round brush,
nothing fancy.

219
00:10:57.806 --> 00:11:03.112
But, you'll notice that we have these
options across this tool options bar.

220
00:11:03.112 --> 00:11:04.969
There's something called opacity.

221
00:11:04.969 --> 00:11:08.499
So right now you'll see that
it's defaulted to 100%.

222
00:11:08.499 --> 00:11:12.924
So let's see the difference if I
were to change it down to 75%, so

223
00:11:12.924 --> 00:11:18.140
I'm gonna just hard type it in, 75%,
and let's draw right underneath it.

224
00:11:20.470 --> 00:11:24.660
Okay, so you'll notice that it looks like
it's almost a faded version of itself.

225
00:11:24.660 --> 00:11:27.967
It's really not faded, so
much as it is transparent.

226
00:11:27.967 --> 00:11:33.969
So let's see what happens
if we go down to 50.

227
00:11:33.969 --> 00:11:35.583
Okay, even less so.

228
00:11:35.583 --> 00:11:37.068
And then down to 25.

229
00:11:40.842 --> 00:11:43.642
Okay, now, you can't really
tell that you can see through

230
00:11:43.642 --> 00:11:46.500
the layer because they're not
stacked on top of each other.

231
00:11:46.500 --> 00:11:49.630
So let's draw through
this top layer up here.

232
00:11:49.630 --> 00:11:54.800
Now when I do,
with this brush at 25% opacity,

233
00:11:54.800 --> 00:12:00.410
you'll see that it looks like it's behind
the stroke, because it's so transparent.

234
00:12:00.410 --> 00:12:05.570
Now if we were to raise the opacity,
let's say to 80%, and draw over it,

235
00:12:05.570 --> 00:12:10.170
you'll notice, if we zoom in,
that you'll be able to see where

236
00:12:10.170 --> 00:12:15.170
it overlaps ever so lightly,
but it's still faded.

237
00:12:15.170 --> 00:12:19.490
So a transparency deals with how
much you can see through something.

238
00:12:19.490 --> 00:12:23.250
Okay, opacity for
the 100% you can't see through it,

239
00:12:23.250 --> 00:12:27.180
if it's lower then you can see
down through it to the next level.

240
00:12:27.180 --> 00:12:30.380
It's a very important
concept in Photoshop.

241
00:12:30.380 --> 00:12:33.600
You learned it already in the layers
panel, cuz you can make your layers

242
00:12:33.600 --> 00:12:37.180
transparent through changing opacity,
you can also do it with brushes.

243
00:12:38.630 --> 00:12:40.300
Okay so that's opacity,

244
00:12:41.430 --> 00:12:45.120
there is one special little tool
in opacity with the CC version.

245
00:12:45.120 --> 00:12:48.190
You'll notice off to the right,
there's this little icon that looks like

246
00:12:48.190 --> 00:12:51.760
a pencil with, it looks kind of like it's
on top of an apple pie for some reason.

247
00:12:51.760 --> 00:12:53.855
That's not what it is.

248
00:12:53.855 --> 00:12:54.920
[LAUGH] If you hover over it,

00:12:54.920 --> 00:12:59.090
you'll see that it'll tell you that

250
00:12:59.090 --> 00:13:04.590
So if you turn this on, and
you hold down your mouse,

251
00:13:04.590 --> 00:13:08.060
it will change how opaque something is.

252
00:13:08.060 --> 00:13:11.740
It's more obvious at certain levels of
opacity than others but if you are trying

253
00:13:11.740 --> 00:13:15.880
to create that authentic, spray paint
look, this might be a good option for you.

254
00:13:17.410 --> 00:13:19.100
Okay, so that's that.

255
00:13:19.100 --> 00:13:20.960
Let's erase just a few of these so

256
00:13:20.960 --> 00:13:25.210
we have a little bit more space And
let's talk about this concept of flow.

257
00:13:25.210 --> 00:13:28.130
So I'm going to change this back to 100,
just so I don't forget to later.

258
00:13:28.130 --> 00:13:29.938
An important thing to note is,

259
00:13:29.938 --> 00:13:33.841
things like opacity like to default
to whatever you had last time.

260
00:13:33.841 --> 00:13:37.977
So if you can't figure out why your brush
is see-through, check your opacity.

261
00:13:37.977 --> 00:13:41.077
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Good to know.

262
00:13:41.077 --> 00:13:42.437
>> Okay, so flow.

263
00:13:42.437 --> 00:13:46.990
What flow does is, it sets the rate
of how much color is applied.

264
00:13:46.990 --> 00:13:48.570
So let's test that out.

265
00:13:48.570 --> 00:13:52.090
So right now it's at 100%,
which is our standard line.

266
00:13:52.090 --> 00:13:53.365
It looks fine, it looks good.

267
00:13:53.365 --> 00:13:55.525
Let's change that to 50%.

268
00:13:55.525 --> 00:13:58.720
Let's zoom in so
you can actually see the difference.

269
00:13:59.770 --> 00:14:04.280
Now you will notice,
if I zoom in even further, you can see,

270
00:14:04.280 --> 00:14:09.320
as I was dragging my mouse,
these overlapping dots of colors here.

271
00:14:09.320 --> 00:14:10.440
That's because of the flow.

272
00:14:12.520 --> 00:14:15.080
Okay, kind of a complicated concept.

273
00:14:15.080 --> 00:14:16.650
You don't use flow all that often.

274
00:14:16.650 --> 00:14:19.709
You use opacity a lot more.

275
00:14:19.709 --> 00:14:23.480
>> Is flow trying to be like, I'm trying
to think of a good example of when you

276
00:14:23.480 --> 00:14:26.980
might wanna do something like that, where
you're spray painting and the spray paint

277
00:14:26.980 --> 00:14:29.590
can is sputtering and running out,
that's kinda the same concept?

278
00:14:29.590 --> 00:14:30.250
>> Exactly.

279
00:14:30.250 --> 00:14:32.630
Yep.
Very much the same.

280
00:14:32.630 --> 00:14:34.310
Okay, I'm gonna take that back up to 100%.

281
00:14:34.310 --> 00:14:37.250
So now I'm back to my default opacity and
flow.

282
00:14:38.630 --> 00:14:42.830
Up at the top, you'll notice we
also have something called Mode.

283
00:14:42.830 --> 00:14:45.650
Mode isn't something we've
really touched on yet.

284
00:14:45.650 --> 00:14:49.250
It's something we're going to be
going over in depth with layers and

285
00:14:49.250 --> 00:14:52.030
photo editing, but
we can do it with brushes, as well.

286
00:14:52.030 --> 00:14:54.550
So let's demonstrate a few of these guys.

287
00:14:54.550 --> 00:14:57.130
Let's click on Dissolve first.

288
00:14:57.130 --> 00:15:01.810
So I'm going to paint across this and
you'll notice that if I zoom in, now all

289
00:15:01.810 --> 00:15:06.710
of a sudden we have kind of this rough
pixelation, it almost looks like a crayon.

290
00:15:06.710 --> 00:15:07.710
>> Mm-hm.

291
00:15:07.710 --> 00:15:08.313
>> Okay?

292
00:15:08.313 --> 00:15:09.840
So that's our dissolve.

293
00:15:11.120 --> 00:15:14.180
Let's try color burn.

294
00:15:15.470 --> 00:15:16.780
If we use our color burn,

295
00:15:16.780 --> 00:15:21.490
you'll notice that it's almost making it,
it is making it darker.

296
00:15:21.490 --> 00:15:22.520
That's really what it is doing.

297
00:15:22.520 --> 00:15:27.480
It's as if you were to take kind of
a flame to it and darken the edges.

298
00:15:27.480 --> 00:15:31.060
So it's something that you might use if
you're doing let's say an old letter, and

299
00:15:31.060 --> 00:15:32.470
you wanna make it look antique.

300
00:15:32.470 --> 00:15:33.500
That's something that you can do.

301
00:15:35.050 --> 00:15:38.260
There are a few other options that you
can do in here, really tons of them.

302
00:15:38.260 --> 00:15:40.400
And it's really an experimental thing.

303
00:15:40.400 --> 00:15:44.160
So you're gonna go through these modes and
say wow, that was unexpected,

304
00:15:44.160 --> 00:15:45.180
right, look at that.

305
00:15:45.180 --> 00:15:48.242
This is our color dodge,
so it's lightening.

306
00:15:48.242 --> 00:15:50.087
>> Kind of the opposite of brown though,
[LAUGH].

307
00:15:50.087 --> 00:15:53.909
>> Exactly, so, modes are something
that you're gonna play around with for

308
00:15:53.909 --> 00:15:58.216
years and years and years, and you still
probably will never understand exactly how

309
00:15:58.216 --> 00:16:01.387
they work, because they're
based on mathematic formulas.

310
00:16:01.387 --> 00:16:02.992
So, don't worry about that.

311
00:16:02.992 --> 00:16:06.060
Just experiment with them,
play with different colors.

312
00:16:06.060 --> 00:16:09.915
It's a pretty fun little mode for you.

313
00:16:09.915 --> 00:16:12.790
[LAUGH] I'm gonna change
it back to normal, just so

314
00:16:12.790 --> 00:16:15.450
we don't have any kind of weird
color things happen later on.

315
00:16:16.490 --> 00:16:22.040
All right, so now we've gone over that
tool, we've gone over the tool options bar

00:16:22.040 --> 00:16:26.730
Now we need to figure out how to

00:16:26.730 --> 00:16:31.880
So what I'm going to do is I'm going to
select a brush from my brush presets.

00:16:31.880 --> 00:16:33.990
And I'm going to select this leaf.

00:16:33.990 --> 00:16:35.660
So the leaf has number 95.

00:16:35.660 --> 00:16:39.820
If you're looking at your tool panel,

00:16:39.820 --> 00:16:40.610
So I'm gonna click on that.

322
00:16:43.090 --> 00:16:44.610
And it defaults to 95.

00:16:44.610 --> 00:16:46.070
That's completely fine.

324
00:16:46.070 --> 00:16:49.750
But I want to do something a little
bit more than what it is right now.

00:16:49.750 --> 00:16:53.900
So let's go ahead and

00:16:53.900 --> 00:16:55.460
So I'm gonna go into my layers panel.

00:16:55.460 --> 00:17:00.320
And instead of erasing like I had before,

328
00:17:01.630 --> 00:17:04.330
And unlock this guy and hide it.

329
00:17:04.330 --> 00:17:05.360
Okay, so there.

00:17:05.360 --> 00:17:06.470
We have our blank layer.

00:17:06.470 --> 00:17:09.315
And that helps refresh you on

332
00:17:09.315 --> 00:17:11.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

333
00:17:11.210 --> 00:17:14.340
let's see what this little
leaf brush looks like.

334
00:17:16.220 --> 00:17:20.530
So, it's kind of hard to see,
because it's on a transparent layer.

335
00:17:20.530 --> 00:17:23.320
So we need to make this background white.

336
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:26.340
So I mentioned earlier that there's
something called the paint bucket tool.

337
00:17:26.340 --> 00:17:28.938
Let's do that instead of making
a really large 5,000 pixel brush.

338
00:17:28.938 --> 00:17:31.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz that's just silly to do.

339
00:17:31.110 --> 00:17:35.160
So the paint bucket is two tools
down from where my brush tool is.

00:17:35.160 --> 00:17:37.230
It might be somewhere

00:17:37.230 --> 00:17:37.810
Just look for

00:17:37.810 --> 00:17:42.349
its hidden beneath what's called the

343
00:17:43.360 --> 00:17:46.520
So if I were to make this a solid
color right now if I clicked,

344
00:17:48.180 --> 00:17:50.400
it would be this purple color.

345
00:17:50.400 --> 00:17:51.810
Not want I want at all.

00:17:51.810 --> 00:17:53.960
Let's just not do that.

00:17:53.960 --> 00:17:56.630
Let's make it instead white.

348
00:17:56.630 --> 00:17:59.840
So white is all the way up

00:17:59.840 --> 00:18:03.130
What I did was I drug my house up there.

00:18:03.130 --> 00:18:07.480
You can also type in [FOREIGN], if you

00:18:07.480 --> 00:18:10.300
We're going to talk about that

352
00:18:11.820 --> 00:18:12.450
So let's do this.

00:18:12.450 --> 00:18:13.950
So now you can see these brushes but

354
00:18:13.950 --> 00:18:16.860
they look kind of silly
because of the transparency.

355
00:18:16.860 --> 00:18:19.240
So I am going to just.

00:18:19.240 --> 00:18:23.280
Ignore this guy, so this is what happens

357
00:18:23.280 --> 00:18:26.230
It's probably not what you
want it to look like, so

00:18:26.230 --> 00:18:29.360
let's just create a new blank layer and
fill it.

359
00:18:29.360 --> 00:18:30.200
Okay, lovely.

360
00:18:30.200 --> 00:18:33.430
All right, so
let's go into our brush again.

00:18:33.430 --> 00:18:38.460
Here's our leaf at 95, so if I were

00:18:38.460 --> 00:18:41.339
So to do that I'm going to click

00:18:43.130 --> 00:18:46.020
And here we have these black leaves.

00:18:46.020 --> 00:18:47.800
Pretty cool, what it does.

00:18:47.800 --> 00:18:50.480
But I want to customize it even further.

00:18:50.480 --> 00:18:54.180
The way that you can do that is

00:18:54.180 --> 00:18:56.370
There's this little folder.

00:18:56.370 --> 00:18:58.330
That looks like it has
little flowers on it.

00:18:58.330 --> 00:18:59.790
It's actually supposed to be brushes and

00:18:59.790 --> 00:19:02.910
a pencil type cup, but

371
00:19:02.910 --> 00:19:05.920
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Now if you open this brush

372
00:19:05.920 --> 00:19:09.260
presets window, you'll notice all of

00:19:09.260 --> 00:19:12.910
So we're gonna kinda click through

00:19:12.910 --> 00:19:16.110
Now at the bottom of your screen
you'll notice that you have this

375
00:19:16.110 --> 00:19:16.870
It's kinda square.

00:19:16.870 --> 00:19:18.910
That has the information in it for you.

377
00:19:18.910 --> 00:19:22.230
So it shows you what's adjusting

00:19:22.230 --> 00:19:25.665
So let's play with the size and

379
00:19:25.665 --> 00:19:30.320
So size, as you guessed,

00:19:30.320 --> 00:19:33.770
So you'll see there,
they're changing as I draw around.

381
00:19:34.960 --> 00:19:38.860
The minimum diameter you
can play around with, too.

382
00:19:38.860 --> 00:19:41.070
All of this.

383
00:19:41.070 --> 00:19:44.670
And let's go ahead into scattering,
cause scattering is really neat.

384
00:19:44.670 --> 00:19:48.060
If I were to turn off scattering,
it would be in a straight line.

385
00:19:48.060 --> 00:19:49.350
So let me demonstrate that for you.

386
00:19:50.420 --> 00:19:51.905
Not super interesting.

387
00:19:51.905 --> 00:19:52.930
>> Uh-huh.

388
00:19:52.930 --> 00:19:56.200
>> It's kind of like an old border that
you might see in one of your old programs

389
00:19:56.200 --> 00:19:57.160
on your computer.

390
00:19:57.160 --> 00:19:58.870
Not really that exciting.

391
00:19:58.870 --> 00:20:03.890
So scattering, what it does is it
changes the direction of the leaves,

392
00:20:03.890 --> 00:20:05.320
it makes them more random.

393
00:20:05.320 --> 00:20:09.670
So if you were going for a more random

394
00:20:10.900 --> 00:20:13.020
Now you can change how much they scatter.

00:20:13.020 --> 00:20:16.740
So if I scatter more,

00:20:16.740 --> 00:20:18.450

397
00:20:19.810 --> 00:20:21.260
You can also change the count.

398
00:20:22.600 --> 00:20:23.750
And again, you can slide all these.

399
00:20:23.750 --> 00:20:26.660
So if I were to change the count
to be even greater than it is now,

400
00:20:26.660 --> 00:20:29.090
that just means they're going
to be more overlapping.

401
00:20:31.180 --> 00:20:31.950
Okay.

402
00:20:31.950 --> 00:20:34.120
So now that we have
just a mess of leaves-,

403
00:20:34.120 --> 00:20:35.110
>> We have a lot of leaves.

404
00:20:35.110 --> 00:20:35.965
Time for a rake.

405
00:20:35.965 --> 00:20:36.900
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I think so.

406
00:20:36.900 --> 00:20:39.220
Let me go ahead and get this back.

407
00:20:39.220 --> 00:20:39.890
Okay.

408
00:20:39.890 --> 00:20:41.470
And let's go into texture.

409
00:20:41.470 --> 00:20:43.468
So texture is something

00:20:43.468 --> 00:20:48.680
There are built-in textures in Photoshop,

00:20:48.680 --> 00:20:52.010
So you can make them look like marble, you
can make them look like whatever you want.

412
00:20:52.010 --> 00:20:53.870
It's something that you don't
use a lot with brushes, but

413
00:20:53.870 --> 00:20:55.260
you do use it other places.

414
00:20:55.260 --> 00:20:56.780
I'm gonna uncheck that box.

415
00:20:57.900 --> 00:21:00.530
Now, if you check a box and
you notice it didn't do anything,

00:21:00.530 --> 00:21:04.310
the reason why is because you have

00:21:04.310 --> 00:21:09.610
So if you click on the word,
