00:21:09.610 --> 00:21:13.960
Same thing with the fx panel, the layer
styles panel that we're going to be going

419
00:21:13.960 --> 00:21:16.530
over a little bit later on in Photoshop.

420
00:21:17.980 --> 00:21:21.110
Color dynamic, now this one is pretty fun.

421
00:21:21.110 --> 00:21:21.880
Let's go ahead and

422
00:21:21.880 --> 00:21:25.530
change the color from white which
is my foreground color right now.

423
00:21:25.530 --> 00:21:28.660
I'm going to pick a green
from my spectrum.

424
00:21:28.660 --> 00:21:30.030
Really doesn't matter what green it is.

425
00:21:30.030 --> 00:21:33.690
You can pick your favorite shade of green
or you can go for a fall leaf, go for

426
00:21:33.690 --> 00:21:34.350
a different color.

427
00:21:34.350 --> 00:21:35.470
Totally up to you.

428
00:21:35.470 --> 00:21:37.730
This is just for demonstration purposes.

429
00:21:37.730 --> 00:21:38.920
I'm going to click okay.

430
00:21:38.920 --> 00:21:42.990
And I'm going to go ahead and
drag across and you'll notice That I have

431
00:21:42.990 --> 00:21:47.360
green leaves, I have some purple,
I have some kind of yellow and brown.

432
00:21:47.360 --> 00:21:50.200
The reason why is the way
these jitters are set.

433
00:21:50.200 --> 00:21:54.850
So if you change the hue,
the saturation, they're going to adjust.

434
00:21:56.820 --> 00:21:59.330
Okay?
So you'll notice now I have some brighter

435
00:21:59.330 --> 00:22:00.720
oranges in there.

436
00:22:00.720 --> 00:22:01.680
You'll play around with it.

437
00:22:01.680 --> 00:22:03.330
It's really fun to add color.

438
00:22:03.330 --> 00:22:08.200
You can also change your background
color as well to get more variety.

439
00:22:08.200 --> 00:22:11.280
So you can really play around with
these really cool brush options.

440
00:22:11.280 --> 00:22:15.250
You can also create your own custom brush.

441
00:22:15.250 --> 00:22:16.740
So how you would do that.

442
00:22:16.740 --> 00:22:21.320
So let's say that I really like what
I've done with this leaf brush, really,

443
00:22:21.320 --> 00:22:23.810
what I want it to be,
I wanna use it in the future.

444
00:22:23.810 --> 00:22:25.490
What you can do is you can save it.

445
00:22:25.490 --> 00:22:27.890
So if you go down to the very
bottom right corner,

446
00:22:27.890 --> 00:22:30.020
you'll notice this sticky note icon.

447
00:22:30.020 --> 00:22:34.510
It probably looks familiar to you because
that's exactly what it looks like in

448
00:22:34.510 --> 00:22:36.950
your layers panel as well
to create a new layer.

449
00:22:36.950 --> 00:22:40.260
So if you click on this,
you'll see it says create new brush.

450
00:22:40.260 --> 00:22:43.080
And you'll be given an option
to name it something, so

451
00:22:43.080 --> 00:22:48.065
I'm going to name mine Fall Leaves and
I'm going to click okay.

452
00:22:49.240 --> 00:22:53.310
Now let's check to see if Photoshop
has that brush I created.

453
00:22:53.310 --> 00:22:57.410
Let's go up to our brushes up here,
and just so

454
00:22:57.410 --> 00:23:01.460
you know it will save as your last brush,
and if I hover over that.

455
00:23:01.460 --> 00:23:03.220
You'll see it says Fall Leaves.

456
00:23:03.220 --> 00:23:05.180
So it did save my brush.

457
00:23:05.180 --> 00:23:09.790
So my regular 95 brush that I was
using before isn't going to look

458
00:23:09.790 --> 00:23:11.770
the same as this modified brush I created.

459
00:23:12.890 --> 00:23:15.480
Let's say that you were messing
around with a brush and

460
00:23:15.480 --> 00:23:16.820
you really hate how it looks.

461
00:23:16.820 --> 00:23:18.760
And you wanna go back
to the original brush.

462
00:23:18.760 --> 00:23:19.940
You can.

463
00:23:19.940 --> 00:23:22.540
What you can do is you can
click on the three lines.

464
00:23:22.540 --> 00:23:26.400
So this little hamburger menu
up at the top of your panel.

465
00:23:26.400 --> 00:23:29.870
So instead of a gear icon,
it's a little menu and

466
00:23:29.870 --> 00:23:35.220
you'll see that you can do reset on lock
settings if you have that were locked and

467
00:23:35.220 --> 00:23:38.560
you modified or
you can clear your brush controls.

468
00:23:38.560 --> 00:23:41.980
So if you do that It'll
change back to what it was.

469
00:23:43.920 --> 00:23:44.840
>> That's very cool.

470
00:23:44.840 --> 00:23:48.400
It'll give you a lot of control over,
I mean one they give you a ton of brushes.

471
00:23:48.400 --> 00:23:52.000
And then the fact that you can
customize any one of those.

472
00:23:52.000 --> 00:23:53.770
The options are endless.

473
00:23:53.770 --> 00:23:55.206
>> They really are.

474
00:23:55.206 --> 00:23:58.810
Not only that, but you can create
a brush completely from scratch.

475
00:23:58.810 --> 00:24:00.748
>> Wow.
>> So let's test that theory out.

476
00:24:00.748 --> 00:24:05.315
So I'm gonna erase all my leaves cuz It's
not fall anymore, we don't need them.

477
00:24:05.315 --> 00:24:06.330
We raked them, they're gone.

478
00:24:08.090 --> 00:24:10.900
Let's say that I wanted
to draw a brush myself.

479
00:24:10.900 --> 00:24:14.270
I'm going to pick one of
these calligraphy brushes,

480
00:24:14.270 --> 00:24:15.960
it really doesn't matter
what brush you pick.

481
00:24:17.390 --> 00:24:20.490
I'm just going to do the letter K for
my name.

482
00:24:20.490 --> 00:24:26.550
I want my brush to be black, so I'm going
to change my foreground color to black and

483
00:24:26.550 --> 00:24:30.610
I'm just going to draw a K.

484
00:24:30.610 --> 00:24:33.540
You can draw the first letter of your
name, you can draw a smiley face.

485
00:24:33.540 --> 00:24:34.560
It really doesn't matter.

486
00:24:36.180 --> 00:24:38.950
We're gong to go up to our Edit menu.

487
00:24:38.950 --> 00:24:44.210
Under Edit, if you look towards the
bottom, you'll see Define Brush Preset.

488
00:24:44.210 --> 00:24:46.240
I'm gonna go ahead and do that.

489
00:24:46.240 --> 00:24:49.310
And you'll notice in my little box,
I have that K.

490
00:24:49.310 --> 00:24:53.430
I'm going to name it K, click OK.

491
00:24:53.430 --> 00:24:57.380
Now you'll notice that my brush
defaulted to this huge K.

492
00:24:57.380 --> 00:24:58.620
Now I'm going to change the size.

493
00:24:58.620 --> 00:25:01.520
It doesn't need to be 695
pixels unless I just really

494
00:25:01.520 --> 00:25:03.860
want the world to see a huge K.

495
00:25:03.860 --> 00:25:08.510
I'm going to change it to 44 and
if I draw with it, it'll do this or

496
00:25:08.510 --> 00:25:12.120
I can just single click and
put my K anywhere.

497
00:25:13.190 --> 00:25:16.560
You might be wondering,
how can I use this?

498
00:25:16.560 --> 00:25:18.240
How is that useful for me?

499
00:25:18.240 --> 00:25:23.030
Some artists and photographers use
brushes for things like watermarks.

500
00:25:23.030 --> 00:25:26.320
Or if you want to create
your artist signature and

501
00:25:26.320 --> 00:25:30.090
you just wanna do a single click instead
of importing some kind of signature you've

502
00:25:30.090 --> 00:25:34.130
created in another program, you can just
create it as a brush and then there it is.

503
00:25:35.530 --> 00:25:38.480
>> I see when you paint it with
those all the Ks are lined up and

504
00:25:38.480 --> 00:25:40.540
they overlap each other,
it makes an interesting looking line.

505
00:25:40.540 --> 00:25:45.060
Do you still have the same options like
the jitter that you were talking about,

506
00:25:45.060 --> 00:25:46.945
can I scatter those around like leaves?

507
00:25:46.945 --> 00:25:48.540
>> [LAUGH] You sure can.

508
00:25:48.540 --> 00:25:53.110
What you can do is, with your K-brush
selected, you can go to this folder that

509
00:25:53.110 --> 00:25:57.270
looks like flowers, and
then you can add your scattering here.

510
00:25:58.780 --> 00:26:00.370
Scatter as much as you want.

511
00:26:00.370 --> 00:26:02.650
It kind of creates a cool pattern,
look at that.

512
00:26:02.650 --> 00:26:03.180
>> It does, doesn't it?

513
00:26:04.420 --> 00:26:05.110
>> There you go.
[LAUGH]

514
00:26:05.110 --> 00:26:05.905
>> Very good.

515
00:26:05.905 --> 00:26:09.570
You have all the same options there
that we have with the built in brushes.

516
00:26:09.570 --> 00:26:10.070
>> Exactly.

517
00:26:11.100 --> 00:26:13.960
I'm gonna show you one more thing
on how to make a custom brush.

518
00:26:13.960 --> 00:26:16.650
Let me just delete all these Ks.

519
00:26:16.650 --> 00:26:18.700
I'll leave that K because that's fine.

520
00:26:18.700 --> 00:26:21.380
I'm going to place an image now.

521
00:26:21.380 --> 00:26:24.080
We're gonna go to File > Place Embedded.

522
00:26:25.980 --> 00:26:28.650
Let's look for this butterfly PNG.

523
00:26:28.650 --> 00:26:29.400
I'm gonna place this.

524
00:26:30.610 --> 00:26:33.610
We need to resize this butterfly,
it's really large.

525
00:26:33.610 --> 00:26:35.418
This would be a huge brush if we had it.

526
00:26:35.418 --> 00:26:36.386
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's resize it.

527
00:26:36.386 --> 00:26:38.785
[LAUGH]
>> Invasion of the butterflies!

528
00:26:38.785 --> 00:26:40.545
>> Yes, this is not a horror movie.

529
00:26:40.545 --> 00:26:43.175
Instead, it's just a nice
little butterfly in springtime.

530
00:26:43.175 --> 00:26:45.115
What we're going to do is
we're going to resize it.

531
00:26:45.115 --> 00:26:48.085
In case you don't remember how to do
that while constraining proportions,

532
00:26:48.085 --> 00:26:50.695
you hold down shift and you drag a corner.

533
00:26:51.905 --> 00:26:55.495
Now that I have my little butterfly
selected, I'm just gonna go ahead and

534
00:26:55.495 --> 00:26:57.580
hit Enter to commit that change.

535
00:26:58.810 --> 00:27:02.070
I'm gonna go up to up to my Edit
menu again, and I'm gonna go to

536
00:27:02.070 --> 00:27:08.600
Define Brush Preset and you'll notice that
it has the K and the butterfly in here.

537
00:27:08.600 --> 00:27:12.130
The reason why is because I
still have my K on the screen.

538
00:27:12.130 --> 00:27:15.800
If this was a blank document and
you just had your butterfly,

539
00:27:15.800 --> 00:27:17.060
it would only pick up the butterfly.

540
00:27:17.060 --> 00:27:21.380
But since we don't, we need to use
one of our selection tools, or

541
00:27:21.380 --> 00:27:24.580
we can erase the K,
whatever your preference is.

542
00:27:25.980 --> 00:27:28.870
Here's our quick selection tool,
where we can select our butterfly,

543
00:27:28.870 --> 00:27:32.450
or for the sake of time,
let's just erase the K.

544
00:27:34.380 --> 00:27:40.730
Since we haven't learned the eraser yet,
I'll just show you where it is,

545
00:27:40.730 --> 00:27:45.120
so here it is and then you'll click and
it says smart object must be rasterized.

546
00:27:45.120 --> 00:27:48.190
The reason why, we don't have
our Layers panel open right now.

547
00:27:48.190 --> 00:27:52.260
Let's open up our Layers panel and
let's hide this K.

548
00:27:53.810 --> 00:27:57.710
There we go, we have a butterfly,
it's a PNG, no background.

549
00:27:57.710 --> 00:28:00.290
Let's go ahead and let's try this now.

550
00:28:00.290 --> 00:28:04.880
Let's go to Edit > Define Brush Preset.

551
00:28:04.880 --> 00:28:06.010
There we go.

552
00:28:06.010 --> 00:28:09.470
If you ever get stuck and
there are weird things on your layers,

553
00:28:09.470 --> 00:28:12.020
if you place an image,
the image will be on its own layer.

554
00:28:13.080 --> 00:28:17.190
But if you didn't, if you happened to draw
something and you want to separate them,

555
00:28:17.190 --> 00:28:20.450
you can select them and
move them to different layers, or

556
00:28:20.450 --> 00:28:23.050
you can erase a piece if
you don't need it anymore.

557
00:28:23.050 --> 00:28:25.350
Photoshop's really flexible in that way.

558
00:28:25.350 --> 00:28:30.930
If we were to go ahead and name this
brush, I'll name it butterfly and if we

559
00:28:30.930 --> 00:28:36.840
go to our brush tool, we'll see butterfly
has been added as our very last brush.

560
00:28:38.100 --> 00:28:39.770
I'm going to just cancel that.

561
00:28:39.770 --> 00:28:44.830
Let's make it a new layer and
let's draw some butterflies.

562
00:28:46.000 --> 00:28:48.890
The reason why it's black right
now is cuz my top color is black.

563
00:28:48.890 --> 00:28:49.920
That's the color of my brush.

564
00:28:51.740 --> 00:28:53.760
That pretty much wraps up brushes.

565
00:28:53.760 --> 00:28:55.380
>> Wow.
That was fantastic, Kara.

566
00:28:55.380 --> 00:28:56.110
We thank you for that.

567
00:28:56.110 --> 00:28:57.390
A lot of great information.

568
00:28:57.390 --> 00:28:59.076
Who knew you could do
all that with brushes?

569
00:28:59.076 --> 00:28:59.880
Kara did.

570
00:28:59.880 --> 00:29:01.640
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now we do too.

571
00:29:01.640 --> 00:29:02.560
Thank you for that.

572
00:29:02.560 --> 00:29:04.060
Hope everybody enjoyed watching.

573
00:29:04.060 --> 00:29:07.460
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I'm Mike Rodrick.

574
00:29:07.460 --> 00:29:08.030
>> And I'm Kara Page.

575
00:29:08.030 --> 00:29:10.437
>> And we'll see you next time.

576
00:29:10.437 --> 00:29:17.332
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Brushing and Erasing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.178 --> 00:00:15.388
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.388 --> 00:00:20.854
I'm your host Mike Roderick,
today we're doing Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.854 --> 00:00:25.380
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at brushing and erasing.

5
00:00:25.380 --> 00:00:29.610
We've already taken a first look at all
the different types of brushes we have and

6
00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:32.890
a lot of the different options that
we have available to configure and

7
00:00:32.890 --> 00:00:35.020
customize, and
even create our own brushes.

8
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:37.370
We are going to take it a step
further with the brushes and

9
00:00:37.370 --> 00:00:40.730
bring you racing into the picture and here
to help us with that is Miss Kara Page.

10
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:41.900
How's it going Cara?

11
00:00:41.900 --> 00:00:47.690
>> I'm great, let's go ahead and get
right into this action here with brushes.

12
00:00:47.690 --> 00:00:52.100
So what we are going to do this time
is we're going to be opening up a file.

13
00:00:52.100 --> 00:00:53.370
So you do have this file.

14
00:00:53.370 --> 00:00:56.240
Go ahead and
locate it its called Lakeside.

15
00:00:56.240 --> 00:00:59.723
So I'm going to go to open in Photoshop,

16
00:00:59.723 --> 00:01:01.870
so make sure you have Photoshop up and
available.

17
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:06.995
Click on open and
then I'm going to select lakeside.jpeg.

18
00:01:11.072 --> 00:01:14.620
All right so now we have this
lovely picture of Tennessee.

19
00:01:14.620 --> 00:01:16.710
It's actually not even a lake,
it's the Tennessee River.

20
00:01:16.710 --> 00:01:18.570
But that's completely fine.

21
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:19.250
Nobody needs to know.

22
00:01:19.250 --> 00:01:20.660
It's our little secret.

23
00:01:20.660 --> 00:01:23.920
What we're going to be doing is we're
going to be experimenting with the art

24
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:24.990
history brush.

25
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:28.510
So what we need to do
first is unlock our layer.

26
00:01:28.510 --> 00:01:29.030
As a reminder,

27
00:01:29.030 --> 00:01:33.140
to unlock you can just click on the lock
icon to the right of background.

28
00:01:34.150 --> 00:01:36.160
There we go, now we have a layer.

29
00:01:36.160 --> 00:01:38.680
Now lets make another
layer on top of that.

30
00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:43.200
So I'm going to click on my little sticky
note in the bottom right corner and

31
00:01:43.200 --> 00:01:44.660
now I have layer one.

32
00:01:44.660 --> 00:01:48.210
It's an empty layer I'm going
to make my layer white so

33
00:01:48.210 --> 00:01:50.560
I'm going to click on
my paint bucket tool.

34
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:54.970
Make sure white is your
top foreground color.

35
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:57.010
And then I'm going to single click.

36
00:01:57.010 --> 00:01:59.353
So goodbye Tennessee lake house.

37
00:01:59.353 --> 00:02:00.958
>> [LAUGH] Well nevertheless.

38
00:02:00.958 --> 00:02:02.665
>> [LAUGH] Right?

39
00:02:02.665 --> 00:02:04.790
I know, all of a sudden it's winter.

40
00:02:04.790 --> 00:02:08.070
Okay, so we're on this layer one
which is just a blank layer.

41
00:02:08.070 --> 00:02:11.080
Now we are going to channel
our inner artist, and

42
00:02:11.080 --> 00:02:14.460
we're going to become these impressionist
artists it's gonna be really fun.

43
00:02:14.460 --> 00:02:17.560
How we're gonna do that is
through the art history brush.

44
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:21.090
So, to find the art history brush,
it's over in your tool panel,

45
00:02:21.090 --> 00:02:23.050
just like every other tool.

46
00:02:23.050 --> 00:02:26.900
And it is the little brush icon
that has a swirly around it.

47
00:02:26.900 --> 00:02:29.060
So it's a brush with a little swirl.

48
00:02:29.060 --> 00:02:30.615
To me,
it's like the Rumpelstiltskin brush.

49
00:02:30.615 --> 00:02:31.170
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know,

50
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:32.310
that's what it reminds me of.

51
00:02:32.310 --> 00:02:36.900
So I'm going to click on
this art history brush tool.

52
00:02:36.900 --> 00:02:43.370
Now I'm going to use my brackets
to make my tip bigger or smaller.

53
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:47.000
It's something that works with your
regular brushes and erasers as well.

54
00:02:47.000 --> 00:02:51.370
So the left bracket makes it smaller,
the right bracket makes it bigger.

55
00:02:51.370 --> 00:02:54.189
So I'm going to use
a decently small brush size.

56
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:57.990
And I'm just going to just start clicking.

57
00:02:57.990 --> 00:03:02.030
Now you'll notice,
that you have these crazy lines appear.

58
00:03:02.030 --> 00:03:03.020
This looks weird right?

59
00:03:03.020 --> 00:03:03.580
>> It does.

60
00:03:03.580 --> 00:03:07.290
>> What it's doing is it's picking
up the colors from the image below.

61
00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:11.530
So, we're actually recreating
this picture, this photograph And

62
00:03:11.530 --> 00:03:14.050
making it look more like a painting.

63
00:03:14.050 --> 00:03:18.290
So this loose line that we have selected,
that might not be our best option.

64
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:20.350
All of your different
styles are right here.

65
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:22.420
So we can do tight short.

66
00:03:22.420 --> 00:03:23.770
See what that looks like.

67
00:03:25.250 --> 00:03:27.540
Or we can experiment with tight medium.

68
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:29.680
See what that looks like.

69
00:03:29.680 --> 00:03:35.170
And as we start dragging along and
it fills in, you'll notice,

70
00:03:35.170 --> 00:03:39.750
ever so slightly, that you're starting
to see some kind of image appear.

71
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:44.800
Now this image up here,

72
00:03:44.800 --> 00:03:48.910
these are trees, and
then there's the house and the walkway.

73
00:03:48.910 --> 00:03:53.510
So if you do more and
more brushing you can make it larger,

74
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:55.590
I will do that for the sake of time.

75
00:03:55.590 --> 00:03:57.250
If you just keep going over and over and

76
00:03:57.250 --> 00:04:01.614
over again, all of a sudden it will look
like you're some kind of amazing artist.

77
00:04:01.614 --> 00:04:03.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that instead of a photograph,

78
00:04:03.520 --> 00:04:05.670
you actually created this all yourself.

79
00:04:05.670 --> 00:04:07.550
So I'm just gonna make this very large.

00:04:07.550 --> 00:04:10.985
This is gonna be extremely
impressionistic so

00:04:10.985 --> 00:04:14.350
[LAUGH]
just for the sake of time.

82
00:04:14.350 --> 00:04:19.570
Filling in all these gaps and it's just
based on what color is right below it.

83
00:04:19.570 --> 00:04:23.990
So this is an extremely abstract
version of the picture.

84
00:04:23.990 --> 00:04:26.410
>> Now are you clicking each time or
are you clicking and holding and

85
00:04:26.410 --> 00:04:29.990

00:04:29.990 --> 00:04:31.550

00:04:31.550 --> 00:04:34.940
Since I was clicking and holding down,

you can also just source click,

89
00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:42.190
Now, you'll notice, if you look at

00:04:42.190 --> 00:04:45.350

91
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:48.200
It's just,
this version is extraordinarily abstract,

92
00:04:48.200 --> 00:04:51.165
nobody's gonna know what

93
00:04:51.165 --> 00:04:52.890
[LAUGH]
>> But you could probably sell that and

00:04:52.890 --> 00:04:54.440

00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:57.060
>> Yea, maybe, maybe if you- [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

96
00:04:57.060 --> 00:04:58.320
>> If you really try.

97
00:04:58.320 --> 00:05:02.710
Now the art history brush isn't one that's
used all that often cuz there's something

98
00:05:02.710 --> 00:05:06.480

99
00:05:06.480 --> 00:05:09.950
So this is something that exists
if you want to experiment

100
00:05:09.950 --> 00:05:12.160
with your more artistic side.

101
00:05:12.160 --> 00:05:16.770
Also underneath this art history
brush tool is the history brush tool.

102
00:05:16.770 --> 00:05:20.390
So what it does is it lets you
undo the brushing that you did.

103
00:05:21.830 --> 00:05:24.320
Okay, so it's not so destructive,

104
00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:29.560
it's just affecting your brush strokes
that you made with your art history brush.

105
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:30.290
Okay?

106
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:33.070
So that was just kind of a one off
random brush that didn't quite fit

107
00:05:33.070 --> 00:05:35.110
with any of the other brushes.

108
00:05:35.110 --> 00:05:36.595
But that's your art history brush.

109
00:05:36.595 --> 00:05:37.095
[LAUGH]
>> Very cool.

110
00:05:37.095 --> 00:05:38.270
That was very cool.

111
00:05:38.270 --> 00:05:39.040
I like that.

112
00:05:40.170 --> 00:05:43.060
>> Okay, so
now we're going to be talking about

113
00:05:43.060 --> 00:05:44.360
erasers
>> So,

114
00:05:44.360 --> 00:05:47.070
erasers are this fascinating
thing in Photoshop.

115
00:05:47.070 --> 00:05:48.500
They are great.

116
00:05:48.500 --> 00:05:52.160
They are more distructive
than other options.

117
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:56.270
You're gonna be learning about
layer masks later on in Photoshop.

118
00:05:56.270 --> 00:06:00.810
That's usually your best way to
erase things if you don't want to

119
00:06:00.810 --> 00:06:03.190
really erase it,
cuz layer masks just hide.

120
00:06:03.190 --> 00:06:05.870
But if you don't want to see

00:06:05.870 --> 00:06:08.040
you can use your regular eraser.

122
00:06:08.040 --> 00:06:11.620
So let's try out that
concept of the eraser.

123
00:06:11.620 --> 00:06:15.160
So we can use this image that we have
up here already because it's there.

124
00:06:15.160 --> 00:06:20.550
So I'm going to click on the eraser, it's
over on the left side of my tools panel.

125
00:06:20.550 --> 00:06:23.640
The shortcut for
the eraser tool is the letter e.

126
00:06:23.640 --> 00:06:25.920
So as you're working in Photoshop
you're going to want to know

127
00:06:25.920 --> 00:06:26.890
the shortcuts, it's very fast.

128
00:06:26.890 --> 00:06:28.770
I'm going to click on eraser.

129
00:06:30.290 --> 00:06:33.430
And you'll notice that I

00:06:33.430 --> 00:06:34.430
That's odd, isn't it?

131
00:06:34.430 --> 00:06:35.060
>> That's very odd.
>> Well,

132
00:06:35.060 --> 00:06:36.400
let's see what happens if I single click.

133
00:06:38.020 --> 00:06:39.980
Okay.
So I'm erasing part of,

134
00:06:39.980 --> 00:06:42.451
part of my art history brush tricks
in the shape of a butterfly.

135
00:06:42.451 --> 00:06:43.930
>> [LAUGH].
>> That's odd.

136
00:06:43.930 --> 00:06:45.810
I wonder why that would be happening?

137
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:48.730
>> Wait.
If we think back, I think you told us that

00:06:48.730 --> 00:06:52.280
a lot of these tools remember what you
set them to the last time you used them.

139
00:06:52.280 --> 00:06:54.060
Could that be what it is?

140
00:06:54.060 --> 00:06:55.650
>> That's precisely what it is, so

141
00:06:55.650 --> 00:07:00.680
what we need to do is go into our
little brush panel off the top,

142
00:07:00.680 --> 00:07:06.270
just the same for the eraser and I'm
going to pick just a regular hard brush.

143
00:07:06.270 --> 00:07:10.740
So this one is very large, so I'm gonna
single click and you'll see okay,

144
00:07:10.740 --> 00:07:14.530
now I'm starting to see that
regular Tennessee image behind.

145
00:07:16.530 --> 00:07:20.390
Okay, so you'll notice that what happened
was it only erased the top layer.

146
00:07:20.390 --> 00:07:23.290
You can't really tell because
these layers have the same colors,

147
00:07:23.290 --> 00:07:25.520
so let me demonstrate that for you.

148
00:07:25.520 --> 00:07:28.350
Let's hide the layer beneath,
so our layer zero.

149
00:07:29.660 --> 00:07:30.530
If I had that,

00:07:30.530 --> 00:07:34.790
you'll notice, all of a sudden, that I

151
00:07:34.790 --> 00:07:35.370
We erased it.

152
00:07:36.960 --> 00:07:41.970
Now if everything were on the same layer,
so if these were merged together,

153
00:07:41.970 --> 00:07:46.270
and you erased,
you would be erasing everything.

154
00:07:46.270 --> 00:07:49.800
So that's why it's really important
in Photoshop to use your layers

155
00:07:49.800 --> 00:07:50.530
appropriately.

156
00:07:50.530 --> 00:07:53.080
And so that way you don't
accidentally delete something

157
00:07:53.080 --> 00:07:54.150
that you don't want to delete.

158
00:07:55.240 --> 00:07:58.690
Okay, so the eraser works like a brush.

159
00:07:58.690 --> 00:08:01.730
It has very similar options,
basically identical options.

160
00:08:02.790 --> 00:08:05.780
You can change the opacity of an eraser,
it's something that you might want

161
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:08.570
to do if you want to create
more of a feathered effect.

162
00:08:08.570 --> 00:08:10.340
So let's play around with that.

163
00:08:11.720 --> 00:08:14.720
So here is 48 percent and
you'll notice that it's.

164
00:08:14.720 --> 00:08:20.730
It's kind of making them see through there

165
00:08:22.080 --> 00:08:25.040
So it almost looks like we ghosted

166
00:08:25.040 --> 00:08:28.570
little ghostly friends popped in and
now there's some weird shadows there.

167
00:08:28.570 --> 00:08:31.060
That's because of that opacity.

168
00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:35.310
So erasers are something that you're going
to want to play around with quite a bit,

169
00:08:35.310 --> 00:08:38.727
and it can be very frustrating if
you forget what layer you're on.

170
00:08:38.727 --> 00:08:42.496
So as a reminder,
always look at your layers panel.

171
00:08:42.496 --> 00:08:45.278
So let's pretend like I didn't

172
00:08:45.278 --> 00:08:48.700
some reason I was on my background

173
00:08:48.700 --> 00:08:50.100
That is not what I want to do.

174
00:08:50.100 --> 00:08:53.810
I did not want to take
apart part of my tree.

175
00:08:53.810 --> 00:08:59.540
But if you'll notice if I zoom in, you

176
00:08:59.540 --> 00:09:01.965
It almost looks like a globe

00:09:01.965 --> 00:09:04.550

>> The reason why is because our opacity

00:09:04.550 --> 00:09:06.590
is set at that 48%.

00:09:06.590 --> 00:09:08.785
So let's change it to 100.

00:09:11.689 --> 00:09:13.300
Let's try that again.

00:09:13.300 --> 00:09:17.570
Now it's a very hard edged erased piece.

00:09:18.750 --> 00:09:20.660

There are no,

00:09:23.182 --> 00:09:26.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] There are no more pixels here.

186
00:09:26.420 --> 00:09:30.100
So just like you had with your brushes you
can also adjust your hardness as well.

187
00:09:30.100 --> 00:09:34.870
So if you didn't want it to be such a hard

188
00:09:34.870 --> 00:09:39.140

look is pretty popular in photography.

00:09:40.770 --> 00:09:44.750
Okay, so those are your basic erasers.

00:09:44.750 --> 00:09:46.850
So, use it just as a brush.

00:09:46.850 --> 00:09:47.910

Okay.

And now I'm going to

So I'm going to go to Open, and

Okay, so Sandwich, Open.

00:10:33.640 --> 00:10:35.630
It's kind of a burger

And I'm going to go ahead and unlock it.

So, I'm making my eraser smaller,

Now you'll notice,

00:11:25.220 --> 00:11:26.450

00:13:05.360 --> 00:13:08.332

Okay, so let's say that I

This is a great time to use

00:13:33.780 --> 00:13:36.610

266
00:13:36.610 --> 00:13:40.530
I'm going to grab the eraser,

00:13:40.530 --> 00:13:41.640
that's a little large.

00:13:41.640 --> 00:13:46.016

00:13:46.016 --> 00:13:48.590

00:13:48.590 --> 00:13:53.240

271
00:13:54.800 --> 00:13:58.190
So the great thing about an eraser

00:13:58.190 --> 00:13:59.350

00:13:59.350 --> 00:14:02.690

00:14:02.690 --> 00:14:04.640

00:14:04.640 --> 00:14:09.170
So using your brackets, the left bracket

00:14:09.170 --> 00:14:12.650
You can get in here and really erase.

00:14:22.290 --> 00:14:24.870
Okay, let's say I'm just erasing away,

00:14:24.870 --> 00:14:27.960

Now since I was holding down on the mouse

00:14:49.980 --> 00:14:51.280
So.

00:14:51.280 --> 00:14:53.010
You can erase to your heart's content.

But erasing is something you're going

00:14:56.330 --> 00:14:58.360

00:15:00.060 --> 00:15:00.600
