learned like erasing, things like that.

309
00:16:00.000 --> 00:16:02.150
It's the art history panel.

310
00:16:02.150 --> 00:16:06.070
So what we need to do is we
need to access that panel.

311
00:16:06.070 --> 00:16:08.490
So where do we go for our panels?

312
00:16:08.490 --> 00:16:10.580
Does anybody, do you remember?

313
00:16:10.580 --> 00:16:11.807
>> I do not.
>> You need a refresher?

314
00:16:11.807 --> 00:16:12.440
>> I do.
>> Okay.

315
00:16:12.440 --> 00:16:15.250
I imagine our audience does
as well because we haven't

316
00:16:15.250 --> 00:16:16.760
worked with panels in a while.

317
00:16:16.760 --> 00:16:21.480
So let's go up to Window, and
you're going to look for History.

318
00:16:21.480 --> 00:16:22.370
Okay?

319
00:16:22.370 --> 00:16:25.010
So you can click History.

320
00:16:25.010 --> 00:16:29.220
And you'll notice that that
lists all of our status changes.

321
00:16:29.220 --> 00:16:29.890
Okay.

322
00:16:29.890 --> 00:16:32.290
So all the different times
I clicked an eraser.

323
00:16:32.290 --> 00:16:34.960
All the times I did the art history brush.

324
00:16:34.960 --> 00:16:38.510
The reason why it says it just once is
because I was holding down the mouse

325
00:16:38.510 --> 00:16:39.750
the entire time.

326
00:16:39.750 --> 00:16:45.310
So if I'd let go and clicked every time I
clicked would be a new art status change.

327
00:16:45.310 --> 00:16:46.990
A new history state.

328
00:16:46.990 --> 00:16:51.190
So what this does is it allows you
to go back farther than just doing

329
00:16:51.190 --> 00:16:53.800
Control Alt Z, Control Alt Z,
Control Alt Z.

330
00:16:53.800 --> 00:16:56.536
So we can go and
select a very particular state.

331
00:16:56.536 --> 00:17:03.432
So let's go and just pick all the way up,
let's see, here.

332
00:17:03.432 --> 00:17:05.416
So I can go all the way up
to a very early state, and

333
00:17:05.416 --> 00:17:08.550
you'll notice that my
background has reappeared.

334
00:17:08.550 --> 00:17:12.550
Reason why is because now
we've erased back further.

335
00:17:12.550 --> 00:17:15.730
Now there are even more status changes
that aren't showing the reason why is

336
00:17:15.730 --> 00:17:19.760
because Photoshop defaults to showing
you a very specific number of

337
00:17:19.760 --> 00:17:23.320
history states so
you can change that in your preferences.

338
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:26.520
It's highly recommended that you
have a lot of history states so

339
00:17:26.520 --> 00:17:29.390
that way if you're doing some
kind of really large document

340
00:17:29.390 --> 00:17:33.500
you can just go back at any point in time
and go back to a specific status change.

341
00:17:34.670 --> 00:17:37.420
Okay?
So you'll see as I click around in here,

342
00:17:37.420 --> 00:17:40.468
you'll see exactly what
status change it is.

343
00:17:40.468 --> 00:17:42.850
>> Fantastic.

344
00:17:42.850 --> 00:17:43.480
All right Kara.

345
00:17:43.480 --> 00:17:45.000
Well again, another great episode.

346
00:17:45.000 --> 00:17:48.420
A lot of very good information on,
one, a new brush.

347
00:17:48.420 --> 00:17:50.570
We saw that art history brush there.

348
00:17:50.570 --> 00:17:55.190
And then a good look at the erasers, and
how we can use those to remove pixels.

349
00:17:55.190 --> 00:17:56.630
Remember, that's the destructive way.

350
00:17:56.630 --> 00:17:59.830
We're going to learn about
layer masks in future episodes

351
00:17:59.830 --> 00:18:01.950
that are not quite as destructive
to our original photos.

352
00:18:01.950 --> 00:18:03.250
And we thank you for that.

353
00:18:03.250 --> 00:18:05.350
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

354
00:18:05.350 --> 00:18:07.330
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

355
00:18:07.330 --> 00:18:08.320
>> And I'm Kara Page.

356
00:18:08.320 --> 00:18:09.734
>> And we'll see you next time.

357
00:18:09.734 --> 00:18:16.967
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Try It Out! Brushes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.197 --> 00:00:15.353
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.353 --> 00:00:21.150
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:21.150 --> 00:00:22.840
And in this episode, it's time for

5
00:00:22.840 --> 00:00:26.190
another one of those fun
filled try it out exercises.

6
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:28.570
We're gonna be doing brushes in this one.

7
00:00:28.570 --> 00:00:30.480
So here to help us is Ms. Kara Page.

8
00:00:30.480 --> 00:00:31.730
How you doing, Kara?

9
00:00:31.730 --> 00:00:33.680
>> I'm great.
Are you ready to test out your

10
00:00:33.680 --> 00:00:34.790
brush skill knowledge?

11
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:36.090
>> I am ready.

12
00:00:36.090 --> 00:00:38.190
>> All right,
let's go ahead and get started.

13
00:00:38.190 --> 00:00:42.010
So open up Photoshop so
you're ready to go.

14
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:45.640
And this time we're actually going
to create a document from scratch.

15
00:00:45.640 --> 00:00:49.210
So go ahead and
get your window ready and rolling.

16
00:00:49.210 --> 00:00:50.240
All right.

17
00:00:50.240 --> 00:00:55.450
We we're gonna go ahead and
do new, or you can do file new.

18
00:00:55.450 --> 00:00:58.730
Whatever version of Photoshop you have
just make sure you access a new document.

19
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:02.860
And I'm going to make
mine six by four inches,

20
00:01:02.860 --> 00:01:05.280
that's one of those
standard picture sizes.

21
00:01:06.380 --> 00:01:08.630
And I'm going to change
my resolution to 72.

22
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:12.060
So I'm creating something for the Web.

23
00:01:12.060 --> 00:01:14.830
So it doesn't need to be CMYK either,
it needs to be RGB.

24
00:01:14.830 --> 00:01:17.530
So 72, RGB, we are good to go.

25
00:01:17.530 --> 00:01:22.650
So, let's go ahead and click OK,
and there is my blank Document.

26
00:01:22.650 --> 00:01:26.080
So what we're going to be doing
first is we're going to be creating

27
00:01:27.170 --> 00:01:29.020
a manmade gradient.

28
00:01:29.020 --> 00:01:31.510
So you don't necessarily know
what a gradient is yet so

29
00:01:31.510 --> 00:01:36.010
we're just going to play around with
brushes and create a gradient of colors.

30
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:39.050
So kind of a fading effect and
this is going to be our sky for

31
00:01:39.050 --> 00:01:41.290
this Little tutorial that we're doing.

32
00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:41.890
>> Awesome.

33
00:01:41.890 --> 00:01:45.460
>> So what we need to do first is we
need to select our color from the bottom

34
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:46.080
left corner.

35
00:01:47.140 --> 00:01:51.530
Go ahead and select some kind of blue
that you feel represents the sky.

36
00:01:51.530 --> 00:01:54.890
So I'm going to do a darker blue
at the bottom of my document

37
00:01:54.890 --> 00:01:57.070
fading into a lighter blue at the top.

38
00:01:57.070 --> 00:01:59.210
So I'm going to pick
one right around here.

39
00:01:59.210 --> 00:02:00.990
You can pick any blue that you like,
though.

40
00:02:00.990 --> 00:02:02.400
It's completely up to you.

41
00:02:02.400 --> 00:02:03.570
So I'm gonna go ahead and click okay.

42
00:02:05.020 --> 00:02:06.510
And we need to select our brush.

43
00:02:06.510 --> 00:02:09.180
So to do that,
we would go up to right here,

44
00:02:09.180 --> 00:02:11.740
where you have this brush tip and
the number.

45
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:14.000
Select this down arrow.

46
00:02:14.000 --> 00:02:17.220
And I'm going to just select a hard brush,

47
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:22.040
and I'm going to make it, maybe let's
do 80 pixels, see how that looks.

48
00:02:23.200 --> 00:02:26.400
All right, so this is a pretty large
brush, I'm just gonna click, hold,

49
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:28.410
and drag it across the bottom.

50
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:31.040
Again if you wanted this to
be an exact straight line,

51
00:02:31.040 --> 00:02:32.900
you would hold own Shift as you do it.

52
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:35.880
But, I'm not really interested in
making it look straight, per se.

53
00:02:35.880 --> 00:02:37.900
I just want this cool little
pattern that we're gonna have.

54
00:02:37.900 --> 00:02:40.090
So there's my first stroke in blue.

55
00:02:40.090 --> 00:02:45.170
I'm gonna go back over to my
colors foreground panel, and

56
00:02:45.170 --> 00:02:49.640
I'm going to select a blue directly above
it, so it's just a little bit lighter.

57
00:02:49.640 --> 00:02:51.240
Draw another line across.

58
00:02:53.040 --> 00:02:56.470
You don't want any white between them
cuz you don't want this random white

59
00:02:56.470 --> 00:02:57.380
straight line cloud.

60
00:02:57.380 --> 00:02:58.040
We don't want that.

61
00:02:58.040 --> 00:03:00.130
Plus we're gonna be creating
clouds in a minute.

62
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:03.200
So just no whitespace,
just connect your lines.

63
00:03:03.200 --> 00:03:06.570
We're gonna do the same thing,
add an even lighter blue.

64
00:03:08.880 --> 00:03:11.120
And then finally, your lightest blue.

65
00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:18.450
So now we have this sort of gradient,
it's very rough.

66
00:03:18.450 --> 00:03:21.720
Now if you wanted it to look
more exact and free-flowing,

67
00:03:21.720 --> 00:03:24.950
we would change the hardness,
the opacity, play around with that.

68
00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:27.590
We really don't care,
as long as we have blue in our background.

69
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:29.800
That's what we're going for right now.

70
00:03:29.800 --> 00:03:33.970
So, we're going to jump ahead and
get a sneak peek at something, just so

71
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:37.170
we know how to create a more
accurate looking sky.

72
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:40.930
So, what we're going to do is we're
going to go to our filter menu.

73
00:03:40.930 --> 00:03:44.170
I have shown you where
the filter menu is before.

74
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:48.250
I'm gonna click on Filter,
go down to this word called Render.

75
00:03:48.250 --> 00:03:53.320
And you'll notice that it gives
you an option for Clouds.

76
00:03:53.320 --> 00:03:57.960
Now before you click it, make sure that
you have blue as your foreground color and

77
00:03:57.960 --> 00:04:01.370
white as your background color,
or vice versa.

78
00:04:01.370 --> 00:04:03.780
You don't want random orange clouds or
green clouds.

79
00:04:03.780 --> 00:04:05.780
That just wouldn't look [LAUGH] too good.

80
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:07.310
So make sure you have blue and white.

81
00:04:07.310 --> 00:04:10.378
We're gonna go render,
clouds, and there we have

82
00:04:10.378 --> 00:04:11.524
>> Wow.

83
00:04:11.524 --> 00:04:15.032
>> This beautiful cloud like pattern
with the click of a button, so see,

84
00:04:15.032 --> 00:04:16.230
impress your friends.

85
00:04:16.230 --> 00:04:20.380
That's a great trick, and it's card
of like a card trick so there you go.

86
00:04:20.380 --> 00:04:21.880
So that's the first
thing that we've done so

87
00:04:21.880 --> 00:04:25.810
we've created this kind of manmade
gradient, we created clouds over it.

88
00:04:25.810 --> 00:04:28.770
So it's a pretty realistic looking sky.

89
00:04:28.770 --> 00:04:29.830
>> It really is.

90
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:32.750
>> So now we're going to
add some grass to it, so

91
00:04:32.750 --> 00:04:36.320
what we're going to do first
is let's change our colors.

92
00:04:36.320 --> 00:04:40.040
So I'm going to make my foreground
color a light green, so

93
00:04:40.040 --> 00:04:42.080
I'm gonna click over here
on my color spectrum.

94
00:04:43.130 --> 00:04:45.670
Select a lighter green.

95
00:04:46.720 --> 00:04:50.420
And then for your background color,
select your white box and

96
00:04:50.420 --> 00:04:54.230
I'm going to pick a darker green.

97
00:04:54.230 --> 00:04:58.340
So I have two colors now, but that doesn't
really do me much good because if I just

98
00:04:58.340 --> 00:05:01.900
single click with this brush,
it just shows you the foreground color.

99
00:05:01.900 --> 00:05:04.690
We're not going to be using just
your standard run of the mill brush.

100
00:05:04.690 --> 00:05:06.110
So I'm going to undo what I just did and

101
00:05:06.110 --> 00:05:08.520
we're going to find
the brush we're gonna use.

102
00:05:08.520 --> 00:05:13.590
So, if you come down to this brush
presets panel, we can scroll down and

103
00:05:13.590 --> 00:05:16.730
find the brush that says 112.

104
00:05:16.730 --> 00:05:20.800
So brush 112 is actually a grass brush.

105
00:05:20.800 --> 00:05:22.350
It'll say grass if you hover over it.

106
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:28.390
You can also use it for things like fur or
hair, but we're going to use it for grass.

107
00:05:28.390 --> 00:05:30.740
So I'm going to select that, it's 112.

108
00:05:30.740 --> 00:05:32.190
112's a fine default.

109
00:05:32.190 --> 00:05:34.890
Going to click away from that so
I don't see my panel, And

110
00:05:34.890 --> 00:05:39.050
I'm just gonna click, hold, and
drag across the bottom of my document.

111
00:05:39.050 --> 00:05:42.830
If you just single click you can do that
as well, but it does have that built in

112
00:05:42.830 --> 00:05:46.310
variance because of it's presents,
so it gives that random look.

113
00:05:46.310 --> 00:05:49.002
So I'm just gonna click, hold,
and drag across the bottom.

114
00:05:53.277 --> 00:05:57.416
Okay, so now that this is nice and
filled in, now we have a sky and

115
00:05:57.416 --> 00:05:58.755
we have some grass.

116
00:05:58.755 --> 00:06:03.560
[LAUGH] All right, so I'm going to
start using my Layers panel now,

117
00:06:03.560 --> 00:06:05.040
just so we stay organized.

118
00:06:05.040 --> 00:06:08.180
And that way, if I want to erase
one layer and not the other, I can.

119
00:06:08.180 --> 00:06:10.180
So let's go to our layers panel.

120
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:11.340
This is our background layer.

121
00:06:11.340 --> 00:06:12.480
That's completely fine.

122
00:06:12.480 --> 00:06:13.990
Let's make a new layer.

123
00:06:15.140 --> 00:06:16.860
Okay.
So you're gonna click on this

124
00:06:16.860 --> 00:06:21.180
new layer icon at the bottom and
I'm going to name this flower.

125
00:06:22.540 --> 00:06:23.040
All right.
So

126
00:06:23.040 --> 00:06:27.690
what we're going to do is we
are going to draw out a flower.

127
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:28.990
So I'm going to use my brush.

128
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:31.820
And I'm gonna come up here and
find a brush that speaks to me.

129
00:06:31.820 --> 00:06:34.080
So a brush can by any
kind of brush you want.

130
00:06:35.320 --> 00:06:38.960
I'm going to use just one of these more
artistic brushes up at the top, but

131
00:06:38.960 --> 00:06:41.970
you're welcome to use any
brush that your heart desires.

132
00:06:41.970 --> 00:06:42.780
So I'm gonna click on that.

133
00:06:43.910 --> 00:06:47.100
And the 112 is gonna be little
bit large for my flower.

134
00:06:47.100 --> 00:06:50.180
Because if I were to do that now,
that's not what I want at all.

135
00:06:50.180 --> 00:06:55.120
So I'm going to change over here,
just to a solid round, and

136
00:06:55.120 --> 00:06:59.450
change the 112, let's try something,
we'll raise it by like 20.

137
00:06:59.450 --> 00:07:02.840
Okay, that's a little bit better,
although it's still probably too big.

138
00:07:02.840 --> 00:07:03.490
Let's test it out.

139
00:07:03.490 --> 00:07:04.705
Let's do Just do a single click.

140
00:07:06.055 --> 00:07:09.745
That's a little bit large compared
to our grass cuz you do want

141
00:07:09.745 --> 00:07:10.905
to keep proper proportions.

142
00:07:10.905 --> 00:07:12.225
So I'm gonna undo that and

143
00:07:12.225 --> 00:07:16.315
I'm going to adjust the brush size without
going back up to this brush tool bar.

144
00:07:16.315 --> 00:07:19.235
Do you remember how to do that,
how to adjust the brush size?

145
00:07:19.235 --> 00:07:20.775
>> The brackets.

146
00:07:20.775 --> 00:07:23.055
>> Yup,
this is when you would use those brackets.

147
00:07:23.055 --> 00:07:26.850
So again, left bracket makes it smaller,
right bracket makes it larger.

148
00:07:26.850 --> 00:07:28.800
So I'm gonna make it smaller and

149
00:07:28.800 --> 00:07:32.990
I'm going to pick a color that
would look like a flower.

150
00:07:32.990 --> 00:07:35.620
So I'm going to pick I don't know.

151
00:07:35.620 --> 00:07:38.850
Let's choose a nice kind of reddish color.

152
00:07:40.270 --> 00:07:43.640
And I'm just going to draw any
kind of flower that you want.

153
00:07:43.640 --> 00:07:44.620
It really doesn't matter.

154
00:07:44.620 --> 00:07:47.830
I'm just gonna do a little
daisy type flower.

155
00:07:52.025 --> 00:07:54.730
Okay, so now I have this flower,
let's say I want to use it again,

156
00:07:54.730 --> 00:07:56.950
I want to make a brush out of it.

157
00:07:58.400 --> 00:07:59.490
Do we know how to do that?

158
00:07:59.490 --> 00:08:02.280
We've learned it,
let's see if we can do it.

159
00:08:02.280 --> 00:08:06.220
So you'll notice that flower is on it's
own layer, I did that intentionally so

160
00:08:06.220 --> 00:08:07.160
that way.

161
00:08:07.160 --> 00:08:10.030
We didn't have that same thing
happen with the K as it did

162
00:08:10.030 --> 00:08:12.150
with the butterfly where
they're both on the same layer.

163
00:08:12.150 --> 00:08:15.840
We don't want that so to just avoid
that flower's on it's own layer.

164
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:19.520
Let's go up to edit and
define brush preset.

165
00:08:21.010 --> 00:08:26.900
And you'll notice well doggone it's on
the background layer too so what can

166
00:08:26.900 --> 00:08:31.730
we do to just select the flower What we
can do is use one of our selection tools.

167
00:08:32.750 --> 00:08:38.100
I'm going to just use the magic wand and
just single click on my flower.

168
00:08:39.310 --> 00:08:44.750
Go up to edit, define brush preset,
and there we go.

169
00:08:44.750 --> 00:08:47.620
So if that ever happens to you if
there's some weird little glitch or

170
00:08:47.620 --> 00:08:50.440
you don't know why things are not
where they are supposed to be.

171
00:08:50.440 --> 00:08:51.725
That's what the selection tools are for.

172
00:08:51.725 --> 00:08:54.530
[LAUGH] All right, so
I'm gonna name this flower.

173
00:08:56.070 --> 00:08:59.590
Okay, so
now if I were to come over to my brush and

174
00:08:59.590 --> 00:09:04.390
scroll all the way to the bottom, you'll
see I have a brush and it's called flower.

175
00:09:04.390 --> 00:09:09.090
So if I wanted to I could, let's go ahead.

176
00:09:09.090 --> 00:09:10.830
Okay.
Watch what happens if I try to click.

177
00:09:11.830 --> 00:09:12.560
Nothing.

178
00:09:12.560 --> 00:09:13.200
>> Nothing.

179
00:09:13.200 --> 00:09:13.900
>> What in the world?

180
00:09:13.900 --> 00:09:15.150
Why is that happening?

181
00:09:15.150 --> 00:09:17.740
Now if you think back to selections,
when we went over that,

182
00:09:17.740 --> 00:09:19.090
we have our running ants up here.

183
00:09:19.090 --> 00:09:21.520
So that means that we have
a selection that's active.

184
00:09:21.520 --> 00:09:23.640
When that happens,
you can't do anything else.

185
00:09:23.640 --> 00:09:24.680
You're stuck.

186
00:09:24.680 --> 00:09:26.290
We need to deselect.

187
00:09:26.290 --> 00:09:30.944
So as a reminder, you can do Cmnd + D or
Ctrl + D to deselect.

188
00:09:30.944 --> 00:09:35.600
So now we're deselected, we should be able
to just single click and get our flower.

189
00:09:35.600 --> 00:09:36.120
So there we go.

190
00:09:36.120 --> 00:09:37.590
>> Very cool.

191
00:09:37.590 --> 00:09:38.800
>> We have flowers.

192
00:09:38.800 --> 00:09:40.670
We could just do as many
flowers as we want.

193
00:09:40.670 --> 00:09:43.340
If you wanted to draw stems you could, or

194
00:09:43.340 --> 00:09:47.940
you can create a custom brush preset
where you can change the colors up.

195
00:09:47.940 --> 00:09:51.550
You can change the variance of
how large and small they are.

196
00:09:51.550 --> 00:09:53.180
So let's try that out.

197
00:09:53.180 --> 00:09:57.160
Let's go ahead up to here to
this folder that has the little

198
00:09:57.160 --> 00:09:58.765
flowers on it that are really brushes.

199
00:09:58.765 --> 00:10:00.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

200
00:10:00.430 --> 00:10:04.780
then let's go ahead and
do some shape dynamics.

201
00:10:04.780 --> 00:10:06.159
So shape dynamics.

202
00:10:07.390 --> 00:10:12.300
We can change the size,
we can change the diameter, the angle,

203
00:10:12.300 --> 00:10:15.660
how round they are,
let's play around with the scattering.

204
00:10:15.660 --> 00:10:19.950
Right now it's not scattered at all, so
they're all stacked on top of each other,

205
00:10:19.950 --> 00:10:21.050
not ideal.

206
00:10:21.050 --> 00:10:25.100
If you spread them out,
you'll have this fun little thing happen.

207
00:10:25.100 --> 00:10:27.280
So let's see what happens
if we were to drag.

208
00:10:27.280 --> 00:10:29.855
All of a sudden we're just filling
our document with these flowers.

209
00:10:29.855 --> 00:10:30.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

210
00:10:30.830 --> 00:10:33.600
what you could do if you wanted to
create this kind of cool pattern,

211
00:10:33.600 --> 00:10:36.000
let's say that you want
something on your notebook.

212
00:10:36.000 --> 00:10:37.620
Or your making something for a client and

213
00:10:37.620 --> 00:10:40.420
you want to do a pattern with some
kind of custom brush you did.

214
00:10:40.420 --> 00:10:41.330
This is how you would do it.

215
00:10:41.330 --> 00:10:43.980
You'd come into the presets and
you can just fill an entire

216
00:10:43.980 --> 00:10:47.710
background with whatever kind
of brush You really want.

217
00:10:47.710 --> 00:10:50.860
So this is a little bit much for what
we're doing, so I'm going to undo a few

218
00:10:50.860 --> 00:10:56.680
times and get back to where we
just have the one single flower.

219
00:10:57.820 --> 00:10:58.610
Okay.

220
00:10:58.610 --> 00:11:03.650
So now I want to add a stem to this
one single flower how would I do that?

221
00:11:03.650 --> 00:11:04.809
Let's go back to the brush.

222
00:11:06.420 --> 00:11:11.860
And I'm going to change this brush to be,
let's try this,

223
00:11:11.860 --> 00:11:18.350
this round blunt medium, but
let's make it a lot smaller and

224
00:11:18.350 --> 00:11:25.660
let's see what happens if we go ahead and
draw it out.

225
00:11:25.660 --> 00:11:28.540
Now it's red, I don't want it to be red,
that seem silly.

226
00:11:28.540 --> 00:11:31.640
So, before you draw with the brush
tool make sure to change your color.

227
00:11:31.640 --> 00:11:36.711
So, I'm gonna undo that and
I'm just gonna select some kind of green.

228
00:11:39.985 --> 00:11:43.470
And draw just like that.

229
00:11:43.470 --> 00:11:47.030
So as you experiment with brushes, they
all have different kind of looks to them.

230
00:11:47.030 --> 00:11:49.560
So let's zoom in to this brush so
you can really see the stroke difference.

231
00:11:51.010 --> 00:11:54.020
So this one has kind of gaps in it.

232
00:11:54.020 --> 00:11:57.220
It really imitates a real paint brush.

233
00:11:57.220 --> 00:11:59.900
So let's see what would
happen if we added to

234
00:11:59.900 --> 00:12:02.069
this little leaf with
a different kind of brush.

235
00:12:03.070 --> 00:12:05.620
So you'll notice that when
we're zoomed in this much, or

236
00:12:05.620 --> 00:12:10.510
if you're using a large brush it will
show you the little bristle dots.

237
00:12:10.510 --> 00:12:13.690
Pretend as if you have a physical
paint brush in your hand and

238
00:12:13.690 --> 00:12:17.090
you dipped it in paint, and
then just set it on the piece of paper.

239
00:12:17.090 --> 00:12:20.160
This would be exactly where
those bristles hit the paper.

240
00:12:20.160 --> 00:12:23.520
So let's go ahead and
Draw out another leaf.

241
00:12:23.520 --> 00:12:25.830
So you'll see this one is kind of similar.

242
00:12:25.830 --> 00:12:29.170
It has more spacing,
We'll try it with an different color,

243
00:12:29.170 --> 00:12:30.980
I'm going to reverse my colors over here.

244
00:12:32.100 --> 00:12:33.210
Let's do another one.

245
00:12:33.210 --> 00:12:38.140
So this fan brush has a very
different type of tip.

246
00:12:42.590 --> 00:12:43.360
And there we go.

247
00:12:43.360 --> 00:12:45.930
Now If you didn't know and

248
00:12:45.930 --> 00:12:50.220
if you just painted an entire little
painting in Photoshop, I doubt many people

249
00:12:50.220 --> 00:12:54.810
would be able to tell the difference if
you got it printed on a textured canvas.

250
00:12:54.810 --> 00:12:58.605
So it'll be our little secret if you
decide to become a Photoshop painter.

251
00:12:58.605 --> 00:13:02.150
[LAUGH] [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] All right Carrie.

252
00:13:02.150 --> 00:13:02.670
>> All right.

253
00:13:02.670 --> 00:13:03.830
>> That was a lot of fun there.

254
00:13:03.830 --> 00:13:04.510
Thanks for that.

255
00:13:04.510 --> 00:13:08.180
We had a good time learning how to really
take everything we learned about brushes

256
00:13:08.180 --> 00:13:09.880
and kinda combine it in an exercise.

257
00:13:09.880 --> 00:13:12.670
And we ended up with a beautiful
little scenery that we have.

258
00:13:12.670 --> 00:13:15.290
All right, well we hope everybody
out there enjoyed watching.

259
00:13:15.290 --> 00:13:17.940
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

260
00:13:17.940 --> 00:13:18.510
>> And I'm Kara Page.

261
00:13:18.510 --> 00:13:19.749
>> And we'll see you next time.

262
00:13:19.749 --> 00:13:28.189
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Project Management for Photoshop
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:07.309 --> 00:00:17.309
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:19.436 --> 00:00:22.890
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at IT ProTV.

3
00:00:22.890 --> 00:00:24.129
I'm you're host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:24.129 --> 00:00:26.290
Today we're doing Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

5
00:00:26.290 --> 00:00:32.300
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be looking at project management.

6
00:00:32.300 --> 00:00:33.160
Now, don't get scared.

7
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:37.330
We're not going into project management,
but project management for Photoshop.

8
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:38.840
All right.
There are certain things that we need to

9
00:00:38.840 --> 00:00:43.370
be familiar with in order to keep
our projects on track, as well as

10
00:00:43.370 --> 00:00:46.700
be able to pass that exam, and her to
help us with that, is Ms. Kara Page.

11
00:00:46.700 --> 00:00:47.600
How you doing, Kara?

12
00:00:47.600 --> 00:00:49.790
>> I'm great,
Are you ready to talk about some concepts?

13
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:50.810
>> I am ready.

14
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:56.160
>> All right, so these are concepts
specific to your ACA examination.

15
00:00:56.160 --> 00:00:58.590
So let's go ahead and get started.

16
00:00:58.590 --> 00:01:02.030
So the first thing is what is project
management in the first place?

17
00:01:02.030 --> 00:01:06.645
So project management is understanding
what your project is, who your

18
00:01:06.645 --> 00:01:11.710
projects for, what your deadlines are and
what your clients going to even like.

19
00:01:11.710 --> 00:01:17.030
So the first step in project management is
figuring out who your target audience is.

20
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:21.080
So, your target audience is a specific
group of people that you intend to reach

21
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:22.870
with your message.

22
00:01:22.870 --> 00:01:26.350
So let's say that you
are designing a flyer, and

23
00:01:26.350 --> 00:01:28.790
your flyer is for high school students.

24
00:01:28.790 --> 00:01:30.230
Maybe it's a flyer for Prom.

25
00:01:31.500 --> 00:01:34.300
You would think about your target audience
when you're designing that flyer, so

26
00:01:34.300 --> 00:01:38.090
you would use colors that would appeal
to them, fonts that appeal to them,

27
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:39.740
imagery that appeals to them.

28
00:01:39.740 --> 00:01:40.390
Okay.

29
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:45.330
If you were designing let's say, a mail
out little postcard for the elderly, it'll

30
00:01:45.330 --> 00:01:48.980
probably look very different than what you
designed for your high school friends.

31
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:51.190
So that's your target audience.

32
00:01:51.190 --> 00:01:53.890
Your target audience needs
to be specifically defined.

33
00:01:53.890 --> 00:01:56.440
So your client might know
specifically who it is.

34
00:01:56.440 --> 00:02:00.070
If not, you need to decide
who you're trying to reach.

35
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:01.790
So think about demographics.

36
00:02:01.790 --> 00:02:05.290
Demographics are things like age and
where they live.

37
00:02:05.290 --> 00:02:09.380
Psychographics are things like
attitudes lifestyles believes

38
00:02:09.380 --> 00:02:11.320
what these people like to do.

39
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:14.940
So an example target audience might
be like what I have on this slide,

40
00:02:14.940 --> 00:02:19.630
high school students ages 14 to 18 who
live in Florida and enjoy surfing,

41
00:02:19.630 --> 00:02:22.450
spending time with friends and
using social media.

42
00:02:22.450 --> 00:02:26.870
So if that were your target audience,
you kind of know who your trying to reach.

43
00:02:26.870 --> 00:02:28.270
Okay?

44
00:02:28.270 --> 00:02:31.025
The important part of setting
a target audience is not only

45
00:02:31.025 --> 00:02:34.240
are you going to be able to create
more effective designs, but

46
00:02:34.240 --> 00:02:37.540
you are going to be able to
set project goals as well.

47
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:42.260
And last but not least is
the target audience determines your

48
00:02:42.260 --> 00:02:45.240
style in the content
of your final project.

49
00:02:45.240 --> 00:02:48.440
So that's why you need to
figure out who they are first.

50
00:02:48.440 --> 00:02:51.940
So once you know who they are,
where they are, and what they like to do,

51
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:55.170
you need to figure out your project scope.

52
00:02:55.170 --> 00:02:58.700
So your project scope is
essentially an outline that

53
00:02:58.700 --> 00:03:00.960
explains exactly what you need to create.

54
00:03:00.960 --> 00:03:06.190
So if you're creating flyers, postcards,
websites, this is where you'd list all

55
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:10.190
those things out along with their project
requirements as determined by your client.

56
00:03:11.790 --> 00:03:15.170
Also under project scope is
determining how much time each

57
00:03:15.170 --> 00:03:17.560
one of these projects is going to take.

58
00:03:17.560 --> 00:03:19.030
So if you're designing a logo,

59
00:03:19.030 --> 00:03:22.060
maybe you know that it normally
takes you four hours to do a logo.

60
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:27.620
You would need to set aside at least
four hours to create that logo project.

61
00:03:28.690 --> 00:03:32.050
Another thing with project scope is
you need to know that all requirements

62
00:03:32.050 --> 00:03:32.640
have been met.

63
00:03:32.640 --> 00:03:35.890
So by having a list of
requirements from your client,

64
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:39.300
you can cross check to make sure
that you've included everything.

65
00:03:39.300 --> 00:03:42.770
So let's say that you are designing
something for print and your client says,

66
00:03:42.770 --> 00:03:47.760
my website has to be on every
single piece of printed work.

67
00:03:47.760 --> 00:03:50.460
You would have a check off
system that allows you

68
00:03:50.460 --> 00:03:53.430
to double check to make sure
that you did include a website.

69
00:03:55.290 --> 00:03:59.760
Once you understand what you're creating,
now it's time to brainstorm ideas.

70
00:03:59.760 --> 00:04:03.720
So you know who you're trying to reach,
what you're trying to reach them with.

71
00:04:03.720 --> 00:04:07.550
Now you need to decide how you're
going to reach them with your message.

72
00:04:07.550 --> 00:04:12.380
So this is the fun part of
your project management steps.

73
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:15.928
You're going to brainstorming,
researching, sketching,

74
00:04:15.928 --> 00:04:20.450
finding inspiration, and
really getting inspired to feel creative.

75
00:04:20.450 --> 00:04:23.450
Now if you are somebody that says
to yourself, I am not creative,

76
00:04:23.450 --> 00:04:24.350
that is not true.

77
00:04:24.350 --> 00:04:27.713
Every single person has
creativity inside them somewhere.

78
00:04:27.713 --> 00:04:29.973
>> [LAUGH] You are reading my mind.

79
00:04:29.973 --> 00:04:34.300
>> [LAUGH] You are creative you just
have to find your inner creativity,

80
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:36.630
just think back to when you were a child.

81
00:04:36.630 --> 00:04:38.020
So maybe you were a kid and

82
00:04:38.020 --> 00:04:41.700
you had this big brown box because
your parents just ordered a new couch.

83
00:04:41.700 --> 00:04:43.940
So there's this huge box
in your living room.

84
00:04:43.940 --> 00:04:46.820
You turn it into a fort,
a bus, all sorts of things.

85
00:04:46.820 --> 00:04:47.980
That is your creativity.

86
00:04:47.980 --> 00:04:50.850
You just need to tap back
into your inner child.

87
00:04:50.850 --> 00:04:52.630
>> So
next time I work on a Photoshop project,

88
00:04:52.630 --> 00:04:56.760
I'm gonna get my refrigerator box out,
sit in there, and see what I can do.

89
00:04:56.760 --> 00:04:58.495
>> You could.
That's a little extreme.

90
00:04:58.495 --> 00:05:00.150
>> [LAUGH]
>> I might recommend just

91
00:05:00.150 --> 00:05:01.414
starting with sketching.

92
00:05:01.414 --> 00:05:03.000
>> Okay.
>> Maybe play some board games,

93
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:04.450
get out play a sport.

94
00:05:04.450 --> 00:05:07.680
You just never know when a creative
idea is going to hit you.

95
00:05:07.680 --> 00:05:11.190
So if you hit a creative wall
at any point, walk outside.

96
00:05:11.190 --> 00:05:13.130
Take a different route to school,

97
00:05:13.130 --> 00:05:16.880
do something that's a little
bit different to break routine.

98
00:05:16.880 --> 00:05:19.470
So once you have brainstormed,
you have some ideas.

99
00:05:19.470 --> 00:05:20.700
Now it's time to doodle and

100
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:24.840
sketch out those ideas to see
what kind of layout works best.

101
00:05:24.840 --> 00:05:26.140
So doodle, sketch.

102
00:05:26.140 --> 00:05:28.130
You can never sketch too much.

103
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.240
Maybe if you're designing a logo.

104
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:32.140
You have 20 different logo ideas.

105
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:36.830
Jot them all down, cuz it'll help you
determine what ideas are the most solid.

106
00:05:36.830 --> 00:05:39.370
If you can't decide because
they're like your children,

107
00:05:39.370 --> 00:05:41.955
you love each one equally,
ask a friend for help.

108
00:05:41.955 --> 00:05:42.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or

109
00:05:42.670 --> 00:05:46.530
ask a client to see which
they feel is the most strong.

110
00:05:47.680 --> 00:05:49.795
So it's always important to
have your sketches on hand too,

111
00:05:49.795 --> 00:05:54.150
cuz if you do meet with a client
before you create solid comps,

112
00:05:54.150 --> 00:05:56.480
which are computer
versions of your sketches.

113
00:05:56.480 --> 00:05:59.370
You can show the client your sketches and
they will give you feedback, so

114
00:05:59.370 --> 00:06:00.820
that way you don't waste hours and

115
00:06:00.820 --> 00:06:03.422
hours in Photoshop on something
that they don't like.

116
00:06:03.422 --> 00:06:05.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] The more time you spend

117
00:06:05.950 --> 00:06:09.250
brainstorming, the more effective
your time will be on the computer, so

118
00:06:09.250 --> 00:06:10.350
don't skip this step.

119
00:06:12.200 --> 00:06:13.910
Now that you have your ideas,

120
00:06:13.910 --> 00:06:17.450
now it's time to actually
engage in the design process.

121
00:06:17.450 --> 00:06:20.670
So you have your step one,
now you've sketched ideas on paper.

122
00:06:20.670 --> 00:06:22.700
Once you have your sketches,
you enter step two.

123
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:25.240
Which is creating a mock up or comp.

124
00:06:25.240 --> 00:06:26.760
So a comp is a comprehensive.

125
00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:30.700
It's something that you create
on your computer in Photoshop.

126
00:06:30.700 --> 00:06:35.140
It's a visual representation of what
your final project will look like.

127
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:37.800
A comp is a prototype.

128
00:06:37.800 --> 00:06:38.940
That's another way to think of it.

129
00:06:38.940 --> 00:06:43.430
So think of it like what your
final product will look like,

130
00:06:43.430 --> 00:06:47.300
it's a rough draft, but
it looks polished and clean.

131
00:06:47.300 --> 00:06:51.820
Step three is presenting that comp or
prototype to the client for review.

132
00:06:51.820 --> 00:06:55.045
They're going to give you feedback,
probably lots of edits.

133
00:06:55.045 --> 00:06:58.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just be kind, take in all the edits.

134
00:06:58.270 --> 00:06:59.180
They are the client.

135
00:06:59.180 --> 00:07:01.250
They're probably paying you for your work.

136
00:07:01.250 --> 00:07:03.079
So don't talk back, the client knows best.

137
00:07:03.079 --> 00:07:05.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, just jot everything down.

138
00:07:05.760 --> 00:07:09.880
Discuss what changes are going to
be made and then make those edits.

139
00:07:09.880 --> 00:07:12.390
And then you'll have your final document.

140
00:07:13.430 --> 00:07:16.600
So this is how you plan for
that successful project.

141
00:07:16.600 --> 00:07:18.650
Step one is planning and analysis.

142
00:07:18.650 --> 00:07:21.210
That's where you determine
all the items that you need.

143
00:07:21.210 --> 00:07:23.280
Those items are called deliverables.

144
00:07:23.280 --> 00:07:25.820
So if you're creating three fliers,
one postcard,

145
00:07:27.000 --> 00:07:30.780
two little emails,
those are all your deliverables.

146
00:07:30.780 --> 00:07:31.910
You'll need to write them out,

147
00:07:31.910 --> 00:07:34.920
and that way you know that
you're not missing one [LAUGH].

148
00:07:34.920 --> 00:07:39.010
Step two is scheduling, so figure out how
much time you think each piece is gong

149
00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:44.110
to take you, and then allocate time for
each of those projects.

150
00:07:44.110 --> 00:07:45.990
You don't wanna feel like you are rushing,
so

151
00:07:45.990 --> 00:07:49.900
make sure that you allow ample time for
all of your projects.

152
00:07:49.900 --> 00:07:52.240
Step three is actually building,
so that is where you sketch,

153
00:07:52.240 --> 00:07:57.070
you create you design comps,
you get ready to show the client.

154
00:07:57.070 --> 00:07:59.950
And then, you move into step four,
which is reviewing and

155
00:07:59.950 --> 00:08:01.380
evaluating with the client.

156
00:08:01.380 --> 00:08:03.690
So, before you even show the client,

157
00:08:03.690 --> 00:08:06.610
first review your work to make
sure there aren't spelling errors.

158
00:08:06.610 --> 00:08:08.095
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, do your spell check.

159
00:08:08.095 --> 00:08:10.970
Check to make sure that you've
included all the mandatories.

160
00:08:10.970 --> 00:08:16.050
So a mandatory might be a copyright logo,
or a logo, or

161
00:08:16.050 --> 00:08:21.040
a slogan, or any type of thing that
would be under your viewing section.

162
00:08:22.280 --> 00:08:25.180
Once it's evaluated,
it's good to go, the client loves it,

163
00:08:25.180 --> 00:08:29.660
now it's time to implement or
publish once you get that final approval.

164
00:08:29.660 --> 00:08:33.040
So implementing might be
watching a website live or

165
00:08:33.040 --> 00:08:36.290
publishing might be actually sending
your document to the printer.

166
00:08:36.290 --> 00:08:39.040
So getting it print ready
by looking at your proofs.

167
00:08:40.940 --> 00:08:43.410
So tips for successful project management.

168
00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:46.790
It's highly recommended that you
work with a project manager.

169
00:08:46.790 --> 00:08:49.620
If you work in some kind of design agency,
chances are,

170
00:08:49.620 --> 00:08:54.280
you will have a project manager that make
sure that you're on track at all times,

171
00:08:54.280 --> 00:08:59.480
they communicate with the client and they
make sure the client needs are satisfied.

172
00:08:59.480 --> 00:09:02.540
The project manager also keeps
the designer on schedule.

173
00:09:02.540 --> 00:09:05.480
Now if you're standing out just
by yourself, chances are you

174
00:09:05.480 --> 00:09:09.595
are your own project manager, so
you need to be detail oriented and

175
00:09:09.595 --> 00:09:12.820
organized to make sure that you
meet all deadlines on time and

176
00:09:12.820 --> 00:09:14.960
that you're delivering
everything that you need to.

177
00:09:16.180 --> 00:09:19.130
A project manager can also help up
with keeping up with scope creep.

178
00:09:19.130 --> 00:09:21.940
Scope creep is where there
are changes in the projects once

179
00:09:21.940 --> 00:09:23.540
the projects are underway.

180
00:09:23.540 --> 00:09:27.940
So maybe a client decided to
change details of a sale.

181
00:09:27.940 --> 00:09:31.060
You need to make sure that
you include those changes

182
00:09:31.060 --> 00:09:35.120
about the sale in your Photoshop documents
as well, or your products in general.

183
00:09:36.430 --> 00:09:38.020
So that was about project management.

184
00:09:38.020 --> 00:09:40.810
Now it's time to talk about something
called intellectual property.

185
00:09:42.730 --> 00:09:44.910
So what is intellectual
property in the first place?

186
00:09:44.910 --> 00:09:48.630
Intellectual property refers to
any property of human intellect.

187
00:09:48.630 --> 00:09:50.370
So it's something that
you've created yourself.

188
00:09:50.370 --> 00:09:52.910
So if you've come up with song lyrics or

189
00:09:52.910 --> 00:09:57.800
you've taken a photo,
this would be your intellectual property.

190
00:09:57.800 --> 00:10:01.740
So examples of what falls under this
umbrella of intellectual property

191
00:10:01.740 --> 00:10:05.880
includes literary and artistic works,
designs, symbols, names and

192
00:10:05.880 --> 00:10:07.680
images used in business.

193
00:10:07.680 --> 00:10:12.400
So if you're using a trade name or a the
brand name, that is copyrighted material

194
00:10:12.400 --> 00:10:16.640
or intellectual property or
trademarked property.

195
00:10:16.640 --> 00:10:18.520
That means that somebody can't come in and

196
00:10:18.520 --> 00:10:23.590
use your name without your permission
to sell a good or a product or service.

197
00:10:25.300 --> 00:10:28.275
So copyrights are what you're going
to primarily be dealing with.

198
00:10:28.275 --> 00:10:31.285
Copyrights protect intellectual
property and gives the author or

199
00:10:31.285 --> 00:10:33.905
creator of the work exclusive rights.

200
00:10:33.905 --> 00:10:38.165
So let's say that you are an artist and
you did this beautiful canvas painting and

201
00:10:38.165 --> 00:10:42.880
it took you 100 hours to do, and
it was just beautiful, and it was amazing.

202
00:10:42.880 --> 00:10:46.610
And you hang it up in a gallery,
and then somebody steals your work.

203
00:10:46.610 --> 00:10:48.350
Maybe not physically steals it,

204
00:10:48.350 --> 00:10:53.090
they don't take it from the gallery, but
they replicate it and call it their own.

205
00:10:53.090 --> 00:10:56.670
So maybe they go home in Photoshop,
or they go home and paint it,

206
00:10:56.670 --> 00:10:58.830
based off what they saw you do,

207
00:10:58.830 --> 00:11:04.380
that would be taking over your exclusive
rights to distribution and publication.

208
00:11:04.380 --> 00:11:05.820
So that is not okay.

209
00:11:05.820 --> 00:11:08.530
So if you see something
that's beautiful online, and

210
00:11:08.530 --> 00:11:13.020
you wanna re-create it exactly,
don't do that, find your own special spin.

211
00:11:14.310 --> 00:11:17.810
Copyrights can only be given to
original works of authorship,

212
00:11:17.810 --> 00:11:22.100
which means that it is not
just a copy it's original.

213
00:11:22.100 --> 00:11:24.530
It's something that you created yourself.

214
00:11:24.530 --> 00:11:28.230
An important thing to note is that
just an idea can not be copyrighted.

215
00:11:28.230 --> 00:11:31.040
So if you have an idea, that's great.

216
00:11:31.040 --> 00:11:34.130
But that idea can't be copyrighted.

217
00:11:34.130 --> 00:11:38.420
You also can't copyright something like
a utilitarian good like a light bulb.

218
00:11:38.420 --> 00:11:40.200
Something that we use.

219
00:11:40.200 --> 00:11:44.470
So examples of works that can be
copyrighted include artistic, dramatic,

220
00:11:44.470 --> 00:11:46.120
literary and musical works.

221
00:11:46.120 --> 00:11:49.450
So, you can copyright a song,
you can copyright a book,

222
00:11:49.450 --> 00:11:51.630
you can copyright a movie.

223
00:11:51.630 --> 00:11:55.220
Any of those things are copyrightable.

224
00:11:55.220 --> 00:11:57.310
So the 1976 Copyright Act,

225
00:11:57.310 --> 00:12:02.370
that is what gives us exclusive
rights to copy or reproduce work.

226
00:12:02.370 --> 00:12:05.850
So if you're the author of the work,
you can decide

227
00:12:05.850 --> 00:12:08.600
where you want it to be reproduced,
where you want it to be displayed.

228
00:12:08.600 --> 00:12:12.800
You can decide if somebody
can create an adaptation or

229
00:12:12.800 --> 00:12:15.670
a derivative work based on your work.

230
00:12:15.670 --> 00:12:19.310
So a derivative work is something like,
let's say you wrote a novel.

231
00:12:19.310 --> 00:12:21.630
And it's this awesome novel,
everybody loves it.

232
00:12:21.630 --> 00:12:23.690
They want to turn it into a movie.

233
00:12:23.690 --> 00:12:29.020
Since the original storyline was yours,
you would have to sign off allowing

234
00:12:29.020 --> 00:12:32.530
somebody else to use that movie
because it is a derivative work.

235
00:12:32.530 --> 00:12:34.800
It's a secondary work
off of your original.

236
00:12:35.910 --> 00:12:40.480
You also have exclusive rights to
distribute copies of your work, and

237
00:12:40.480 --> 00:12:43.160
to perform and display the work publicly.

238
00:12:43.160 --> 00:12:45.550
So for example, songs on the radio.

239
00:12:45.550 --> 00:12:47.725
Radio stations pay to play those songs.

240
00:12:47.725 --> 00:12:49.460
>> Mm-hm.

241
00:12:49.460 --> 00:12:51.670
>> If you have something
that's copyrighted.

242
00:12:51.670 --> 00:12:56.390
You need to include a copyright notice,
which includes copyright or COPR,

243
00:12:56.390 --> 00:13:01.040
you can abbreviate it, the little
copyright symbol, the year, and your name.

244
00:13:02.760 --> 00:13:04.930
If you really want a solid copyright,

245
00:13:04.930 --> 00:13:10.360
you should also file your copyright claim
with the Library of Congress in DC.

246
00:13:10.360 --> 00:13:15.060
If you do that then you are more
likely to win a battle in court,

247
00:13:15.060 --> 00:13:15.980
if it comes down to that.

248
00:13:15.980 --> 00:13:20.120
If you just slap, copy right on to
the bottom of the sheet of paper.

249
00:13:20.120 --> 00:13:21.510
That's great, you can do that.

250
00:13:21.510 --> 00:13:22.720
But!

251
00:13:22.720 --> 00:13:27.375
How is somebody going to prove in court
that you actually created it on that date?

252
00:13:27.375 --> 00:13:27.920
>> Hm-mm.

253
00:13:27.920 --> 00:13:29.730
>> Okay, so keep that in mind.

254
00:13:29.730 --> 00:13:34.710
It is your responsibility to add
this notice to your work, okay?

255
00:13:34.710 --> 00:13:36.570
So if you're doing something
like photography or art,

256
00:13:36.570 --> 00:13:38.542
make sure to add your copyright notice.

257
00:13:38.542 --> 00:13:42.480
All right, so
I already explained this briefly,

258
00:13:42.480 --> 00:13:46.215
but derivative works are works
based on work that already exists.

259
00:13:46.215 --> 00:13:48.605
So, different version of a song.

260
00:13:48.605 --> 00:13:53.325
So, maybe a song was originally a pop song
and a country artist wants to re do it.

261
00:13:53.325 --> 00:13:54.945
That's a derivative work.

262
00:13:54.945 --> 00:13:59.730
You do need permission from
the author to do that.

263
00:13:59.730 --> 00:14:01.320
Derivative works, once they are created,

264
00:14:01.320 --> 00:14:03.510
they become separate
from the original work.

265
00:14:03.510 --> 00:14:05.850
So a movie stands alone from the book.

266
00:14:09.140 --> 00:14:11.640
Also under copyrights is something
called the fair use doctrine.

267
00:14:11.640 --> 00:14:15.050
The fair use doctrine allows
you to use copyrighted work.

268
00:14:15.050 --> 00:14:17.950
You can reproduce it for specific reasons.

269
00:14:17.950 --> 00:14:19.610
So often times,

270
00:14:19.610 --> 00:14:23.610
you can include copyrighted
material if you're reporting news.

271
00:14:23.610 --> 00:14:27.990
If you're commenting and criticizing
something, praising for education,

272
00:14:27.990 --> 00:14:29.500
parody and research.

273
00:14:29.500 --> 00:14:33.210
So there are four factors considered
when determining fair use.

274
00:14:33.210 --> 00:14:37.820
So, fair use just means that you use
something that somebody else owns, but

275
00:14:37.820 --> 00:14:40.490
you're using it for
a reason that is protected.

276
00:14:40.490 --> 00:14:42.390
So, these are the four
factors they look at.

277
00:14:42.390 --> 00:14:45.030
The first is purpose and
character of work.

278
00:14:45.030 --> 00:14:50.330
So, if you are, let's say,
copying a page or two of a textbook.

279
00:14:50.330 --> 00:14:52.900
And you're sharing it with a class and
you are using it for

280
00:14:52.900 --> 00:14:57.070
education, that's going to be more
likely to be protected than if somebody

281
00:14:57.070 --> 00:15:01.690
had copied pieces of your work and
resold them.

282
00:15:01.690 --> 00:15:06.650
So if it's a for profit use, that's
probably not going to fall under fair use.

283
00:15:06.650 --> 00:15:09.240
The second thing to look at is
nature of copyrighted work.

284
00:15:09.240 --> 00:15:15.870
If the work has been published before,
how easy it is to access this information.

285
00:15:15.870 --> 00:15:19.920
So if it's a book that you can pick up in
any airport and you're copying ten pages

286
00:15:19.920 --> 00:15:24.220
of it, probably not gonna be okay,
because it's easy to get a hold of.

287
00:15:24.220 --> 00:15:27.510
You're kind of hurting author's
ability to make a profit,

288
00:15:27.510 --> 00:15:29.370
because people aren't gonna go out and
buy the book.

289
00:15:29.370 --> 00:15:32.810
They're just gonna read
the ten page excerpt, okay?

290
00:15:32.810 --> 00:15:35.500
Also if the work has been published or
not is a big thing that they look at.

291
00:15:35.500 --> 00:15:37.350
So if the work is unpublished.

292
00:15:37.350 --> 00:15:42.520
Let's say that you are writing a story and
it's a biography and you're just, Writing

293
00:15:42.520 --> 00:15:46.150
it, your about to publish it, you've
sent it to different literary houses for

294
00:15:46.150 --> 00:15:52.120
review and one of them publishes ten pages
of it before it's been published by you,

295
00:15:52.120 --> 00:15:53.540
that would not be fair use.

296
00:15:53.540 --> 00:15:58.200
You have the original right to publication
and distribution of your work.

297
00:15:58.200 --> 00:16:00.020
So, keep that in mind.

298
00:16:00.020 --> 00:16:04.430
The next factor they're going to look at
is amount and substantiality of work used.

299
00:16:04.430 --> 00:16:10.190
So, let's say that you have a novel and
it's a 100 pages long,

300
00:16:10.190 --> 00:16:15.750
and you as a teacher, you copy just
three paragraphs out of that book.

301
00:16:15.750 --> 00:16:17.460
That's not a very
substantial amount of work.

302
00:16:17.460 --> 00:16:19.840
That's probably gonna fall under fair use.

303
00:16:19.840 --> 00:16:25.040
If you had copied the most
central points of that book, so

304
00:16:25.040 --> 00:16:30.142
the key plot outlines, you copied multiple
pages, that is a lot of pages and

305
00:16:30.142 --> 00:16:34.580
it's a substantial amount of the work
used, not gonna fall under fair use.

306
00:16:34.580 --> 00:16:38.260
And last but not least, is the effect
of the use upon the potential market.

307
00:16:38.260 --> 00:16:41.850
So, if you by using this artwork or

308
00:16:41.850 --> 00:16:44.180
this original copyrighted
material in a different way,

309
00:16:44.180 --> 00:16:48.880
if that's going to negatively effect the
original author, that would be an issue.

310
00:16:51.290 --> 00:16:53.580
So, whenever you're dealing
with copywrited material.

311
00:16:53.580 --> 00:16:58.670
So let's say that you are using
images that you found online.

312
00:16:58.670 --> 00:17:02.020
So, you're creating a pamphlet for
somebody, a brochure.

313
00:17:02.020 --> 00:17:04.710
And you wanna use other peoples' photos.

314
00:17:04.710 --> 00:17:09.340
Make sure you obtain permission
to use those photos, okay?

315
00:17:09.340 --> 00:17:13.060
It's not always enough just to cite
the source of your copywrited materials.

316
00:17:13.060 --> 00:17:16.560
And make sure you buy either buy
the rights to use that photo or

317
00:17:16.560 --> 00:17:21.040
that the photo is in the public domain and
is free for use and distribution or

318
00:17:21.040 --> 00:17:23.550
receive permission from that author.

319
00:17:23.550 --> 00:17:28.450
And now that you know a little
bit of background, it's time for

320
00:17:28.450 --> 00:17:30.130
you to start designing.

321
00:17:30.130 --> 00:17:32.030
So, good luck.

322
00:17:32.030 --> 00:17:33.710
>> All right, Kara,
thanks for that information.

323
00:17:33.710 --> 00:17:34.990
A lot of really good stuff there.

324
00:17:34.990 --> 00:17:39.550
Important terms and concepts that we
can apply to our Photoshop career,

325
00:17:39.550 --> 00:17:44.080
as well as help us get past that
Photoshop exam, so we thank you for that.

326
00:17:44.080 --> 00:17:47.325
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching,
signing off for IT ProTV.

327
00:17:47.325 --> 00:17:49.180
I"ve been your host, Mike Roderick.

328
00:17:49.180 --> 00:17:49.860
>> And I'm Kara Paige.

329
00:17:49.860 --> 00:17:52.051
>> And we'll see you next time.

330
00:17:52.051 --> 00:17:55.289
[MUSIC]

331
00:17:55.289 --> 00:18:00.066
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Masking in Photoshop
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.687 --> 00:00:15.304
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.304 --> 00:00:20.569
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

4
00:00:20.569 --> 00:00:22.702
And specifically in this episode,

5
00:00:22.702 --> 00:00:26.570
we're going to be looking at
masking within Photoshop.

6
00:00:26.570 --> 00:00:28.790
We've got layer mask,
we've got clipping mask.

7
00:00:28.790 --> 00:00:30.989
We've got masks for masquerade parties.

8
00:00:30.989 --> 00:00:32.785
Wait, maybe not the last one,
but definitely the first two.

9
00:00:32.785 --> 00:00:36.500
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Nick Page, how's it going, Nick?

10
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:37.130
>> Pretty good.

11
00:00:37.130 --> 00:00:39.640
Let's dive right into masking here.

12
00:00:39.640 --> 00:00:43.000
So with masking, think of masking tape.

13
00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:45.560
Do you know what you'd do for
masking tape if you're painting?

14
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:48.080
>> Yeah, trying to keep paint from
going on to the wrong places,

15
00:00:48.080 --> 00:00:49.480
the places you don't want it to?

16
00:00:49.480 --> 00:00:52.883
>> That kinda works, but in this case,
we're doing destructive and

17
00:00:52.883 --> 00:00:54.418
non-destructive editing.

18
00:00:54.418 --> 00:00:59.279
So we've been hearing these
words this whole time,

19
00:00:59.279 --> 00:01:04.120
this whole series,
what is destructive editing?

20
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:08.470
So do you-
>> Not quite sure, but it sounds bad.

21
00:01:08.470 --> 00:01:12.800
>> All right, so let's dive right into
Photoshop, and I will go over this

22
00:01:12.800 --> 00:01:17.190
theory with you, not a theory,
it's just this whole concept there.

23
00:01:17.190 --> 00:01:21.950
So in Photoshop,
I'll go to File > Open, and

24
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:26.209
then here, I'll pick this waves picture.

25
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:31.640
So, now, here we have our picture,
I'm gonna zoom in just a little bit.

26
00:01:31.640 --> 00:01:35.490
And I'm gonna show you the way
we've been doing things so far.

27
00:01:36.750 --> 00:01:40.410
We've been doing stuff with like
using the Magic Wand to erase things,

28
00:01:40.410 --> 00:01:41.870
using the Eraser to erase stuff.

29
00:01:41.870 --> 00:01:44.730
So, let me just show you how
we would normally do that.

30
00:01:44.730 --> 00:01:48.123
If I wanted to erase the sky,
it would look pretty bad, but let's do it.

31
00:01:48.123 --> 00:01:53.595
Erase, it's just going, it's gone.

32
00:01:53.595 --> 00:01:58.930
Simple, but now the sky is gone forever,
unless I hit Undo,

33
00:01:58.930 --> 00:02:03.900
but say if I did a bunch of other
things after this, and then I wanted

34
00:02:03.900 --> 00:02:07.560
to bring back that sky later, I'd have to
reload the picture or undo everything.

35
00:02:07.560 --> 00:02:09.330
But if I don't have any undo states to do

36
00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:11.370
that, yeah-
>> So

37
00:02:11.370 --> 00:02:14.020
that would be what we call destructive
editing then because we're

38
00:02:14.020 --> 00:02:16.010
actually destroying the pixels
that used to be there?

39
00:02:16.010 --> 00:02:16.510
>> Exactly.

40
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:20.610
This is the way that people
have been doing Photoshop for

41
00:02:20.610 --> 00:02:25.180
a long time until the whole concept of
nondestructive editing came into play.

42
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:29.730
So, here I'm gonna undo this
because I don't wanna break things.

43
00:02:29.730 --> 00:02:35.710
Undo and then undo, let's go to my
history panel to show up these.

44
00:02:36.740 --> 00:02:37.670
>> Bring our sky back.

45
00:02:37.670 --> 00:02:41.130
>> Yeah, there, each step I took,
back to where I opened it.

46
00:02:41.130 --> 00:02:43.578
So, first things first, I will start
off my layers panel right over here.

47
00:02:43.578 --> 00:02:45.840
And then, I'm gonna unlock this layer.

48
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:49.583
This just can show you, so
now when I do your aces,

49
00:02:49.583 --> 00:02:51.542
you can see the transparency behind it.

50
00:02:51.542 --> 00:02:53.731
I'm gonna undo that.

51
00:02:53.731 --> 00:03:01.600
So now, let me show you first layers.

52
00:03:01.600 --> 00:03:03.270
We're gonna create a layer mask.

53
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:06.150
A layer mask is a way to
do nondestructive editing.

54
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:06.970
So first,

55
00:03:06.970 --> 00:03:10.630
I'll just show you how to create it, and
then I'll show you what it all means.

56
00:03:10.630 --> 00:03:14.250
Here, on the layers panel,
go down to this little icon.

57
00:03:14.250 --> 00:03:16.250
It's very small in the bottom right.

58
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:21.030
It looks like a white square with a black
circle in it, kind of like a camera.

59
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:22.530
It says Add Layer Mask, so

60
00:03:22.530 --> 00:03:27.570
I'll click that, and now you see on the
layers panel right next to my thumbnail,

61
00:03:27.570 --> 00:03:33.000
there's a chain link and
a white rectangle or square.

62
00:03:33.000 --> 00:03:34.660
This is the mask.

63
00:03:34.660 --> 00:03:38.293
Layer masking works based off
of two colors, black and white.

64
00:03:38.293 --> 00:03:44.030
And I'll just take my brush and
start painting.

65
00:03:44.030 --> 00:03:47.260
So, make sure the layer mask
is selected right here.

66
00:03:47.260 --> 00:03:50.250
And I'll just paint with a black brush.

67
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:52.670
Now, what does this look like I'm doing?

68
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:54.600
>> It looks like you're erasing.

69
00:03:54.600 --> 00:04:00.060
>> I am, but the picture is still there,
and you can see the thumbnail.

70
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:04.020
The mask is what is having
the black on it, so

71
00:04:04.020 --> 00:04:07.590
it looks like I'm taking what is on
the mask and erasing that from the image.

72
00:04:08.660 --> 00:04:14.520
But if I wanted to, I can right click
this and I can Disable Layer Mask.

73
00:04:14.520 --> 00:04:16.905
My pictures is still in its full glory.

74
00:04:16.905 --> 00:04:18.910
>> Uh-huh.

75
00:04:18.910 --> 00:04:21.590
>> Just the mask kind of
modifies the existing pixels-

76
00:04:21.590 --> 00:04:23.320
>> Anywhere that you're painting black on

77
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:26.880
that layer mask, it's gonna hide
those pixels, but not remove them.

78
00:04:26.880 --> 00:04:28.060
>> Exactly.

79
00:04:28.060 --> 00:04:33.910
So with this, there's a common
little thing to remember this by,

80
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:37.500
a little saying, us Photoshop reviews.

81
00:04:37.500 --> 00:04:41.940
It's called black to conceal,
white to reveal.

82
00:04:41.940 --> 00:04:43.100
That's how to remember this.

83
00:04:43.100 --> 00:04:46.310
So, if you can't remember that,
think of that whole thing,

84
00:04:46.310 --> 00:04:49.530
if you're not sure which one is which,
like was it white to conceal?

85
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:51.840
Think of alphabetical order.

86
00:04:51.840 --> 00:04:56.479
Black to conceal, BC, and
then the rest, so white to reveal.

87
00:04:56.479 --> 00:04:58.390
>> Okay.

88
00:04:58.390 --> 00:04:59.990
>> So now with that in mind,

00:04:59.990 --> 00:05:04.510
I'm gonna show you how to do
another way to create a layer mask.

00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:05.930
This was the quick way.

00:05:05.930 --> 00:05:09.431
You could also go to the layer panel or
the Layers menu and

00:05:09.431 --> 00:05:11.156

00:05:11.156 --> 00:05:15.600
Let me get rid of this one first to show,

So Layer > Layer Mask, now there

00:05:29.487 --> 00:05:34.490

black to conceal, white to reveal.

00:05:34.490 --> 00:05:36.960

What if I do Hide all,

00:05:40.780 --> 00:05:42.565

00:05:42.565 --> 00:05:43.220

00:05:50.340 --> 00:05:51.530

00:05:51.530 --> 00:05:55.803

The image back.

00:05:58.862 --> 00:06:02.639

00:06:02.639 --> 00:06:06.611

00:06:06.611 --> 00:06:08.383

00:06:08.383 --> 00:06:13.596

00:06:13.596 --> 00:06:18.660

00:06:18.660 --> 00:06:23.470

So if this is a random picture that I had,

00:06:44.585 --> 00:06:45.860

>> This is where this would come

00:06:45.860 --> 00:06:47.200
in to play.

Let's pretend that this

00:06:51.920 --> 00:06:56.888
So now I'll create Layer >

00:07:02.510 --> 00:07:03.490
In this case,

00:07:03.490 --> 00:07:08.720

while you're getting that reset,

00:07:35.143 --> 00:07:38.473
with that transparency one, even though

00:10:28.960 --> 00:10:35.080

00:11:12.747 --> 00:11:15.322
and then

288
00:15:56.095 --> 00:16:00.210
So now it's kind like I
just matted an image.

289
00:16:00.210 --> 00:16:01.548
>> Right, very nice.

290
00:16:01.548 --> 00:16:06.782
>> So, very useful, you could also
do the same thing with text as well,

291
00:16:06.782 --> 00:16:11.226
so if I wanted to write beach,
I'll just do it quick Text.

292
00:16:11.226 --> 00:16:12.021
Beach there.

293
00:16:12.021 --> 00:16:19.030
It's really hard to see now, but
let me get rid of these shapes here.

294
00:16:19.030 --> 00:16:19.795
Is that a beach there?

295
00:16:19.795 --> 00:16:21.000
>> Mm-hm.

296
00:16:21.000 --> 00:16:23.348
>> I want to put
the picture layer above it,

297
00:16:23.348 --> 00:16:27.460
then I'll right-click
>> Gray clipping mask.

298
00:16:27.460 --> 00:16:28.940
There's the beach.

299
00:16:28.940 --> 00:16:32.490
So now, I could move the location
of the actual text, or

300
00:16:32.490 --> 00:16:35.050
I can move the location of the background.

301
00:16:36.570 --> 00:16:39.190
This is a good way to do some really cool

302
00:16:39.190 --> 00:16:42.120
text effects later on if
you want to do voice cards.

303
00:16:42.120 --> 00:16:43.450
>> Absolutely.

304
00:16:43.450 --> 00:16:45.270
>> That's really how they do it.

305
00:16:45.270 --> 00:16:48.130
And it's also the best part about it is

306
00:16:48.130 --> 00:16:51.825
that I'm only showing the text
with the letters beach in there.

307
00:16:51.825 --> 00:16:52.680
>> Mm-hm.

308
00:16:52.680 --> 00:16:54.310
>> But, I'm not destroying anything.

309
00:16:54.310 --> 00:16:57.130
>> So you can actually change
a word later if you wanted to.

310
00:16:57.130 --> 00:16:57.840
>> Yep, exactly.

311
00:16:57.840 --> 00:16:59.750
Change it to Nick.

312
00:17:01.290 --> 00:17:06.570
Double click the text thumbnail there.

313
00:17:06.570 --> 00:17:07.810
So now it's Nick.

314
00:17:07.810 --> 00:17:10.360
>> Very cool.

315
00:17:10.360 --> 00:17:13.490
>> So
that is the basics of clipping masks.

316
00:17:13.490 --> 00:17:14.510
Let's see.

317
00:17:14.510 --> 00:17:19.610
I think that's-
>> So it

318
00:17:19.610 --> 00:17:23.140
looks like the important thing there with
those clipping masks was to make sure that

319
00:17:23.140 --> 00:17:27.130
what you're going to use as a mask was the
next layer under the image has to be that

320
00:17:27.130 --> 00:17:27.810
>> Next one break.

321
00:17:28.850 --> 00:17:33.130
And also, one more thing before I forget,
there's a whole other topic.

322
00:17:33.130 --> 00:17:36.000
Let's do, it's semi related.

323
00:17:36.000 --> 00:17:39.520
It's just kind of a bonus topic here.

324
00:17:39.520 --> 00:17:41.420
Bonuses are great.

325
00:17:41.420 --> 00:17:42.830
This is the refined edge.

326
00:17:42.830 --> 00:17:47.270
I'm gonna close out this current thing,
and I'm going to open a new project.

327
00:17:47.270 --> 00:17:52.020
The refine edge tool, it's really good,
it's kind of an advanced selection method,

328
00:17:52.020 --> 00:17:55.870
but it's advanced but it's easier,
so it's pretty awesome.

329
00:17:55.870 --> 00:17:56.560
>> Okay.

330
00:17:56.560 --> 00:17:57.500
>> So, let's go to file, open.

331
00:17:57.500 --> 00:18:01.913
I'm going to take this picture
of this little puppy, Mei Mei.

332
00:18:01.913 --> 00:18:04.832
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now, we have this dog and I kinda

333
00:18:04.832 --> 00:18:08.960
wanna cut out the dog or I wanna just
put the dog in a different background.

334
00:18:08.960 --> 00:18:13.500
But do you see these strands of hair?

335
00:18:13.500 --> 00:18:16.080
>> That's gonna be a lot of work
with our normal selection tools.

336
00:18:16.080 --> 00:18:20.220
>> That is going to be a ton of work, so
>> Let's open up my layers.

337
00:18:20.220 --> 00:18:23.004
Let's unlock this layer.

338
00:18:23.004 --> 00:18:24.390
Good.

339
00:18:24.390 --> 00:18:29.140
And then, let's create a background color.

340
00:18:29.140 --> 00:18:31.930
I want the dog to be on
a black background, so

341
00:18:31.930 --> 00:18:36.190
I'll select black as my
Paint Bucket tool and I'll fill in.

342
00:18:36.190 --> 00:18:40.530
You see I was doing that behind
the current image just kind of you see how

343
00:18:40.530 --> 00:18:45.175
layers work you could edit the image below
the current one as long as it's selected.

344
00:18:45.175 --> 00:18:46.076
>> [CROSSTALK] You can't see it.

345
00:18:46.076 --> 00:18:46.576
>> Exactly.

346
00:18:47.910 --> 00:18:54.605
So now to do this I'll go to make
the selection as well as I can, at first.

347
00:18:54.605 --> 00:18:56.110
>> Mm-hm.
>> So in this case,

348
00:18:56.110 --> 00:18:59.880
I could use the magic wand tool.

349
00:18:59.880 --> 00:19:04.470
I'll have to change the tolerance
down to probably 20.

350
00:19:04.470 --> 00:19:05.510
Let's do 22.

351
00:19:05.510 --> 00:19:06.120
Make a click.

352
00:19:07.570 --> 00:19:12.770
Right here, it's selecting the multiple
instances of a dark color.

353
00:19:12.770 --> 00:19:19.900
You could see I have a setting
enabled which is somewhere over here.

354
00:19:22.470 --> 00:19:23.229
I do not see it.

355
00:19:26.430 --> 00:19:26.930
Hold on.

356
00:19:30.560 --> 00:19:32.130
Continues, there it is.

357
00:19:32.130 --> 00:19:33.330
Usually has a check box for

358
00:19:33.330 --> 00:19:38.070
the word continuous and it's a thumbnail
now...the things Photoshop does.

359
00:19:38.070 --> 00:19:39.840
So I'm going to click that.

360
00:19:39.840 --> 00:19:43.400
>> Let me try it again.
So now, it's only selecting the touching

361
00:19:43.400 --> 00:19:49.310
colors rather than every color of that
part of the spectrum in the image.

362
00:19:49.310 --> 00:19:53.310
I'll click once, I'll hold shift and
then gonna add to my selection.

363
00:19:53.310 --> 00:19:54.450
Just keep clicking around.

364
00:19:54.450 --> 00:19:59.200
So this is good, but then you see it's
kind of selecting pieces of the dog.

365
00:19:59.200 --> 00:20:00.750
Not very helpful for me.

366
00:20:00.750 --> 00:20:05.570
So, i'll continue just clicking away, and

367
00:20:05.570 --> 00:20:10.610
then here's a use case for the quick
mess tool that we just learned about.

368
00:20:10.610 --> 00:20:15.355
I'll press Q on the keyboard,
now you can see the dog is selected, or

369
00:20:15.355 --> 00:20:18.975
the dog is not selected in the case, I'm
actually selecting the background first.

370
00:20:18.975 --> 00:20:26.115
So let me use my paint brush and
remember black to conceal white to reveal.

371
00:20:26.115 --> 00:20:28.110
So the black.

372
00:20:28.110 --> 00:20:29.680
Technically, the dog is
concealed right now.

373
00:20:29.680 --> 00:20:30.750
That's how I want to keep it.

374
00:20:30.750 --> 00:20:35.470
I accidentally just made a big
old red mark on a quick mask.

375
00:20:35.470 --> 00:20:39.730
I want to undo this, and
then change my color.

376
00:20:39.730 --> 00:20:40.268
Hold on, there.

377
00:20:40.268 --> 00:20:43.502
Undo, there.

378
00:20:45.670 --> 00:20:47.040
Now I want to change my color.

379
00:20:47.040 --> 00:20:48.570
You could use that by pressing x.

380
00:20:48.570 --> 00:20:54.970
On your keyboard to change the colours of
your right here [LAUGH] Yeah the colours.

381
00:20:54.970 --> 00:20:58.460
So I change my foreground colour
to white and start painting.

382
00:20:58.460 --> 00:21:04.380
So now, I want to just get rid
of all this stray hair for now.

383
00:21:06.870 --> 00:21:09.710
There, and then switch to black and

384
00:21:09.710 --> 00:21:14.210
then repaint the dog fully in so
I don't miss a piece of her face.

385
00:21:15.390 --> 00:21:16.030
All right, so

386
00:21:16.030 --> 00:21:20.200
now that I have this selected I'll press
Q again to show the marching ants there.

387
00:21:20.200 --> 00:21:25.130
I want to go to Select > Refine edge.

388
00:21:25.130 --> 00:21:30.800
Its also be done by control alt R or
command option R on a Mac.

389
00:21:32.400 --> 00:21:35.850
So now I have all these settings.

390
00:21:35.850 --> 00:21:40.150
These settings can be manipulated to try
to get the best quality image possible.

391
00:21:40.150 --> 00:21:44.670
But, it requires a lot of fiddling
to get the perfect numbers and

392
00:21:44.670 --> 00:21:47.340
in this case we'll do
something called smart radius.

393
00:21:47.340 --> 00:21:48.100
>> Which is great.

394
00:21:48.100 --> 00:21:50.090
So I'll click that.

395
00:21:50.090 --> 00:21:54.930
And then, I will be able to start
painting around the edge of this.

396
00:21:54.930 --> 00:21:56.410
So, let me change the view right here.

397
00:21:56.410 --> 00:22:00.340
You have options so,
the selection on white.

398
00:22:00.340 --> 00:22:01.635
I can do it on black.

399
00:22:01.635 --> 00:22:04.685
I can do overlay like we were
used to with the quick mask.

400
00:22:04.685 --> 00:22:08.085
Marching ants,
which we've seen a lot as well.

401
00:22:08.085 --> 00:22:12.372
Then you can do the really simple
black and white thing to the layers.

402
00:22:12.372 --> 00:22:15.690
And Reveal Layer just shows
exactly what's there.

403
00:22:15.690 --> 00:22:20.580
For this case, I'll do a overlay for
now just so we can see what's going on.

404
00:22:20.580 --> 00:22:25.010
And I might switch to on black just so
we can see everything as it,

405
00:22:25.010 --> 00:22:30.040
once we start selecting things, refining
the selection, it'll be really obvious.

406
00:22:30.040 --> 00:22:32.350
>> Okay.
>> So let's do that.

407
00:22:32.350 --> 00:22:33.250
Click that.

408
00:22:33.250 --> 00:22:39.210
So now, I want to make my brush size
bigger with the square brackets.

409
00:22:41.220 --> 00:22:44.300
Then I'll start painting along this.

410
00:22:44.300 --> 00:22:47.790
Just kind of along the border for
the selection where the kind

411
00:22:47.790 --> 00:22:51.940
of flyaways will happen, like the hair,
the split ends, the hair.

412
00:22:51.940 --> 00:22:56.801
I'm just gonna keep going along the edge,
and as I do this, it's erasing it and

413
00:22:56.801 --> 00:23:01.174
then filling it in smartly, so
let me kind of zoom in for you right here.

414
00:23:01.174 --> 00:23:04.790
You could see how-
>> Wow, I can see where it's actually

415
00:23:04.790 --> 00:23:10.480
grabbed some of those individual hairs
>> Exactly, yeah it's actually, sorry

416
00:23:10.480 --> 00:23:15.070
about that, yeah, it's actually selecting
the small hairs how small they are.

417
00:23:15.070 --> 00:23:17.430
The magic wand would
never have gotten that.

418
00:23:17.430 --> 00:23:18.300
>> No.

419
00:23:18.300 --> 00:23:20.260
>> So, it's good to have right there.

420
00:23:20.260 --> 00:23:21.910
>> Or
you could spend hours with an eraser or

421
00:23:21.910 --> 00:23:23.590
something trying to get
those little hairs.

422
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:26.430
>> Exactly, so,
I'm trying to keep going over these,

423
00:23:26.430 --> 00:23:28.650
make sure they're captured properly.

424
00:23:31.260 --> 00:23:33.410
>> So basically,
it looks like its erasing it for

425
00:23:33.410 --> 00:23:37.530
a second but you're just telling Photoshop
to take a closer look at this area and

426
00:23:37.530 --> 00:23:38.730
do a little more detailed work there.

427
00:23:38.730 --> 00:23:39.840
>> Exactly.

428
00:23:39.840 --> 00:23:41.570
And Photoshop is really
smart with this so,

429
00:23:41.570 --> 00:23:43.985
a few years ago that wasn't the case,
but now.

430
00:23:43.985 --> 00:23:46.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> They've gotten much better.

431
00:23:46.010 --> 00:23:48.350
So now, it looks pretty good.

432
00:23:48.350 --> 00:23:52.402
So, I'm gonna hit, right down
here there is a bunch of options,

433
00:23:52.402 --> 00:23:56.760
output to Selection,
Layer Mask, New Layer.

434
00:23:56.760 --> 00:23:58.338
Let's do Layer Mask since it's related.

435
00:23:58.338 --> 00:23:58.939
>> Mm-hm.

436
00:23:58.939 --> 00:24:01.120
>> [LAUGH] Then I'll hit OK.

437
00:24:02.510 --> 00:24:07.640
So now, I have a layer mask with
the dog and the background.

438
00:24:07.640 --> 00:24:09.350
But it's kinda backwards.

439
00:24:09.350 --> 00:24:12.430
Let's click on the layer mask, and
being that I'm using black and

440
00:24:12.430 --> 00:24:14.630
white here, I can inverse that.

441
00:24:14.630 --> 00:24:20.650
So on my keyboard, if I press Ctrl+I,

442
00:24:20.650 --> 00:24:23.600
that'll reverse that black and white.

443
00:24:23.600 --> 00:24:26.940
So now,
what's concealed is now revealed and

444
00:24:26.940 --> 00:24:29.870
now the puppy is there
on the black background.

445
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:35.070
But you can kind of see
there's a little area down

446
00:24:35.070 --> 00:24:38.340
there where there's a little bit.

447
00:24:39.660 --> 00:24:42.530
It did well, but not perfect.

448
00:24:42.530 --> 00:24:47.500
We can just simply use the A layer mask.

449
00:24:47.500 --> 00:24:49.410
I want to conceal that.

450
00:24:49.410 --> 00:24:53.760
So, switch to black paintbrush.

451
00:24:53.760 --> 00:24:56.430
And then make it small enough,
and just go down.

452
00:24:56.430 --> 00:24:59.870
Then, set the hardness to really soft,
so it kind of eases you into it.

453
00:24:59.870 --> 00:25:03.652
And just make a few little touch-ups,
like that.

454
00:25:03.652 --> 00:25:04.900
>> Beautiful.

455
00:25:04.900 --> 00:25:08.370
And then, up here too and that's about it.

456
00:25:08.370 --> 00:25:11.580
So, then, there we have our cutout puppy.

457
00:25:13.690 --> 00:25:14.380
Perfect.

458
00:25:14.380 --> 00:25:15.060
>> Fantastic.

459
00:25:15.060 --> 00:25:17.350
>> Yeah
>> All right, Nick,

460
00:25:17.350 --> 00:25:20.420
a lot of great information there when
it comes to working with these masks,

461
00:25:20.420 --> 00:25:25.040
both layer masks and clipping mask and
>> Some really cool ways that we can take

462
00:25:25.040 --> 00:25:27.270
that puppy and get him on his own picture
and get rid of that background, right?

463
00:25:27.270 --> 00:25:28.950
We can put some other background in there.

464
00:25:28.950 --> 00:25:29.970
So, we thank you for that.

465
00:25:29.970 --> 00:25:32.140
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

466
00:25:32.140 --> 00:25:33.360
Signing off for IT Pro TV.

467
00:25:33.360 --> 00:25:34.700
I'm Mike Rodrick.

468
00:25:34.700 --> 00:25:35.490
>> And I'm Nick Paige.

469
00:25:35.490 --> 00:25:37.289
>> And we'll see you next time.

470
00:25:37.289 --> 00:25:45.400
